This must continue to be the case and, to that end, we must reach a specific fisheries agreement. Trade in fishery products should also be continued. About 67% of UK fishing and seafood exports go to European markets. I hope that these trade flows will continue, but to do that, reciprocal access to waters must also be maintained: fish know no frontiers; the management of the fishing stocks we share must also be carried out in close coordination. Fisheries is an area in which we will have to reach a constructive, mutually beneficial future relationship. Access to water and market access must be closely linked.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, two years have passed since that miserable referendum in which a tragic mistake perpetrated by a European ruler was revealed — and not for the first time — to seek to curb populism and europhobia, so represented in this House, by embracing their flags. But the damage is done. Many of us didn't want it. And what we have seen, despite the complexity and darkness that many of the debates on the monitoring of Brexit are, is that European public opinion, which did not want it, has already been done to the idea. But this contrasts with the confusion prevailing in the British position: no clarity with regard to Northern Ireland, Gibraltar — territories which, by the way, voted against Brexit — and, above all, concerns about commercial aviation agreements on the part of companies invested by British capital. That is why they are extremely demanding, Mr Barnier, clarity, resolution and determination, because time is running against us and the hourglass indicates the expiry time of the negotiation. The time to carry it out is now. The hourglass runs against us.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, I just want to say briefly in this debate that I am disappointed that none of the realities of the UK leaving have really been touched upon from the EU point of view, such as the fact that the UK will become the largest single market of the EU when we leave – bigger than China, the United States and Japan, for example. We have a GBP 75 billion deficit with the EU of your goods, and we employ 1.5 million Germans through cars, etc. The City of London is very important in funding EU businesses. I have heard none of this today.  What we need is a super Canada deal, one that is bigger, better and deeper than the one with Canada – which is entirely achievable – and a strategic partnership agreement on foreign affairs, defence and security. I thank Mr Verhofstadt for his support for the UK in respect of the dreadful attack on our soil. When it comes to security, we are as one.

name: Catherine BEARDER
text: – Mr President, this Brexit Government still has no plan: no plan on Northern Ireland, no plan for its citizens, and no plan for businesses. No clear plan is a dereliction of duty. The Church Times wrote, and I quote: ‘when a government sees an impending threat to the people in its care, it fails in its duty if does nothing to remove that threat’. Ms May and her Conservative Government are failing in their duty of care to the country. As the so-called ‘party of business’, it would appear they have no business plan. You can’t run a corner shop without a business plan, let alone a country.  The single market has massive benefits, but it also has rules. This resolution is clear about those rules, and it is reasonable to defend them. But whatever the deal might be, we as the Liberal Democrats demand the people have a say on it. We here will have a vote. It’s likely the Parliament of Wallonia will have a vote. As my hashtag says, #giveusasayMrsMay.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Mr President, Mr Barnier, you have been known as Commissioner for Regional Policy and you know well what fisheries and cohesion policy are. We would like to know whether the European Commission — as we asked you a year ago — has done an impact assessment on European fisheries, particularly with regard to Galicia, since Galicia is a fishing country that will be hit hard by the consequences of Brexit. We would also like to know the impact on the free movement of persons. Many young people from my country have emigrated to the United Kingdom and we do not know what will happen to them as citizens of the Union. They're in a dead end. This is not just one or two people; more than 40,000 people from Galicia live in the United Kingdom.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, people should have the right to decide sovereign their destinies, including when it comes to leaving the European Union. This decision must be respected and the ongoing negotiation process must be free of pressure, threat and blackmail. We reiterate here that the UK's withdrawal agreement from the European Union must not result in a weakening of the rules on migrant workers' rights or other social rights, such as the right of residence, the right to equal treatment, the right of access to public services of the European Union. health care and education, the right to transferability of social security benefits, the right to family reunification and mutual recognition of academic qualifications and professional qualifications. Any future economic and trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the European Union must take into account the specificities and interests of the different Member States, and each Member State should have the right to establish relations with the United Kingdom in a wide range of areas, according to its own interests.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I dare say there are a few in this House that put a few bob on the horses and we should acknowledge that the Cheltenham Festival is today. There might be a few people there discussing Brexit because actually Brexit will damage the horse—racing industry because it relies on EU rules, and I dare say Mr Farage might be interested in that. This is a huge concern for punters, for breeders, for trainers, and we need to find a solution.  Can I also address Prime Minister Theresa May directly? When she spoke in her speech about a precious union of the United Kingdom, I get that. I fully understand it. But, can I say that the European Union is also precious? Not in the way that sometimes precious is perceived; it’s important, it’s vital, and therefore that’s why we defend it.  Can I say that one of the big hurdles we face, continuing the racing metaphor, is that of the border with Northern Ireland? Jim Nicholson has left the Chamber, but he’s a wise man and he, in my view, is a bridge between the extremes of Sinn Fein and the DUP. Perhaps we should listen to him.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Mr President, as the resolution recognises, the logical consequences of the UK Conservative Government’s red lines are customs checks and delays at Dover and elsewhere, which will seriously impact the supply chains not only of UK businesses, but also businesses in the EU27. Theresa May’s red lines have boxed the UK into a corner, with a free trade agreement now the only option. This will be damaging for the EU and a disaster for the United Kingdom. Whitehall’s own assessment of the impact makes for bleak reading. If the UK ends up with only a free trade agreement, it can expected a GDP drop of 5% nationally, including in my South-East constituency. Under WTO rules, which the likes of UKIP want, that would be even worse.  None of this seems to bother the UK Conservatives, who seem to have abandoned UK business entirely, but it will not be their wealthy chums who suffer from this. It will be ordinary people. It is high time this government dropped its red lines and negotiated with an open mind.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President! We are discussing guidelines for future relations between the EU and the UK here today. This is important. However, I also tell you that when I go to the market place at my house or am at the regulars' table, then the people there will not be discussing what will happen with the United Kingdom. What people expect from the Commission is a solution for the EU-27 of the future, in particular a financial solution. And here too, the vernacise is very clear: “We are not paying a cent more, we are paying enough anyway.” Unfortunately, this embassy does not arrive in Brussels. One third of the Brexit gap, says Commissioner Oettinger, is expected to fill Germany — three to four billion euros per year. We are already paying EUR 13 billion more than we get. Plus four is 17, divided by 82 million, power 208 euros per capita. That is why I call in this round: if we find a solution to the budget, let us also discuss guidelines for relations between the EU and its citizens.

name: Michel BARNIER
text: Chief Brexit negotiator. — (FR) Mr President Tajani, Mr President Juncker, thank you for allowing me to speak at the end of this debate, which we have obviously listened very carefully. Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to meet with you to take stock. The majority of British citizens have chosen sovereignly to leave the European Union. It is a choice that we regret, it is a choice that we respect. Now we are implementing it. Brexit means Brexit. But at this stage, I would like to say two things, beforehand, that everyone, here and elsewhere, must understand and keep in mind. First of all, with regard to the United Kingdom, which has chosen to leave the Union: we have had, I have always had, and we will keep until the end, in any case and under all circumstances, for this country — its culture, its people, its history, solidarity with ours in the most tragic moments, its diplomacy — the respect that is due to a great country, a friendly country and an allied country. Secondly, it is important for everyone to understand that, in this extraordinary, complex, extraordinarily complex negotiation, our responsibility, yours, that of the Council and, of course, that of the Commission under President Juncker's authority, our responsibility is to preserve, for the future and for the long term, what we are, Union, our values, our identity, our single market, our common policies. None of this, ladies and gentlemen, none of this is negotiable, and we are responsible for it. Every day — just a little personal word in the mission entrusted to me, at the very beginning, by President Juncker, and which you accompany, ladies and gentlemen — I keep in mind a phrase from a French statesman whom I respected very much, Pierre Mendès France, who said, in a speech, “Never sacrificing the future to present”. Earlier, Mr Hökmark and Mrs McGuinness also said this very forcefully. As we are in this negotiation, at the end of this debate, I want to share with you three messages. First, we must put things in the right order, as we have done from the beginning, to prepare and build a new ambitious partnership with the United Kingdom: the prerequisite — the prerequisite — is to organize its withdrawal in an orderly rather than disorderly manner. Roberto Gualtieri insisted on this point. Under the authority of President Juncker — whom I thank again for his confidence — the Commission — who is doing its job and doing the work you have entrusted to him — presented this comprehensive draft treaty fifteen days ago. Things are now clear, we can have them in your hands. The aim is, through the proposal of this comprehensive draft treaty, to accelerate and facilitate discussion with the British by now working on a legal text. As Danuta Hübner and President Juncker said very well earlier, the time is very short. It is short for the negotiation of the withdrawal agreement, it will be short for negotiation of any future relationship. It is also short — let me stress this — for the preparation that we must carry out in each of our countries and, together with stakeholders, to prepare for the inevitable consequences of Brexit, which the British have chosen. This preparation — I would like to say this and thank him — is also led, at Commission level, by our Secretary-General, Martin Selmayr. Time is short. We have points of particular vigilance on this text, which you have reminded each other in your speeches and which you recall, Guy Verhofstadt, in this resolution. Obviously, our common priority is, first and foremost, the citizens. We will stay until the end attentive — that is, until the time of ratification of this withdrawal agreement — to the guarantees we obtained in the joint report in December and on the effective implementation of all rights under simple and non-costly procedures. Mrs Miranda, you mentioned earlier, like Gabriele Zimmer, Barbara Spinelli, Jill Evans and Josef Weidenholzer, this priority issue of the rights of British citizens who live and work — and who have chosen to live and work — in one of our 27 countries, and, of course, of the three and a half million Europeans, among whom many students, who live and work in the UK. We also expect the United Kingdom to see a sincere commitment and progress in the coming days on all other issues, such as the governance of the Euratom Agreement. I could multiply the examples of the subjects that we have not completely negotiated, on which we do not yet agree, which are part of all the subjects of separation and which are essential to an orderly withdrawal. This, of course, also concerns the transition. We accept — European leaders have accepted, you have accepted — the British government's request, submitted by Theresa May, to include a transitional period in the withdrawal agreement. Obviously, in this short transitional period, in compliance with Article 50, all Union rules will have to be applied without distinction. For example, a citizen arriving during this transitional period — Mercedes Bresso mentioned this — will have to enjoy the same rights as the one who arrived before Brexit Day. There is a second point, obviously, that of our future partnership, referred to in your resolution. You draw, in this text, the architecture and content — as the European Council will do in a few days, under the authority of Donald Tusk — of this that this ambitious partnership with the United Kingdom could be. Guy Verhofstadt talked about the future association with this great country around four pillars, and I find myself in this architecture you propose. First, our business relationship. Mr. Sulík was talking about exchanges earlier. We must, of course, supervise this trade and continue to trade with the United Kingdom, including in this trade relationship — as Mr Vandenkendelaere, Mr Millán Mon or Mrs Miranda mentioned — a balanced agreement on the issue of fisheries. Secondly, thematic cooperation. Mr López Aguilar was talking about aviation, Mr Peter van Dalen was talking about research or universities — I could quote Erasmus. We will establish, in a regulatory financial framework different from today's — since the United Kingdom has chosen not to be in the Union anymore — a framework for cooperation to maintain this work with the British in the common interest. Thirdly, cooperation on justice, home affairs, police or judicial cooperation and, finally, of course, with this great country, a strategic partnership for foreign policy, security and defence. With regard to the first pillar, that of economic cooperation, as we speak, all models of cooperation with third countries are still on the table. They are available. We are open for business. It is the UK that is closing doors. I listened carefully to Theresa May's speech at Mansion House, which confirms the doors that the UK itself closes objectively by confirming red lines. Leaving the internal market, leaving the customs union, Elmar Brok recalled this red line earlier. Esteban Gonzáez Pons too. Retrieving regulatory and commercial autonomy, this was told earlier by several of you. Never be bound by the Court of Justice again, these are the red lines which the United Kingdom confirms. We take note of this, but then we have to make it clear. One cannot want both the status of a third country and at the same time ask for the benefits belonging to the Union and only to the Union, as Philippe Lamberts pointed out. We cannot and will not be able to use the à la carte internal market — Mr Lenaers earlier or Mr Danti said so — when it is an integrated ecosystem and the four freedoms, including freedom of movement, are indivisible and indivisible. We cannot want to participate in our agencies without the legal commitment to adopt and apply EU law and the jurisdiction of the Court of Justice. Mutual recognition of rules and norms cannot and cannot be sought from the outside, whereas this can only be based on trust, i.e. a common law, coherent supervision and a single jurisdiction. Ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, it is quite a surprising idea to believe that the 27 Member States of the Union and your Parliament could, in a way, accept convergence when the United Kingdom wishes and at the same time allow it to diverge when it comes to creating an advantage Comparative. To coin a sentence, it's time to face up to the hard facts. Mr Ferreira, Mr Lange and Mrs Scott Cato mentioned the question of standards in the United Kingdom — it will be a third and sovereign country — and then at home too. This is a very important point and it is a question I asked a few weeks ago and for which we have not yet received an answer from the United Kingdom. The United Kingdom chooses to leave the Union, chooses to leave the single market and the customs union. We take note of this. Does he also want to leave or move away from our regulatory model, the same one that we patiently built together with you and you with us for 44 years? A regulatory model that is not just a question of standards, standards or laws, behind which there are actually societal choices that we have made together: the social market economy, social protection, security and certain food models, financial regulation. I could cite other examples of these common societal choices we made at 28 which are translated, consolidated by this regulatory model. And this question is very important. Does the United Kingdom also want to move away from that model we built with it and embark on the path of regulatory competition, even dumping, against us? This issue is not only important — I say this in passing — for the economy itself, for citizens and for consumers. It is also very important for the political conditions for the ratification of any future relations agreement between us and the United Kingdom, because on that day it will be for the European Parliament to vote, for the Council as well, but also unanimously for the 27 national parliaments and perhaps even for some regional parliaments. And I recommend on this issue of the divergence, or even the risk of dumping, that we pay very close attention to the conditions for such ratification. Finally — this is my last point — there is the question of Ireland at the intersection of who we are, the European Union, and what Brexit means and means. Ms. McGuinness raised this point very forcefully. Everyone knows that the Union has played its role, has held its place for dialogue and peace in Ireland, to bring together and give a common horizon the conditions for stability and dialogue between formerly divided communities. The Union is not responsible for the consequences of Brexit, but it is accountable for this cooperation, stability and common future. That is why, as many have wished, a strong and lasting agreement on Brexit — listen to me well — on orderly withdrawal must include a solid and lasting solution for Ireland and Northern Ireland. That is the meaning of the protocol we have proposed in this draft withdrawal agreement. This option, the third option we have operationalized, is part of the joint commitments between us and the United Kingdom at the highest level, that of Theresa May, President Juncker and Donald Tusk. And this document only implements one of the options of the December joint report. I have already told you, Mrs Dodds, when we were seen in my office a few days ago, and I also tell Mr Nicholson that I always listen carefully, it is part of the options we have decided to study in order to provide concrete solutions. It is our responsibility to clarify operationally how we will avoid a hard border on the island of Ireland in the absence of alternative solutions and taking into account the decision of the United Kingdom to leave the single market and leave the customs union. And I will not stop repeating that this backstop solution, one of the three, is ready to replace it with any other better solution proposed by the British Government. This is something that Mr. Carthy or Richard Corbett mentioned earlier. In conclusion, Mr President Tajani, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I simply want to confirm that the solidity and clarity of the Union's position, our unity on the subjects of withdrawal, as well as on the future, is what makes our strength in this negotiation. Obviously, this clarity and solidity would not be possible without the trust you place in our negotiating team and your negotiating team and we will continue to work as I said to the steering on Brexit, to Guy Verhofstadt, in a permanent attitude of dialogue and transparency with you. Mr President, I would like to thank you, Guy Verhofstadt and each member of the Brexit steering group, the chairmen of the groups and the chairmen of the committees, and your coordinators, for the quality and sincerity of our joint work, and I believe that the resolution you are going to adopt is essential for success of the steps we have before us.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. — (FR) Mr President, since we share the same view on Brexit, following Mr Barnier's speech in French, I will also make my concluding remarks in French. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress once again that the Presidency believes that the unity of the Union of 27 and our institutions is essential for the success of the negotiations. We look forward to receiving tomorrow Parliament's new resolution, which I am sure, like the previous ones, will make a useful contribution to the process. We would like to reiterate our support for the European Commission negotiating team and also to the chief negotiator, Mr Barnier. We pledge to continue our discussions with Parliament and the Brexit Steering Group during the negotiations in order to achieve the best possible agreement for the Union and the citizens.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I have received two motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 March 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. — I begin by giving credit to the outstanding efforts made in the Brexit negotiations by EU representative Michel Barnier, along with his team, and by providing him with further support and solidarity in particular to defend the rights of citizens, but also to respect the statutory commitments to contribute to the EU budget from the United Kingdom. Secondly, I would like to emphasise the post-Brexit importance of equally respecting both the rights of British citizens within the European Union and the rights of European citizens in the UK and the bilateral assurance that no citizen will be deprived of rights. The consequences of this political decision must not have irreversible effects on those we represent, and the rights of citizens after withdrawal must be clearly specified and fully respected by the authorities of both parties, particularly with regard to vulnerable persons. I believe in a strong EU-UK partnership even after the retreat, with the Union and the UK demonstrating that they can take much more sustainable, effective and effective action together than separately.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. — Presidents of Parliament, the Commission and the Council, Brexit is a sad discussion, because one of the major states has decided in a referendum and with a stubborn government to leave the European Union. The exit negotiation has been going on for two years and European citizens are concerned from two perspectives: respect for the rights of European citizens in the UK and trade agreements. Mr Michel Barnier, you are the EU negotiator and you have a major responsibility. Please give us a clear message: will citizens' rights be respected in the UK or not? Will trade agreements take into account the protection of the internal market by imposing standards of similar products in trade? When will citizens and businesses trading know about how the EU works with Britain, which will become a third party? The Council and the Commission have a responsibility to speed up the completion of Brexit without negative effects on citizens and companies in the European Union.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – Dear President, dear Colleagues, The UK is an important member of the EU and it is important that it would remain an important and close ally of the EU after Brexit. Therefore, I support the resolution of the European parliament were it states that close cooperation is foreseen between the EU and the UK in international security, foreign policy, research and development, education. Also, the negotiation process most importantly has to secure citizen’s rights and their free movement which has been of the core values of the EU. It has to remain this way. In regards to the EU Single Market, the EU should stand firm for the values it represents and the UK has to respect the values and rules which come. If it doesn’t want to ‘play’ by them, then the UK cannot enjoy the EU Single Market. A pick-and-mix approach for a non-member state should not be an option. Therefore, I support the common line by the EU, that free trade agreement will be offered as an alternative.

name: Ian HUDGHTON
text: in writing. – Scotland’s coastal communities must not be made to suffer as a consequence of Brexit. A London Tory government deemed our fishing communities expendable on our way in to the EU and it would be no surprise if the industry is deemed by the UK Government to be expendable again on the way out. This resolution calls for a new bilateral partnership agreement and it is vital that the UK agrees only to a deal which will benefit our fishing industry, fully adhering to international law. The agreement must allow Scottish fishermen to fully benefit from our resource-rich waters. And our fishermen’s interests must not be bartered away for the interests of the City of London or any other sector. The key word in this resolution is ‘agreement’ – and the UK government must only agree to a deal which fully protects our coastal communities. As part of that deal, fishing powers must be returned to the Scottish parliament so that we can benefit Scotland’s coastal communities, managing our rich fishing resources sustainably and entering future fisheries negotiations as a normal coastal state. I call upon the UK Government to give our fishing communities the priority they deserve in this negotiation.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The EP endorsed the fundamental pillars of further cooperation with the United Kingdom following its withdrawal from the Union. Partnership and cooperation in the field of trade and economic relations, foreign policy, security and development cooperation, internal security and thematic cooperation, in particular in areas of common interest, must be the main ideas of each contracted area. Future relations must be based on mutual respect, reciprocity and benefit, take account of existing commitments and take into account, as far as possible, the interests of citizens of all Contracting Parties.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. — We must be uncompromising about the rights of European citizens in the context of Brexit and the future EU-UK relationship; this resolution recognizes this. We have made progress in this regard, particularly by referring to future spouses in the Commission's draft agreement. However, the fight will not stop here. This resolution gives its consent to the conclusion by the EU of a Brexit agreement and a transitional period in October 2018; until that date, the protection of the rights of all European citizens will be our duty. As Members of the European Parliament, we represent the interests of the peoples of Europe, and therefore also those of the citizens of the United Kingdom until the formal withdrawal of the United Kingdom. First and foremost, the right of residence and movement of European citizens in the post-Brexit UK is to be ensured if access to the European market for the United Kingdom is concerned. It will also be necessary to maintain the right of UK citizens living in an EU country to move freely within EU countries. We will hold these interests at heart even by debating the fate of Ireland, today the main obstacle to an agreement serving the interests and ensuring the rights of as many as possible.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. — The United Kingdom Government has established its red lines: exit from the Single Market and the Customs Union. The EU, in turn, has red lines: the integrity of the Single Market and the Customs Union. With red lines on both sides, it is difficult to reach agreement on the future of relations between the EU and the UK, as we all want them, i.e. without trade barriers and the free movement of European and British citizens. Flexibility is needed on both sides for the progress of the negotiations. Unfortunately, between these red lines, the problem of the future relationship between Northern Ireland and Ireland has still remained without a solution.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - In Brexit, I believe that damage is still being remedied, since the current situation caused by the inscrupulousness of British nationalists, the irresponsibility of the former conservative government and the inertia of the current one can only come out at a loss for both parties. Our report also shows that the EP is still the most consistent and responsible player in limiting losses from the EU's point of view. That is why I support our negotiating directive that the future of EU-British relations should preferably be regulated in a modern association agreement, even if London's narrow-mindedness does not yet make it available. At the same time, the EP also has a major responsibility to ensure, with close supervision and complete unity, that the agreement has a balance of obligations and rights, to ensure the integrity of the single market, and to ensure the EU's legal and policy-making decisions because the non-Member State Great Britain cannot enjoy the same privileges to the detriment of the 27. As a socialist, it is particularly important to me that our efforts and EU standards aimed at social Europe and sustainability, and thus the competitiveness of the EU, cannot be undermined by the post-exit settlement. As a representative of the Member State strongly affected by working in Great Britain, I specifically ask for the further support of my fellow Members in the rigorous enforcement of the mutual rights of settlers and workers, both during the transition and post-Brexit periods, as the Member States differ from the Council because of its interest and even the opposition of some people, we expect this in vain.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. — The future Partnership Agreement with the UK must not overlook cooperation in research, education and culture and creative sectors, which are areas of mutual benefit. The resolution prepared by the European Parliament rightly underlines this position. As chair of the Brexit Monitoring Group on the Culture and Education Committee, I have proposed that, at this stage, the European Union retain maximum flexibility for future cooperation arrangements with the United Kingdom. We recognise that currently the non-EU and EEA countries covered by the programme enter into specific bilateral agreements with the EU for each programme. However, in the course of negotiations, it may be in the interest of the EU to set out conditions for participation in the programme, e.g. in the framework of an association agreement. I am pleased that the above proposals have been accepted. However, it should be remembered that once you exit the EU, the UK will become a third country and the same rules as other non-EU countries will apply.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before moving on to the next debate, I must unfortunately give you some bad news: our Swedish colleague Jens Nilsson, from the Socialist Group, died a short while ago. I'll remember it before the vote and we'll have a minute's silence. The next item is the debate on Council and Commission statements on the preparation of the European Council meeting on 22-23 March 2018 (2018/2502 (RSP)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, next week, leaders will meet in Brussels for a series of key debates. As usual for its spring meeting, the European Council will focus on jobs, growth and competitiveness. The overall picture is positive. The European economy is growing at a fast pace across Member States and unemployment is falling. Looking ahead, this robust performance is expected to continue in the coming years. The global environment, however, remains uncertain, and we need to continue to ensure the conditions to support confidence. One essential aspect, in order to foster jobs and growth and promote innovation, is to unlock the full potential of the Single Market. The European Council will address the different single market strategies, including when it comes to the Digital Single Market, the Capital Markets Union and the Energy Union, to ensure sustained progress. Delivering on these strategies in the current institutional cycle is a shared responsibility that will require co-legislators to continue to work closely on a number of legislative files and to speed up the process where necessary. Policy priorities under the European Semester also help create the right conditions for growth. We will have the opportunity to discuss this tomorrow night. The European Council will provide guidance on the priorities for 2018 and will be invited to endorse the recommendation on the economic policy of the euro area. The European Council will also return to social issues following the debate held in December. Last but not least, we know how vital trade is to our common prosperity in Europe and globally. That is why any attempts to undermine the rules-based multilateral trading system affect all of us. The European Union should play a leading role in opposing them. The European Council will discuss international trade relations following the US announcements. I know you will discuss this tomorrow and will review ongoing work in the field of trade policy and free trade agreement negotiations. Beyond the formal session of the European Council, leaders will also exchange views on taxation as part of the Leaders’ Agenda. They will hold an open debate, with a particular focus on the challenges associated with digital taxation. In keeping with the spirit of the Leaders’ Agenda, there will be no conclusions or formal outcome on this point next week. Finally, leaders of the euro area will meet in the margins of the European Council. They will hold an open debate on long-term issues that are specific to the euro area. So, altogether, the leaders next week will touch upon many aspects that underpin our economic and social future. The European Council will also deal with a number of other issues: it will address the preparations for the EU-Western Balkans summit in Sofia on 17 May 2018, since a specific priority of the Bulgarian Presidency is the European perspective and connectivity of the Western Balkans. As you know, this is a major event for the Presidency. The Council will also discuss relations with Turkey. As you just discussed, the European Council on Article 50 will meet on Friday to review the state of the negotiations with the United Kingdom and adopt additional guidelines on the future relationship with the UK.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, just under two weeks ago, I returned from a tour of the Western Balkans. It was a memorable trip for many reasons. What struck me the most was the passion and conviction in the European Union. This gave me a renewed sense of belief and hope that if a region, a dramatic region like the Western Balkans, is so determined to reform from top to bottom in order to join our Union, then we must be a Union worth being part of. The Western Balkans clearly see much more in us then we ourselves see in our Union. I want to see the same belief in our Union across all 27 Member States.  Of course, there is a great deal of work to be done. All bilateral disputes must be resolved and more unity is needed. Each of the Western Balkan partners must continue their reform path, especially when it comes to the rule of law and fundamental freedoms and values. As I said to all leaders in the region, there will be no fast-tracking. We will put substance over speed. Each case will be taken on its own merits, with no fixed dates or firm deadlines. But I came back from the trip more convinced than ever that it is our shared future. It is about reconciling our history and geography, but it is also another reason to focus on building a stronger, more democratic and united Union. This is what the March European Council is about.  I would like to thank this House and the Bulgarian Presidency for leading the way in recent weeks. The breakthrough on posted workers will ensure that fairness comes first in our labour market. As we collectively agreed: equal pay for equal work in the same place. The agreement on 5G shows that we are serious about our digital leadership and equipping ourselves with the tools we need to thrive in the society of tomorrow.  Mr President, Europe believe in open and fair trade based on a global rule book. Our economy depends on it and our consumers expect it. But as I have said all along: we are not naive free traders. So we will not sit idly by if our industry is hit with unfair trade measures that put European jobs at risk. We will defend our workers; we will defend our industry, and we will do so while respecting the rules that the world agreed to under the WTO.  The United States has regrettably decided to impose restrictions on steel and aluminium which will impact a significant amount of EU trade. We believe in win-win trade, but going it alone on tariffs is a lose-lose for all. Yes, the global steel industry has an overcapacity problem. This is why, since December, along with Japan and the US, we have been looking at how to address this issue globally. Commissioner Malmström met with both of her counterparts this weekend to deepen that cooperation further. And she also expressed our concerns to the United States on the tariffs being imposed on national security grounds. Exports from the European Union are clearly not a threat to the United States’ national security. We are long-standing and trusted security partners and we work together to keep each other safe and secure. As their own figures show, the US only needs 3% of its annual steel production to serve the Pentagon’s needs. We will keep making this point in the run-up to the European Council next week. We are expecting more clarity from the American side in the coming days, and we will continue to work with our partners to push for an exemption from these measures.  As always, we will – and we have to – prepare for all eventualities. Should the need arise, the European Union will respond in three ways. Firstly, under WTO rules we have the right to rebalance these measures, and we stand ready to do so. Secondly, we will be ready with safeguard measures if there is a surge in imports into the European Union as a result of the US closing its market. And thirdly, we will seek dispute settlement consultations in the WTO, in conjunction with other affected countries. Herr Präsident, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Wenn wir unserer Union mehr Stärke, mehr Handlungsfähigkeit verleihen wollen, müssen wir auch in die Architektur unserer Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion investieren und sie zukunftsfester machen. Die Umstände dafür sind so günstig wie selten zuvor. Die europäische Wirtschaft wächst über Erwarten, in den vergangenen zwei Jahren mit mehr als zwei Prozent. Und sie wächst schneller als die US-amerikanische Wirtschaft. Gleichzeitig haben wir in Europa mehr Menschen in Arbeit als jemals zuvor, 236,3 Millionen – ein neuer Rekord. Das sollte uns Bestätigung und Ansporn zugleich sein, unseren Reformkurs konsequent fortzusetzen. Und genau das tun wir. So legt die Kommission heute am frühen Nachmittag ein Paket zur Bankenunion vor. Es geht darum, die Finanzstabilität zu sichern, indem wir uns noch stärker mit notleidenden Krediten beschäftigen. Dort haben wir schon einige Erfolge erzielt. Seit 2014 ist der durchschnittliche Anteil notleidender Kredite in der EU schon um ein Drittel gesunken. Dabei wollen wir es nicht belassen. Das ist umso wichtiger, weil bei der Vollendung der Bankenunion Risikominderung und Risikoteilung Hand in Hand gehen. Eine vollendete Bankenunion wäre ein wichtiger Schritt, um unsere Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion zu stärken.  Genau darum geht es beim Gipfel. Über die Vorschläge, die die Kommission im Dezember vorgelegt hat, haben wir hier im Hause und bei einem früheren Eurogipfel schon diskutiert. Wir wollen den europäischen Stabilitätsmechanismus schrittweise zu einem europäischen Währungsfonds ausbauen. Außerdem wollen wir die Mitgliedsstaaten und solche, die es werden wollen, bei den Reformen unterstützen sowie mit einer Stabilisierungsfunktion sicherstellen, dass selbst im Falle von schweren Schocks Investitionen in Bildung und Infrastruktur weiterhin gewährleistet bleiben.  Monsieur le Président, Mesdames et Messieurs, chers collègues, compléter l’union économique et monétaire n’est pas une fin en soi, c’est un moyen de créer les conditions d’une vie meilleure, d’une vie plus prospère et plus équitable pour tous nos concitoyens.  Égalité des chances, conditions de travail équitables, protection et insertion sociales doivent devenir une réalité pour tous. C’est pour cela que nous nous sommes engagés à mettre en œuvre le socle européen des droits sociaux. 16 millions de nos concitoyens, par exemple, vivent et travaillent dans un autre État membre que le leur. C’est deux fois plus qu’il y a dix ans et ce phénomène ne fera que s’amplifier. Ces personnes ont, comme tout un chacun, des droits qui doivent être respectés et effectivement mis en œuvre dans un marché européen du travail. C’est la raison pour laquelle la Commission va présenter aujourd’hui sa proposition de création d’une Autorité européenne du travail qui ne viendra pas se substituer aux autorités nationales mais qui renforcera la coopération et la coordination entre elles. Ceux qui travaillent à temps partiel, ceux qui relèvent du statut des travailleurs intérimaires ont eux aussi droit à une protection sociale convenable. C’est une responsabilité commune, celle de mettre en œuvre le socle des droits sociaux. Il faut évidemment continuer à parfaire le marché intérieur, notamment les marchés de l’électricité qui, en Europe, s’ils étaient totalement interconnectés, les Européens feraient des économies de 40 milliards d’euros par année. Si l’Europe numérique fonctionnait, cela nous apporterait 415 milliards d’euros de croissance nouvelle chaque année. Donc rien que sur l’interconnectivité de l’électricité et de la mise en place totale de l’Europe numérique, nous réaliserions un bénéfice – si je peux m’exprimer de la sorte – de 450 milliards. Nous avons tous, je crois, conscience qu’il serait essentiel, souhaitable, bienvenu que nous puissions mettre en œuvre tous les éléments dont je viens de vous parler d’ici les élections européennes de l’année prochaine. (Applaudissements)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, I am pleased that you are sending the text on non-performing loans today after the College meeting because it is up to the Commission, Parliament and the Council to decide at legislative level. It is not the supervisory board of the European Central Bank that has to make laws but the European institutions, Commission, Parliament and Council.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Mr President, Madam President-in-Office of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to address three issues. Firstly, following our discussion on Brexit, I would just like to make it clear once again, including in the direction of the British Government: the European Union is not a supermarket to enter, select goods and buy goods as cheaply as possible. We have the European internal market and the European internal market is not a self-service shop. Mr Michel Barnier and the Commission have put forward good proposals for future cooperation. And when we adopt our resolution tomorrow, I believe that we have also delivered and shown that we have an idea of what good partnership will look like in the future. The second issue, which will also be raised at next week's Council summit, is the issue of the digital single market and, above all, the issue of taxation. I would like to emphasise that I am very pleased with the Commission's proposals on the taxation of the digital economy. It is also a very important issue for our citizens that tax legislation in this European Union is also fair. That will also be the subject of the TAXE 3 Committee, which we will also be voting on tomorrow. And here, too, with a view to Brexit, we need to look closely at what is happening in the British Virgin Islands. We cannot allow tax havens to be set up here alongside the European internal market. Last point: Economic and monetary union. Ladies and gentlemen, we will be discussing this intensively. As you know, I'm not a friend of a liability community. I believe that risk-taking and liability must go hand in hand, and that we therefore do not communitigate the need adhesion. There are different proposals from the Commission. I'm sure we'll discuss this up and down in the house.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, this European Council is taking place at a very special moment, where we have polls around the world coming up with a nationalistic tone in Russia, China and the United States. In this context, the European Union needs to assert its own vision and its own way of life and to have a long—term strategy, which should be based on human dignity, fairness, democracy and a clear commitment to sustainable development. Yes, climate change is there, and we need to have a growth strategy driven by sustainable development goals. Yes, the digital revolution can change our way of life, but we want to make the best of this by framing this revolution. That is why our commitment to the European Pillar of Social Rights is so crucial. We need to tackle not only the old inequalities, but also the new ones. We are now waiting for the final content of the Social Fairness Package to be adopted by the Commission because we need to make sure that all citizens can have access to full coverage via social protection. But can we say that all citizens now have real access to all these benefits? This is not the case. We still have many inequalities across the Union, and that is why we in the European Parliament really expect a forward—looking Community budget – the financial framework – to ensure that these promises will be delivered.  The same applies to the eurozone. We need to stop the trend for divergence. That is why we expect the Commission’s proposed budget line to build up fiscal capacity for the eurozone. But then we come to the big problem. How can we finance this? That is where the discussion on taxation, which will take place in this European Council, is so crucial. Let me give a very simple figure. When it comes to large corporations, something very weird is happening. In 2000, their profits were taxed at around 34%; now their profits are taxed at just 24%. So the situation we have is that large corporations are paying less and less tax, while our governments are under pressure to make cuts to welfare and healthcare systems. Something is wrong, and we should not be surprised that citizens are now feeling insecure and that nationalistic and xenophobic positions are gaining ground. We need to reverse this trend. The only way to reverse this trend is for the European Council to say, ‘if we want everybody to benefit from this strategy and for the social pillar to be implemented, we need to have the means’, and the means will be fair taxation. If the European Council really wants to change the situation in Europe, it needs to be bold on fair taxation.  (Applause)

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, thank you for coming today, because we missed you very much yesterday during the interesting debate on the appointment of your Head of Cabinet Selmayr as Secretary-General of the European Commission. Now I want to talk about the future of Europe which must be social. We need to work towards upward convergence and make the EU a place where it is good for everyone to live. We do this, among other things, by tackling fraud and social dumping. This is rightly a priority for the Juncker Commission, although I do ask myself critical questions about how the Commission intends to achieve this social objective. Commissioner Thyssen, for example, will present her proposal for a European Labour Authority this afternoon. According to Thyssen, this new European agency should be the missing piece of puzzle in the fight against social fraud. However, I would like to stress that we need to consider the added value of new bodies. Do we really need that authority? Does she really add anything that Member States themselves cannot? Why, for example, do we abolish the recently established platform against undeclared work in order to replace it with the authority? The creation of expensive European bodies should not be an end in itself. Nor should the aim of the authority be to replace the Member States. Even though this may not be the overt ambition today, I wonder how this European Labour Authority will continue to grow in its role. Her name and permanent character in any case indicate further plans for the future. I think that we should be very careful not to increase the powers of the Member States by little, in which the Union is going to undermine the competences of the Member States. If a smokescreen of good intentions is being erected today, but the real objective is to set up a European social inspection, then I regret this maneuver. I repeat that the future of Europe must be social, but I would add that Europe has no future without respect for and from its Member States.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I want to urge the Council to add two specific items to the normal agenda (the Western Balkans, which President Juncker has spoken about).  The first is that we need from the Council a common reaction from the EU, together with our friends in the UK, on the new aggression by the Kremlin on what is still European soil – in Britain – and I am referring to the poisoning case of Sergei Skripal and his daughter. Mrs May has said that it is an attack against Britain as a country, and I think that a common reaction in the next European Council is absolutely needed and counter—measures need to be decided by the EU.  My second point, naturally, is that, regarding the type of solidarity that we need still to have with the UK, that we hope also for it to be returned. Solidarity from the UK, for example, in our policies towards Mr Trump: it should absolutely be avoided that, behind the EU’s back, they send somebody to the US to find a special deal on these trade measures. If Mr Trump finds that there are horrific tariffs from our side, there are also horrific tariffs from their side. He is talking about the 10% on the import of US cars in Europe, and we paid only 2.5%. But there are other examples: tariffs on a train carriage, for example, are 14% in the US, or for pickups – and there are a lot of pickups in the US – we have to pay 25% in tariffs. I think what the European Council should do now is say that there are two options in this starting of a trade war. Either we start a trade war and a war on tariffs by increasing them from both sides, or we do what should be the thing to do: to lower the tariffs in both cases, the tariffs on the European side and the tariffs on the US side, which both sides find so horrific. I hope that that can be the common position. We have no interest in starting a trade war. What we have to offer instead is a trade deal from the European side. In fact, there are many people who were against TTIP but now see that if we had got TTIP we could have avoided what is happening today. I hope that this measure will be taken – no trade war, but a new trade deal.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, President of the Commission, Mr President-in-Office of the Council. Before the summit participants will arrive at all, the first and most important disappointment of this summit is to be seen. This is evident that the promise made by President Macron and Chancellor Merkel in December that they wanted to present joint proposals for discussion with colleagues from the other Member States on the development of the European Union in March, that is to say at this summit. outside, be it from Russia, be it from China or from the US, is urgently needed not to be redeemed. This disappointment is not outweighed by the fact that the Summit will deal with indeed very important issues — from jobs and competitiveness to the Western Balkans, from trade policy to the social pillar, from tax policy to foreign policy. Ladies and gentlemen, dear Representative of the Council, I believe that the greatest urgency is for us to understand this fundamental orientation of the Union. There is a fundamental difference behind the postponement of the proposals from Berlin and Paris. Do we want a core Europe like Macron envoyors? Or do we want an inclusive Europe? Do we want a division into a luxury EU and a timber class EU, or do we want a common European future? This needs to be clarified! We need a vision of Europe that is inclusive, which values diversity, protects citizens, strengthens self-determination, makes the economy fairer and realises the environmental and social transformation that we owe to our children and the whole world.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, Mr Juncker, representatives of the Council, at the forthcoming summit the leaders of the Union will decide on the biggest problems affecting Europe: economic crisis, refugee, brexit, energy union and external relations. However, as long as the Council continues the same anti-grassroots policies, deepening and institutionalising the neoliberal model, the crisis will intensified. In order to provide solutions that genuinely serve the needs of the peoples, measures must be promoted to boost the real economy, policies that strengthen social and regional cohesion and address the disparities that are constantly increasing. As far as energy union is concerned, the proposals put forward, instead of solving the problems in energy supply, create new deadlocks, as they invalidate Member States' sovereign rights in shaping their energy policy. One example is the new directive on the internal market in natural gas, which seeks to manipulate states by transferring greater powers to the European Commission, and as a result there will be additional problems in creating new import and export infrastructures. natural gas. Then, with regard to Euro-Turkish relations, unfortunately Turkey, with its illegal actions in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean Sea, continues to violate international law, the law of the sea, as well as the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus and Greece. At the same time, it invades Afrin, bloodshed the Syrian Kurds, while continuing to violate the civil liberties and human rights of its own citizens. The Union must intervene so that Turkey can put an end to its illegal actions. We expect concrete solidarity and more drastic measures. We call for pressure to be exerted on Turkey to respect human rights, to end the invasion of Syria, to respect the sovereign rights of the Republic of Cyprus and to support the resumption of a meaningful dialogue on a solution to the Cyprus problem. Unfortunately, however, the Union continues to caress Turkey, with the launch of the approval of the new EUR 3 billion financial aid for refugees, as well as discussions on strengthening the customs union and visa liberalisation for the Turks citizens.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Juncker, members of the Council, the proposals for the next European Council are as always many and amazing, but our fear is that again they are just big announcements that are unlikely to result in anything concrete for our citizens. Let's start with the priorities of the European semester. For us, the economic policies of the euro area cannot in any way continue according to the wrong recipe of this Commission, based solely on austerity and rigour, which we oppose without if and without buts, because only through investment in high-return sectors and expansive policies will it be possible to create real sustainable employment in the medium to long term. To ensure growth and competitiveness it takes a concrete commitment by the Council to allow respect for the principle of reciprocity, both in markets and in public procurement, by monitoring investment foreign and putting in place binding rules of sustainable development, maneuvers that should fall within all trade agreements and which are often sacrificed. That is why we want to know what the Council is doing on this matter, and how it is ensuring that our partners are meeting our standards, thus avoiding a trade war that It would risk damaging our businesses and “made in”, which we expect to be a priority for Europe, the Commission and the Council. Even on the digital market too often this Commission has lacked courage. At the beginning of the legislature, the completion of the digital single market was announced through 16 initiatives: many of these, however, remained in half, such as geo-blocking, where from the scope are audiovisual were excluded, the area where geographical blocks based on nationality are most evident. Priority goal is to get out of the recessionary spiral where we have swooped, and in this context, the priority that assumes the implementation of the principles and rights set out within the framework of the European Pillar of Social Rights becomes clear. And a key element of the social pillar is the implementation in the Member States of policies of minimum income of citizenship, as required by this Parliament itself which has approved in this regard, a very large majority, the resolution of the 5 Star Movement. The vote in Italy is the reproof that citizens ask to return to being protagonists, protected and defended by institutions, and the 5 Star Movement today represents the possibility for Italy to return to to be a strong, authoritative and credible voice within the European institutions.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Once again, the Council is debating the issues of migration and asylum, and once again nothing but hot air is being produced. This discussion has been ongoing since 2014/2015, and since 2014/2015 it has been the case that millions of people have been pushing to our continent. Yes, there are also vulnerable people where I believe it would be better to provide this protection in the region. But in addition to these, there are also criminals, in addition to these, terrorists are also involved. And we have the situation — whether it was now in Brussels, whether it was in Paris, whether it was in Munich — that Austria has now also been the victim of a terrorist action, where a person from Egypt attacked a guard soldier, tried to stab him with a knife just because Iran's involvement in Syria — and all this on Austrian soil. I say that it is high time to protect the external borders. We have been discussing this for a long time, it is not done. And as long as the external borders are not effectively protected, I call for the Member States to be given the right to protect their borders. Austria is now negotiating at European level, and I would only ask you to give your support to this solution.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear colleagues, I would have liked to address Mr Juncker, but, as usual, he could not make it until the end of the debate, and he had to leave. We wish him well in every aspect. I will therefore also address Mr Timmermans and President Tajani. At the end of the previous three-hour debate on Brexit, Mr Juncker said that we should now look not into the past, but into the future. For the future, in connection with next week's European Council, let me ask you: Has the European Union drawn from Brexit the conclusion that it is not possible to force Member States to the extreme to adopt values and measures that are taken from the respective peoples, nations Absolutely aliens? Can we Hungarians hope that, by drawing this conclusion — and I look forward to Mr Timmermans's response — they will finally stop forcing Hungary to accept mass migration by continuing threats? We don't want to and we won't. I look forward to your answer.

name: Pilar del CASTILLO VERA
text: Madam President, thank you very much to the Council and also to the Vice-President of the Commission. If we look back at the origins of the European Union, the single market provided a vision for the future of the need to act together, if we wanted European economies to have an area to optimize their development and be able to compete in the world. This, which was in principle simply an idea, developed slowly and, now, in the 21st century, has become the only possibility for different European countries to make their economies competitive and for their citizens to achieve ever greater well-being. And, in that context, the digital single market is crucial. If we turn to four years ago, I think it was an extraordinary success, both on the part of the Commission and Parliament, to focus one of the points of action and decision on the development of digital transformation, and to promote everything that allowed it. Today we can say that we have delivered in that sense has been fulfilled. And in that regard, I believe that we are going to stand for elections shortly with a set of decisions taken which are decisive for the European economy to achieve precisely those levels of global competitiveness. I would like to stress the importance of the interim agreement reached on radio spectrum, which is a pioneering one and which will enable 5G to be able to develop in Europe by the end of 2020, offering extraordinary possibilities for the development of digital transformation in Europe.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! The forthcoming Council finally promises an agenda that is not just a response. It will address questions that citizens have long been waiting to answer: jobs, growth and competitiveness of the European economy. There are quite a lot to show. The internal market is at the heart of our Union. Continuing it, especially in the digital sector, is an important investment in the future. We have already come very far here. We should not allow this to be jeopardised by national unitary approaches right now. Unfortunately, such tendencies are also noticeable in economic policy. In the Eurozone in particular, however, more European impetus is needed, especially at a time when it turns out that crisis interventions were successful, despite all dulks. Some things could have been more successful if austerity dogma had not been restricted. Above all, we will hear from the Portuguese Prime Minister how it could have been. For us Socialists and Democrats, the black zero is not a dogma; we are concerned with the responsible use of budget funds. This also means, above all, the courage to make public investment, especially when it comes to preventing society from drifting apart. We therefore welcome the fact that the Council has been dealing with social rights for a long time. Only by consolidating the social pillar will we consolidate our future. Allow me to say that I believe that it would be important for the Council to take a position on the horrific developments in Afrin.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen. First of all it's time to stop dividing us Attacks on Poland or Hungary do not harm the governments of our countries, because public opinion is rather consolidating against the authorities but harming above all the Europe they destabilise. Europe wants change today, as evidenced by the recent elections in Austria or Italy, and it's time for the European Union authorities to hear that voice — the sooner the better. At the prospect of the upcoming European Council summit, one should expect: a strong awareness that immigration policy, and already particularly asylum, must respect the sovereign powers of individual countries. The sooner we understand what the nations of Europe want, the better our cooperation will be.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I apologise for my naivety, but I must say I really expected this to be a political debate. I am sorry, Ms Panayotova, but with all due respect and sympathy to you, we have received a list of what is to be on the agenda. I would expect at least an attempt from the side of the President of the Commission to say: these are the priorities, this is how we analyse the situation, the bottlenecks, this is what the ambition is, this is what the President of the European Council and the Presidency expects. Of course, I know that you cannot go into detail, but not to give us any hint on any of the political issues is, I think, really a failure. No wonder, in fact, that the European Council is at a standstill. We are not delivering. We have got issues such as the reform of the EU, greater efficiency, real issues of security, trade, other political sensitivities that we need to address. We are not delivering. This is something that we would like to address concretely in this House with the Council. I do apologise, but this system, is in my opinion, unacceptable for the future. Guy Verhofstadt referred to the Russian attack in the UK: I think it is an attack, and I would expect that the Council would hint that this is to be on the agenda and will be debated, with concrete measures against the Russians and concrete concessions vis-à-vis the citizens, the entrepreneurs, the scientists, etc. This is the kind of issue we want to debate and the way we want to debate it.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: — The European Union is ruining the cancer of bureaucratic short-sightedness. In practice, the agendas of all institutions, without distinction of the European Council, are overloaded with complex issues and the most pressing issues that merely mimic the solution of problems. The European Union is today incapable of embracing and managing the general economic and social processes which will have decisive significance for the fate of the Community. The economic and social differences between countries are so great that even euro area countries, such as Lithuania, are threatened to lose all their human resources capital in the long run. It is rather like a fictitious economic union that does not actually function, where there are no common policy criteria and rules, and the principle of free movement of labour has become a scourge or even a mass displacement of peoples. I would think that the responsible European institutions should be much more sensitive to reflecting such negative processes in the Member States, which not only do not allow people to talk about well-being, but also testify to increasing social exclusion, poverty and discrimination. I believe that it would be time to end this protracted political play and return to the common policy agenda, to the search for the fundamental objectives of the European Union and the path to the implementation of its priorities.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: — Madam President, Jean-Claude Juncker has just travised to six Balkan states, where he has been able to join the European Union as early as 2025. The European Council must debate this. Serbia's accession is a good idea, because it is a country that is a traditional ally of France. Franco-Serbian friendship is beautifully symbolized by the monument of recognition to France, which Serbia erected in Belgrade. Kosovo's accession would, on the other hand, be a nightmare, because it is a nest of jihadists. A jihadist general, Lavdrim Muhaxheri, for example, has just returned from Syria with 400 fighters to set up a branch of the Islamic caliphate. Albania's accession would be just as catastrophic, as it is such a corrupt State that it is smugting its inhabitants away. The only ambition of this faltering country is to transform itself into an open dump of all household waste in the European Union. It is a Europe of cooperation among sovereign peoples that I want, not this Europe of jihad and the exploitation of poverty.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President! A further debate on migration and the revision of the Dublin system will also be expected in the March European Council, on the basis of the report and initial proposal from the Bulgarian Presidency. However, this proposal will continue to be based on compulsory distribution of migrants, which will only lead to further sharing between Member States and therefore certainly not be part of the real solution. It is not possible to take away the right of Member States to decide who to let in and who is not living in their territory. EU decision-makers should have realised a long time ago that no system based on compulsory migrant distribution will be able to solve Europe's immigration problem. This will be considered an invitation for hundreds of thousands of migrants waiting to leave. Instead, Europe must regain full control over its external borders, which is a basic condition for stopping illegal migration. The protection of external borders and the billions spent on it should therefore be seen as a manifestation of solidarity, since it contributes to the protection of our European heritage and the preservation of the stability of the continent.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: — The European Commission has presented a clear commitment to the future of enlargement of Western Balkan countries. The countries of the Western Balkans have significantly reformed institutions and laws in the 20 years, contrary to what my predecessor has spoken about Kosovo and Albania. We promised them membership if they persist on this path. The Union has worked most with political elites for this objective. Now is the time to actively engage citizens as well. If we want the investments of the 20s to be sustainable, citizens must also be on our side. Our commitment in effort and money must be double. Membership is not just a political goal; it must become a democratic achievement for all the societies of the Western Balkans. I call for European leaders to make a clear commitment to enlargement at the summit, including May's Sofia summit, and to place the enlargement at the June meeting. We have to work with Western Balkan leaders openly and sincerely. Until the conditions are met, progress is not possible. The biggest part of the responsibility lies in the hands of leaders in the Balkans. For example, Turkey has failed the test of the rule of law and respect for human rights. More than 130,000 people detained since the summer of 2016 are proving that this is not a safe not democratic state. Therefore, for all those EU countries that unfortunately believe the opposite and are closing the door to political asylum seekers: counterpart, the Union needs the Western Balkans — and on the contrary - to help overcome common challenges, stability and peace for young people who instead of fleeing need hope, security and European the future.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, our position on this issue is very clear, because for us the idea of reviving the European project with further enlargement is the most wrong. It does not make sense for us to put together countries such as Finland and Montenegro, it does not make sense to put the countries of the East in competition with the Balkan countries, having already put in competition those of the South with those in the East. I would like to point out the serious consequences, for example, of the Embraco issue, of the question of the transfer of a company from my country to Slovakia. We think that rather we should work and contribute to the development and stability of the region, without trying to make thoughtless steps forward to put everyone under the banner of the Union and find out after how hasty and ill-prepared a Union has been, which, moreover, is functioning rather badly today. The strategy outlined by the European Commission actually makes water on all sides, and it reproposes, exacerbated, the problems that the enlargement process in the East already posed before. No precise deadlines have been set for anyone, and beyond the chatter only Serbia and Montenegro, actually, have begun formal talks to join the European Union and seem capable — and I conclude — to be able to reach the target by 2025.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: — Madam President, Bulgarian Presidency, Mr Vice-President, I would like to say that there is some frustration on the agenda of this Council, because what we expected, coming to March, is that, of course, President Macron and Chancellor Merkel would be able to present at least a first roadmap for the reform of the euro area. If that is not possible, then at least the principles and basic guidelines for preparing this work for the June Summit or European Council. In the meantime, I think there are two points that are very important. One is the answer to Trump and its limitation to international trade, which is totally unacceptable and which is completely contrary to what is the European Union's line. I have to say that today we would be in a safer and more prosperous world if TTP with the United States and TTIP with Europe and the United States were already properly in place or at least far ahead — that could combat unfair, social and environmental competition from some markets, such as the Chinese market, and not exactly another kind of retaliation, like this one. Finally, I would like to say that I note with some pity that the poor relative of this Council is the Energy Union — only President Juncker spoke about it. For Portugal and Spain it is decisive, for the European Union it is crucial to make interconnections between France and the Iberian Peninsula. On the day they are made, our dependence on Putin and our dependence on Russia will diminish greatly and Europe will gain much from it.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: — Madam President, Mr Vice-President, at this European Council, under the authority of the Presidency, you will discuss the question of capital markets union. It is absolutely essential that the Union move forward in this area, even at a time when, unfortunately, we have to look at Brexit. But this will only be reasonable if, at the same time, we progress in the conditions of supervision of the markets. I therefore really urge the Council to go to this issue, without this in any way depleting the question of progress in economic and monetary union. And here, frankly, we sometimes have, beyond realism, the impression of waiting for Godot. We were waiting for the German elections, we were waiting for the German government, now we are waiting for the Franco-German agreement. This is not reasonable, even because, in the trade war now between us in the United States, the best weapon of the euro area is to make progress in its integration in tax matters and investment strategy. I hope that is the message you will bring to this Council.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I am pleased to see that economic subjects form a big part of the Council meeting agenda. After all, economic performance plays a very important role in the way that people perceive the functionality of the European Union. I am especially pleased to see that tax issues are an informal part of the Council meeting. I hope that not just digital taxation but also VAT reform and CCCTB will be discussed and we will get closer to their adoption. I call on the leaders of the Member States to proceed and, if necessary, go to enhanced cooperation in the case of CCCTB.  Secondly, I want to mention the energy union. After a very good Commission proposal, short—term national interests, as well as the interests of some groups, could now weaken the result and this would be unfortunate. It would be a lost opportunity for Europe and for our citizens. Last but not least, I also want to mention the issue of trade, but instead of going into details, I will just declare my support for what President Juncker said about this subject. I hope that we will achieve our goal, which is to support deferred and open trade globally.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Just a few sentences in preparation for the Balkan Summit, since this point also plays a role: yes, we promised to bring the countries of the Western Balkans to the EU, and we promised to help them restructure and reform their countries. We are increasingly demanding that these countries do their schoolwork before entering the EU. But now it's our turn in the EU to do our homework. That is why I would ask the Bulgarian Presidency to promote the Council to adopt and develop the Commission's Western Balkans strategy in a positive way. Talk to our Greek friends about how we can help them with the several problems that exist with the Balkan countries and please make sure that none of the six partners are sitting at the cat table just because some are not yet as far as the majority of European countries.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Madam President, I wonder if the next summit on March 22nd and 23rd will be able to absolvent the number of topics on the agenda. Anyway, I'm glad that there are economic topics here, and there are topics related to foreign policy and foreign action. I'm glad that jobs, growth, competitiveness and, of course, the common market are mentioned. Last week our EPP group stayed in Valencia where we talked about the digital wave, in which the European Union must lead. I consider this an extremely important topic for the upcoming Council meeting and I am pleased that digital Europe will be discussed. I personally believe that innovation can change the lives of our citizens, and our task is to make innovation a top priority of the next period. We see the European economy stronger, we see growth rising above expectations, that unemployment has decreased, investment is recovering, that the state of public finances is improving.
