But we need to take care of our relations with the United States of America. They should not be based on confrontation, as Mr. Juncker said. It is important to reach a compromise. I am also pleased to mention that President Juncker has visited the countries of the Western Balkans or Southeast Europe, as we like to say, I am glad that he noticed that they believe in the European future, but as Mr. Fleckenstein said, it is up to us to do our homework, to help them on that path. We need to provide full support to these countries and allow them to meet the conditions for entry into the European Union as soon as possible.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, last November, the Heads of Government met in Gothenburg and they signed together for the European social pillar. That pillar is gradually beginning to take shape, but the pace has to go up. The Commission's proposal for a European Labour Inspectorate is being presented today, but the previously announced social security number has already been dropped. The European Labour Inspectorate is a step in the right direction, a step towards a decent and fair European labour market, by tackling exploitation and unfair competition between workers and unfair competition between companies at European level. The proposal also gives Europe teeth to bite when it comes to cross-border abuses. But, Mr President, if the Heads of Government really want a social Europe, they must now go ahead. We want to see actions and not just words.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the next Council has much to discuss, and discuss they will, but one area I think they need to focus very strongly on is the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the next budget: Europe without a good budget can be talking forever about what they would like to do, but they cannot do much about it. Especially now that the United Kingdom will be leaving the European Union, regretfully, there will be a EUR 14 billion or so deficit in the budget. I think it is incumbent on the Member States to make up that deficit. After all, if they are all talking about the need to stick together to preserve what we have built, then I think also a strong budget is the key to that. I was delighted to hear our own Taoiseach, Leo Varadkar, say here in this very Chamber in January that Ireland will commit itself to increasing our percentage contribution from 1% to 1.1% or 1.2%. But every other Member State needs to do the same, because if we are to do the things we want to do in relation to security, Erasmus, development aid, the single market, migration or climate change, it is going to take funding. It is estimated that every euro in Europe generates about EUR 4 in added value. This is where the added value is, but the Council must give the commitment to do that now, unanimously, and then we can progress.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 25 years after its inception, a strategic reflection must be made on the meaning and future of the single market. In many areas its completion is far from being accomplished and is perceived in public opinions with detachment, as a bureaucratic superstructure that limits the freedom of enterprise and not protects consumers sufficiently. Digital, the new frontier of the single market, is then considered a ruleless dimension and hostile to sectors of the traditional economy. That is why it is time for renewed political momentum and ambitious choices. We need a harmonised tax system that helps domestic virtuous competition, a European tax for web giants, market surveillance of effective products, and new protection instruments of consumers. We hope that the next Council will take these demands on its own and relaunch the single market as Europe's economic and social engine. The world today runs fast: to do this we do not have the 25 years behind us, but the 25 months ahead of us.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, the Estonian Presidency managed to focus the attention of the Council on the digital dimension. It was good, but not enough. Now it is crucial to move ahead, including with the files on the digital market. EU Governments need to decisively deepen the single market, especially their services market, and put an end to deep-seated national protectionism, otherwise optimistic talk about deep integration will remain just talk. By the way, I hope that President Trump’s hurried decisions could be used as a positive incentive to finally overcome the EU’s traditional cautiousness about our own free trade. Regarding the energy market, yesterday the British Prime Minister declared that there could be no business as usual with Russia after their apparent use of chemical weapons on UK territory. How can one think today that there can still be business as usual on Nord Stream 2? The Council cannot continue to avoid this challenge. It is not about differences between the Council and Commission legal services; it is about protecting EU common interests, exercising our energy solidarity in practice and preventing Mr Putin from undermining EU security and unity on such vital issues.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would not like to be pessimistic, but certainly a reading of what things are, of the reports which have been presented today, leads us to say that the European Council of the European Council of next 22-23 March looms as yet another meeting of postponed decisions, yet another meeting of missed opportunities. I think that the European Union can not miss the opportunities that arise further, really worth its deep difficulty. The elections in Italy were also a clear signal from this point of view: the European Union must start giving concrete answers to citizens, it must be an institution perceived as a friend, as a neighbour, and not as an institution far away and indifferent to the most serious challenges that European citizens are experiencing. I think of my country, I think of the issue of immigration, I think of the issue of an economic policy that has not been able to encourage development, to give answers to work in a sufficient way. And so today the reform of the eurozone, the social pillar of the EU and the many, too many shortcomings of the European Union, starting with the lack of a subsidy on European unemployment, which had also been placed in the programme, they can no longer wait for slow rhythms and contradictions of national policies, and so the issues of fiscal fairness, and I remind the intervention of Maria João Rodrigues.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: — Madam President, despite the strong decision of the European Council against Turkey on its unacceptable, provocative and illegal violations, both in Cyprus and in the Aegean, Turkey once again does what it always does: it despises, insults and provokes its decisions European Union. The Cyprus case, the case of the invasion of the Cyprus EEZ, the violations in the Aegean Sea, the insulting of countries of the European Union by a country that behaves pirate and terrorist, such as Turkey, I believe that it is not a matter of Cyprus and Greece, but it is a matter of European, because one fundamental rule of the European Union is the solidarity of the Member States of the European Union and I think it is very important for the European Union to respond to this provocative attitude and behaviour of Turkey. The European Union is being tested on this issue and we expect the European Council, which will meet on 22 and 23 March, to finally send out the strong message that it will no longer tolerate being despised and insulted by Turkey and that it will take steps so that if it continues violations in the Cyprus EEZ and does not stop them immediately, then Turkey cannot expect and expect anything from the European Union. At the same time, I would like to appeal, but also to demand from the esteemed Vice-President of the European Commission, Mr Timmermans, that the European Commission finally harmonizes with the European Council and the European Parliament and stop taking decisions on upgrading relations between Turkey and the European Union. We must send out the message that these attitudes can no longer be tolerated, because unfortunately Turkey is decontaminating and, in conclusion, I will call on you to take action, because tomorrow it will be too late with this Turkey, Erdogan's Turkey.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, Mr Juncker, said earlier that at the next Council you will discuss a stronger and more democratic Union. Begin to show more strength against the tax evasion and avoidance of multinationals, which cost us a thousand billion a year: three “Juncker plans” of investment were paid, with that figure. And if you only have political will, tomorrow you could approve fundamental law enforcement measures, such as state-by-state public reporting or CCCTB, to establish a simple principle: that taxes take place they pay where you make the profits. And much more courage we want on Dublin reform: the drafts circulating in the Council are an insult to our role and they mortify this House. Solidarity only voluntary, which nothing has ever solved, mandatory ineligibility procedures that violate international law and exacerbate the burdens of border countries, less guarantees for minors and sanctions that violate fundamental rights and monetize them: is a life really worth 30 000 euros to you? Parliament calls on you to have an ambitious position, which exceeds the hypocritical criterion of the first access country and replace it with a permanent accountability sharing mechanism. A stronger Union, yes, but with the strong, not with the weak.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: — Madam President, next week's Council meeting is a good opportunity to make an overview of the state of affairs in the European Union, to see where some of the most important initiatives and legislative proposals have come. I support the focus on jobs, growth and competitiveness, on monitoring the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights and the Commission's proposal on a European Labour Supervisory Authority. Washington's announcements of imposing additional tariffs on an increasingly long list of products seek a response from European leaders. The European Union needs to have a strategy for how to deal with these threats. As an MEP from Croatia, I support the envisaged adoption of conclusions on the Western Balkans ahead of the May summit in Sofia. I hope that certain reserves towards expansion will be overcome in the conclusions. The countries of the Western Balkans deserve a credible perspective of membership. The upgrading of the European project in the 21st century is of utmost importance for the future of the Union, and enlargement is one of the pillars of European identity and one of the most successful policies of the European Union since its creation.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Madam President, I believe that the challenges facing the European Union really are a whole range. There are countless, it's Brexit, it's asylum and migration issues, a multi-year financial framework and the role of cohesion policy. The pressure on the budget is immense and in this spirit the European Council needs to be called on to be truly united. That point of unanimity, I think it has a key role to play. On the other hand, those who call for unanimity need to have an honest dialogue. I think this is important to emphasise to the heads of government, and it's important for the presidency as well. I would also like to raise the question of Cyprus, because I have been on this island in the past period and I have been quite shocked at how divided this city is, how divided this island is. It is a bit of a shame in the 21st century for Europe that Cyprus remains such a divided island, and I think that really the European Presidency and also the European Council should focus on that

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, the Council meeting is very important. Many colleagues have said here, I think we need to define what the European Union wants to be. Mr Juncker said: improving the internal market, interconnectivity. Very good, but we still have first-class countries, second-tier countries, third-class citizens, we have double standard products. Are we clarifying what the future of the European Union is? We have a Brexit to negotiate. Very important are the themes at the summit. The problem is that we cut a suit without knowing its size. We need to know what we want in the future, and, Mr. Timmermans, with all due respect, please don't have a double language anymore. Go to our states and say something to the citizens, come here and talk something else. This is the case of Romania, in which you went to say something, last night at LIBE, again nominating Romania as a country that does not respect the rule of law. Say what we do not respect, because otherwise the citizens are dissatisfied and we will certainly develop Euroscepticism.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, the European Council, in its discussion and conclusions on the so-called Western Balkans, has the opportunity to establish the true situation on the ground, set realistic goals and send a clear message that none of the non-integrated countries will become a member until it meets all the criteria. We are witnessing that the European Union, this supposed oasis of human and civil rights worldwide, ignores the fact that it is at the head of a candidate state — Serbia, an authoritarian ruler who threatens democratic standards and the rule of law, impedes free elections and tramples on media freedoms. The toleration of Aleksandar Vucic is only a confirmation of the long-recognized European hypocrisy, which causes the Union to lose its reputation in the world. Let's not forget, the accession process is completely meaningless if the candidate states fail to make significant progress through it. Not just declarative, but essential. The way Vucic rules Serbia is a clear sign that we should not expect such progress from that state while he is at its helm.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, the erratic situation in the Western Balkans is reminiscent of the conditions prevailing before the First World War and the Balkan Wars. The pervasive irredentism and the blatant hate speech, especially by Albania and the government of Skopje against Greece, create an explosive mix, with the tolerance of Merkel mainly and for reasons we Greeks know well. In addition to the above, Erdogan's Turkey literally slaughtered Kurdish civilians in Afrin, having illegally invaded Syrian territory. The Union's policy of urges, calls for a ceasefire, verbal condemns and calls for dialogue has no effect. On the contrary, the Union maintains the climate through statements from official lips, continues the pre-accession negotiations of these countries and finances them, rather than isolating them and imposing sanctions on them. But history, at least for us Greeks, is not altered. Borders are not counterfeit, national consciences cannot be bought and national Member States do not forfeit their sovereignty rights.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, in reaction to what was said I have a few remarks.  First of all, I want to say something about the poisoning of people in Salisbury. Just try to get your mind around this: in Salisbury, people have been poisoned by a Novichok nerve agent, which is a substance that is banned under a UN convention. A nerve gas was actively used against civilians in one of our Member States. I believe that the European Council should, in clear terms, express its full solidarity with the British people and the British Government in addressing this issue. I believe it is of the utmost importance that those who are responsible for what has happened see very clearly that there is unequivocal, unwavering and very strong European solidarity, so that those responsible are really punished for what they did. We cannot have nerve gas being used in our societies. This should be addressed by all of us and not just left to Prime Minister May and the British Government. It is a collective European responsibility, including under the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW) rules. I want to thank your Parliament, Madam President, for its clear support for my words right now because it will also send a clear message to all those involved and to the European Council next week.  Yesterday, I was at Dillinger Hütte, in Saarland, to meet with representatives of the European steel industry from Saarland, from Lorraine and from Luxembourg – a very competitive steel industry, able to innovate, able to create green steel in the future, to make sure that steel remains an essential element of the European economy, in a way that is sustainable. Of course, people there were extremely worried about the measures announced by President Trump. I had a very clear message for the people there and I want to repeat it today: the Commission is working day and night to convince our American partners that there are no grounds for these measures. We are security partners. How on earth could European steel be a threat to American security? It is simply impossible, so there are no grounds for these measures. We hope we can convince our American partners of this, but if that fails, if we cannot convince them and they persist in this, the Commission will act with the support of the Member States to protect our European economy.  We do not believe in protection. No war could be predicted in terms of its outcome except for a trade war because we know that a trade war only has losers. Nobody can win a trade war. We hope that we can convince President Trump of that reality, but we will protect our interests if need be and we will help the European steel industry and the European economy to be competitive. Let me end on this. This is something that will be discussed at the European Council: jobs, competitiveness, growth. The world is changing at breakneck speed. We will need to be more competitive to keep up, but there are different ways of doing this. You can be competitive by lowering your prices, but then you will demolish the social fabric which is the very backbone of Europe. You can also be competitive by being smarter, more innovative, investing, inventing new things. This is what Europe has always been great at – all European nations – and that is why I believe that if we talk about the future of Europe, we talk about better taxation, so that people pay taxes where they make profits and that they do not get away with playing one Member State against another.  (Applause) We have to make sure that we develop the skills necessary to be able to act on the world stage. It is a delusion to think that we can protect the steel industry of individual Member States if Member States act individually on the world scale. We need the European Union to act together on this. At the end of the day, it will be necessary to build Europe on the basis of the values Europeans share: a social market economy where the values are protected, where the race to the bottom is stopped and where we make sure that through solidarity and by working together, Europe has a strong position on the world stage.  (Applause)

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the House for its remarks and comments. I will convey all of them to the President of the European Council. I took careful note of the suggestions that were addressed to me personally by Ms Berès, Mr Verhofstadt and Mr Fleckenstein, and I assure you that I will bring all of them to the attention of Mr Tusk. In response to Mr Telička’s criticisms, I would like to bring to your attention three main points. The first one is that it is the role of the Presidency to present to you the state of play in preparations for the European Council meeting. So I am here to listen to you and you can be sure that I will convey your remarks, proposals and ideas to President Tusk. That is the purpose of this debate. Secondly, Mr Tajani will intervene at the opening of the meeting and he will also have the opportunity to express Parliament’s views. Thirdly, President Tusk will be in plenary in April for a full debate with you on all these topics. In conclusion, I would like to say that we need to ensure that the decisions taken by leaders will be implemented in full over time. In that spirit, the Council will continue, under the Bulgarian Presidency, to regularly discuss the implementation of the European Council conclusions.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. — The next European Council is taking place at a crucial time, where nationalist winds blow strongly in Russia, China and the United States. In this context, the EU needs to vindicate its own life project with a long-term strategy based on human dignity, justice, democracy and sustainable development. Our commitment to the European Pillar of Social Rights is inalienable. We will await the final content of the social justice package proposed by the Commission, which must guarantee our citizens complete social protection in order to eradicate inequalities. Funding the Social Pillar leads us to a fundamental issue under discussion at the next European Council: fair taxation. It is unacceptable that multinationals pay less and less taxes while our Governments apply cuts in the welfare state. If we want to avoid the insecurity surrounding our citizens, and that nationalist and xenophobic forces continue to gain ground, we must reverse this trend. If EU leaders really want to change the EU's socio-economic context, their commitment to fair taxation must be a reality at the next European Council.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I welcome the European Council reunion next spring, where pressing issues are going to be discussed. Romania cannot accept, it is completely unacceptable an EU with two or more speeds. If taken, this path could step by step destroy the nowadays EU. There is generally one change for Europe – a solidary EU, with equal rights for members and citizens. It is unfair and incorrect to keep Romania outside the Schengen area, with all kinds of pretexts invoked mainly by Netherland for trade and economic interests, having nothing to do with Schengen area requests and standards. To put it blindly, to keep the advantages of Rotterdam harbour as a main gate for entrance within EU of foreign goods. Constanta harbour, in Romania, to the Black Sea might make a huge competition to the Rotterdam harbour, having lots of geographic and strategic advantages. This situation cannot continue in this way. The Presidency of Romania has to rise this issue stronger than ever at the next European Council meeting, on 22 and 23 March 2018. There are unfortunately double standards inside EU. I addressed again and again this situation which can jeopardise, on a medium and long term basis the EU’s future.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — The next European Council is taking place at a crucial time, where nationalist winds blow strongly in Russia, China and the United States. name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: in writing. — The rule of law in Turkey is being blatantly violated. Recently, we voted overwhelmingly in the European Parliament that Turkey cannot even have a fair trial for political dissidents with the Erdogan regime. This state, which oppresses the peoples within Turkey, imprisoning the dissidents, which despises the unanimous resolution of the UN Security Council to cease military operations and continues the invasion of Afrin, which cooperates with the most notorious terrorists , while baptizing a terrorist anyone who is Kurd, who interferes with its fleet in Cyprus's energy planning and harming the EU's energy interests, which threatens Greece and continues illegally occupying the northern part of Cyprus, so this state of Turkey unthinkably favorable treatment. The question is simple: in the name of which European values or interests which prevail above, is this distortively favourable treatment imposed on Turkey? So distortive that we are going to give it another three billion euros of European citizens for the management of Syrian refugees, at the same time that it is causing a new humanitarian tragedy by increasing the exit of refugees from Syria and strengthening the Islamic State, which it has been funding for years.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. — Dear colleagues and colleagues, the inclusion of social issues at the European Council should be clearly welcomed. Social and labour standards are an inherent dimension of the single market, so it is necessary to discuss them honestly. To discuss honestly is to discuss with everyone to whom impact measures may concern. After Brexit, 85 per cent of EU GDP will be made up of eurozone countries. Does this mean that the opinion of other countries is therefore no longer necessary to know, and parallel institutions and summits will begin to be formed to decide for everyone? Is the convening of a European Council summit for only 19 countries a signal that this is how it will proceed in the future? Such an approach challenges the principle of unity that we so often like to talk about and is a step backwards.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As announced at the beginning of the debate that has just ended, unfortunately, our colleague Jens Nilsson passed away prematurely. He died this morning, in Sweden, following a brief illness. My colleague Nilsson was first elected to the European Parliament in 2011 and re-elected in 2014 in the ranks of the Swedish Social Democratic party and sat on the S&D Group benches. on transport and tourism, the Committee on Regional Development and the Delegation for Relations with Belarus, Nilsson carried out his political activity with sincere enthusiasm and with a non- common working capacity. He campaigned with determination for a social economy, an ideal in which he firmly believed and which was for him the battle of a lifetime. On behalf of all of us, I want to address an affectionate thought to his family, his wife, daughter, and express my deepest condolences to his friends, his party mates, the S&D Group and to all those who have known and appreciated him. I therefore ask you to join me in observing a minute's silence in the memory of Jens Nilsson. (The assembly, standing, observes a minute's silence)

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I am taking the floor on behalf of the S&D Group, the group that Jan Nielsen belonged to. In just a few words, first of all I would like to thank all Members of the European Parliament for this homage and these minutes of silence. We, as the S&D Group, would like to recall him as he was: a very generous man, a man who was very committed to the European project, someone who was also very much in touch with all the people at grassroots level, and the leading actor for a social economy across Europe. Jan Nielsen, we will always remember you with much friendship.  *****

name: Ashley FOX
text: – Mr President, last week in Salisbury, my constituency, a man and his daughter were poisoned with a military-grade nerve agent. A police officer who attended the scene was also poisoned. Yesterday, the British Prime Minister announced it was highly likely that Russia was responsible for this outrage, either through a direct state—sponsored assassination attempt or because it allowed a deadly substance to pass into the hands of others. Today, we are awaiting an explanation from Moscow. This must be a wake-up call for all of us. We in the West are being tested: the annexation of Crimea, cyber—attacks in Estonia, and the use of chemical weapons in Salisbury. A disturbing pattern is emerging, one we have to meet firmly and with a united front.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The plenary applause needs no further comment.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Mr President, I rise in relation to the rules related to the conduct of Members of this House towards one another. This morning, in the debate on the relationship between the European Union and the UK, a Member of this House, Mr Alyn Smith from Scotland, quite rightly used some language to criticise Brexiteers like myself. But he used one particular word in that criticism, which I feel that you, as the President this this Chamber, would actually recognise as being highly disgraceful and would warrant an apology. He called Brexiteers shysters. As you know, the word shyster is derived from the German word for someone who defecates. But it also is a very poignant word for those of us who have Jewish ascendants or Jewish relations in our family, as I do. Shyster is used to criticise Jews on a regular basis for being dishonest and for various other aspects.  I believe that Mr Smith may not have wanted to use that phrase in that context, but now recognising the strength of that, he should apologise. I would ask you to seek that from him.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: – Mr President, I refer colleagues who might not be familiar with the English word, the definition of ‘shyster’ in the Collins English Dictionary: ‘shyster, plural shysters. If you refer to someone, especially a lawyer or politician, as a shyster, you mean that they are dishonest and immoral [...] a person, especially a lawyer or politician, who uses discreditable or unethical methods.’  There is nothing about Jewish anything in it, and nothing could have been further from my mind. Indeed, the allegation is as ridiculous as Mr Woolfe is himself. I refute it absolutely, and I would urge the House not to waste time on such nonsense.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dishonest and immoral cannot be said to anyone, but if there was no intent on his part, obviously, like that intended by Mr Woolfe, I believe that this is a sufficient clarification. But dishonest and immoral can certainly not be interpreted in the direction of another colleague.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: – Mr President, thank you for taking the point of order.  I rise under Rule 11, Section 3, and to quote the Rules of Procedure, ‘the conduct of Members shall be characterised by mutual respect’. Whatever Mr Smith’s inadequate comments just now, the fact of the matter is that he has violated the values and principles of the European Parliament, of which we had an outstanding example from Mr Fox’s comments earlier on. Notwithstanding, the request is that the President deliver to Mr Smith a formal reprimand.  (Applause)

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, I’d like to bring Parliament’s attention to Ibrahim Halawa, who is up in the viewing chamber today because in December 2015 this Parliament voted for a resolution calling for his immediate release. It is great that he is here today, now a free man, who was locked up.  (Loud applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ms Boylan, thank you very much.

name: David COBURN
text: – Mr President, I don’t normally get upset by anything, but Mr Smith is the master of the politically correct. He’d hound anyone to the gates of hell if they said anything politically incorrect. I don’t normally worry about these things, but on this occasion I think he’s gone over the top and I think he should apologise. Normally he’s not so silly, so I think he’s not doing himself or his political party any good.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Well now I think, Mr Coburn we know that you are quite lively, we know your vivacity. I believe that in the end the words spoken or the intention to use that term was of political criticism and not of offence towards the colleague, so as the interpretation was given, it was a matter of a political criticism and it seems to me that he didn't want to offend either on racial grounds, nor political reasons, so I think the word should be interpreted as pure political criticism. If it were otherwise we would be forced to intervene, but I think it was, honourable, just political criticism and nothing more.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is voting time. (For the results and other information on the votes: see Minutes)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: — We believe that this decision needs to be taken here because it is of great importance to our community. We are in favour of us Europeans doing more together for our common security, and this includes close cooperation in the security industry. But what is to be decided here is a missed opportunity. We are not going to reduce the 178 armaments systems that we have in Europe, we will not reduce the 80% purely national arms expenditure, we will not increase the efficiency rate of 15%. This means that we will not be able to achieve the objectives that will be proclaimed. That is why we are criticising this proposal. We do not need more money for armor, but more efficiency. We don't need more overcapacity. This only leads to new arms exports.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, on 21 February the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy widely adopted my report on the industrial defence programme and the negotiating mandate. I therefore ask you to support and confirm today this decision to enter into inter-institutional negotiations. This regulation we wish to support industrial cooperation in Europe in order to make our industry more competitive and encourage innovation. It is therefore a matter of developing our European industrial and technological base and limiting unnecessary and costly duplications. Our fellow citizens are asking us to act for their safety. It is therefore time to launch better cooperation at European level to meet their expectations in an international context that we know unstable. Since this regulation will come into force on 1 January 2019, we need to be able to quickly implement it and put it into the budget for 2019. I therefore ask you to support the decision to start these negotiations.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, it is quite extraordinary the way in which we conduct the debate on customs and borders as though we were still living in the 19th century, as though crossing an international frontier involved greasy customs officers in peaked caps and epaulettes opening all our bags. In fact, almost all clearance is done online and in advance these days, and that process is accelerating as technology improves. In particular, I think developments in blockchain will within a few years make all customs checks between advanced economies redundant and this is something we should greatly look forward to. What an irony that people who see themselves as being forward—looking and futuristic are, when it comes to the question of borders with non-EU countries, the most determinedly stuck in the past.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I supported this report because I believe that it builds on the news and material relating to the digital market in Europe. If a few days ago, in fact weeks, we adopted a report that relates to the online sale of goods on the Internet, then it is also good to address the question of how goods that are sold online on the Internet, deliver to the consumer. And it is this report that addresses the question of how it is possible to deliver purchased goods around Europe without the providers of these services raising tariffs only because the goods are sold across the borders of the Member states. I consider this a very important material, if we create a single market, then all borders within the European Union need to be demolished, and one of these notional boundaries is that providers services charge much larger tariffs when goods are sold and transferred from one Member State to another. That's why the material is good and I supported it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I also supported this proposal for a regulation and would like to appreciate the role of the Estonian Presidency in pushing it through. For me, it is really important that barriers are removed that even impede the rules of the single internal market. Therefore, improving the rules for the delivery of cross-border packages is really important, and while I am not a supporter of the use of the harshest form of legislation, that is, the form of regulation, I think here is completely out of place. Undoubtedly this measure, that is, regulation, will improve efficiency and transparency in the delivery of packages, improve the situation of consumers. I want to draw attention to the situation of small companies, which use this service very much and the often unfair practices of delivery people that complicate their business. So I very much welcome this adjustment, which is why I supported it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, as I said in my speech yesterday, thousands of Turkish trucks are circulating without the requirements of the law both in Greece and in the European Union, causing hundreds of accidents. There must be a check on the monkey diplomas that the drivers of Turkish lorries have, the conditions under which they operate must be checked, because they do not even comply with the standards. In addition, in Greece there is a process whereby duty-free shops allow Turkish trucks at the border, in Evros and Kipi, to be supplied with duty-free oil, and so Turkish trucks are unwrongly competing with Greek professionals. This must be stopped and the judgment of the Court of Justice C 590/2016, issued on 8 February 2018, must finally be implemented, forcing the Greek Government to stop the operation of OEMs in the areas I mentioned, namely Kipi and other border areas of Greece, and prohibits to supply duty-free oil. This decision, which concerns Kakavia, Evzonous and Evros Gardens, must be implemented at last. This is something we demand here and now to be implemented.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, when we highlighted the role of the single market in the last report, which talks about improving the conditions for cross-border delivery of shipments, that is, for better delivery options, road transport is key. The latter is crucial in general to the functioning of the internal market. In order to improve the efficiency and safety of road transport, it seems, to increase the safety requirements and the qualification of drivers appropriately. Unfortunately, the labour market situation in many Member States of the European Union precisely in the field of road truck transport is very tight, there is a shortage of drivers, and if we subvote those claims that we have on drivers, in the sense of reducing these claims, for example, unequal conditions across Member States, so I think it will also affect our safety. That is why I welcomed the report and supported it because it introduces reasonable, comparable rules and a level playing field into road transport safety.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr President! The aim of the report was to make recommendations to the Union on gender equality in trade, especially in the context of new trade agreements signed, such as CETA, TTIP or TiSA, where trade liberalisation and trade agreements relate more to services, standards and regulations than ordinary trade. However, it is difficult to agree to a call for quantitative and qualitative data by gender or on the impact on trade or the impact of gender in trade policy, by gender across all trade and investment agreements. Similarly, it is unacceptable to propose the need for employment in all ministries of trade of Member States or to promote equal presence of women in the internal structure of the WTO, the World Bank or other trade organisations where employment should depend on professionalism of individuals, not from gender, which is why I voted against the report.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! The European Union's trade policy cannot be guided only by narrowly defined principles of growth, competition and productivity. It should also be a tool for promoting values such as international labour standards and human rights. Unfortunately, the labour situation of women outside the borders of the European Union is difficult, and although women contribute significantly to the development of the global economy, they remain invisible to trade policy. Most women in the countries of the global South are employed as lower-level workers in sectors such as agriculture and seasonal work. In southern Asia, for example, in the confection industry, mainly women are employed on slavish terms. That is why I believe that trade agreements should have a positive effect on improving women's situation. However, the report we are voting on today is moving in the wrong direction, because through free trade agreements it wants to export gender ideology. We must raise standards and adhere to civilisational labour standards, but the European Union cannot impose its left-wing worldview.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr President! Ladies and gentlemen. Officially, as Commissioner Andriukaitis wrote this year, the European Commission recognises the differences in states' approach to the issue of abortion, which is not the subject of European Union policy or legislation. So why is the Commission silent? And here Commissioner Thyssen listened to the rationale of Ms. Forenza and Björk's report, and why is she silent if we are dealing with the European Union's involvement in the export of the abortion revolution in the world? I call on the European Commission to respect the treaties, and I remind you that our countries — and there are, thankfully, a few — that, while promoting the civilization of life in their law, have the right to respect. And to defend that respect, we have the right to demand from the European Commission.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I finally refrained from this report after much thought, and I therefore provide this explanation of my decision. I am a big supporter of free trade. I believe that the free trade agreements that the European Union concludes with third countries, such as South Korea, objectively bring great economic benefits. I also see as a very important topic of gender and gender equality and the protection of women. On the other hand, it strikes me that this message kind of mixes pears and apples. By and large, a little bit, the spirit of the fact that we don't all completely support free trade and not all colleagues are supporters of these international agreements. That's why I refrained because I think both topics are too serious and should be dealt with separately and not like this together.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! The report proposes positive solutions to support growth, sustainable development and job creation in the less developed regions of the European Union. They are based on the principle of subsidiarity and partnership. These solutions consist of improving the relationship between entrepreneurs and businesses and universities, investing in infrastructure and education, improving connections between cities and neighbouring areas, greater investment in public institutions to improve effectiveness and the efficiency of public administration and the strengthening of the links between the European semester and the cohesion policy. Although the report generally promotes positive solutions, I did not support the funding part related to the migration crisis through the European Structural and Investment Funds.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: — Mr President, the island of Mayotte is the poorest region in the European Union. Yes, yes! The poorest region of the European Union is a French region while France is the second largest economic power of the European Union. And you should know that currently Mayotte is plunged into the most serious crisis in its history. In Mayotte, 84% of the population lives below the poverty line, half of the population is illegal immigrants and public services are destitute. I say here from Strasbourg that Mayotte is a shame for France and that France shames Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: — The situation of EU regions lagging behind is also extremely worrying, as current trends preserve backlog and make the effective use of cohesion policy instruments difficult. I come from a country where most of the development regions are lagging behind and I would like to draw attention to two serious problems. One is the difference between the statistical data and the real situation: if we look at the differences within each development region, it seems that without the results of the major cities, which are the development pole, the situation would be even more disappointing. There is a trend for these development poles to drain resources and investment from the peripheral and less developed regions of the region, which intensifies already serious inequalities, and development policy has no response to this. Another serious problem is the phenomenon of emigration: on the one hand, migration to more developed regions can be observed within each region, and on the other hand, we see this at European level, not only from east to west, but also from south to north. Emigration puts the lagging regions in an even more difficult position, as the active, young, working layer with the potential for growth is going away.

name: Stefano MAULLU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report has the merit of putting to the attention of the European Parliament the imbalance between the various regions, and in particular of putting under a magnifying glass the poorest and least developed regions of the Union. Here, I believe that this is an absolutely central topic at this historical moment, and I say this thinking of an island, one of the largest islands in the Mediterranean, Sardinia, which suffers — despite the principle of territorial continuity is guaranteed by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union — of a series of utterly intolerable imbalances, imbalances that penalise the island from every point of view , particularly in the transport sector. It becomes almost impossible to think, but it is reality, that the citizens of this island, Italian citizens, European citizens, are unable to move with the same freedom that their Italian countrymen have, rather than the other countries of the Union. I believe that this is one of the focal points to restore dignity and justice to an island that is an integral part of Italy and Europe.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr Transit, I supported this report because I think it is right for us to address the problems of the poorest regions within the framework of European solidarity. The report talks about forty-seven regions in eight states and it is very well, I welcome it in the report that in addition to the financial support and assistance underlying the cohesion policy, the report also addresses other aspects and problems of these poorer regions. There is a question of labour law, there is a question of how individual Member State governments should deal with reforms that could lead to greater economic growth in the regions, because any financial support under the cohesion policy, while welcome and correct in my opinion, will not solve the poverty of certain areas in the long term. Without kick-starting economic growth in these areas, support will only be support.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, a third of the current EU budget is allocated to a financial instrument which supports cohesion policy, and we cannot allow this amount of money to be spent inefficiently. For this particular reason, I greatly welcome the report drafted by our colleague, Ms Giuffrida.  My country, Latvia, is one of the clear winners of EU cohesion policy. However, we need to reinforce its social dimension. Social inclusion is crucial for the harmonious growth of the EU, and when I speak about inclusion I speak about minorities and vulnerable groups. They need to be given a role to play, and they need to have a voice at the political stage. They should benefit from EU policies too.  On another role, the implementation of cohesion funds should not become a victim of politicisation. EU cohesion funds are not a vehicle for the European parties to achieve their short-term goals. Nepotism, corruption and politically motivated appointments should be absolutely excluded from our cohesion projects.

name: John FLACK
text: – Mr President, I was proud to be the ECR’s shadow rapporteur on this report. We made very useful progress. We made it clear, firstly, that stronger monitoring mechanisms are needed to measure the contribution made by cohesion policy in fighting climate change; secondly, that greater autonomy is needed for cities so that they can adopt their own mitigation plans free from Brussels’ interference; and thirdly, that support should be given to the collaboration between businesses and cities in spearheading green tech and decarbonisation. These are all points which I and the ECR were happy to support, but we could not support paragraph 20, which reiterates the need to increase the post—2020 cohesion policy budget. This was a separate amendment which was not included when negotiating the compromises. It has been the long—standing position of the UK delegation and the ECR Group not to support further spending in this area. I therefore advise the ECR to abstain, as I did.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, combating climate change needs both large and small actions, and that scale — small, local — is the one that is showing the greatest commitment to the energy transition. The national commitments that governments have made in the Paris Agreement have proved inadequate, and I would like to congratulate the municipalities and regions that are taking action today. In the Spanish State, for example, the municipalities of change are playing a key role, with measures, such as those in Madrid, Barcelona or Cádiz, to ensure that public buildings are supplied with 100% renewable energy, support energy efficiency in households or eradicate energy poverty. Secondly, in coal-dependent regions, we need to safeguard the dignity of their people. Therefore, we demand clarity in the closing dates of coal, because only with a marked and well-defined end horizon can we activate all the social actors necessary for a just transition with alternatives. From our cities and from our regions we must put in the hands of people the new, more sustainable energy system.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Mr President! Dear ladies! I supported the report on the role of regions and cities of the European Union in implementing the Paris Agreement from the COP21 Conference on Climate Change for several reasons. I think it's a good thing that there's calls for investment in solutions that will improve urban air quality. We should support initiatives that help protect the lives and health of our citizens. A good example is increasing support for the thermomodernization of public buildings. I agree that the regional policy budget should be increased after 2020. Additionally, funding is necessary to support innovation and research that will help develop new technologies to reduce pollution. This is extremely important in particular from the point of view of mining regions, which, like Polish Silesia, are in the process of energy transformation. I hope that funds for modern coal technologies will be in this project.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of climate change is particularly close to the heart of the We are pleased with the report because three instances proposed by us have been included in it, namely: one, the proposal to consider reducing greenhouse gas emissions, remediation work and activities aimed at regenerating and decontaminating polluted industrial sites as an important element in assessing the performance of operational programmes. Two, the vital role regions, cities and local authorities have in promoting the energy transition: clean energy innovations and small-scale renewable energy projects are fundamental in achieving the objectives of Paris, together with a truly sustainable and more generally sustainable local public transport together with an awareness given by the correct and complete information of citizenship on the importance of the consequences of climate change. Three, condemnation of the irresponsibility of capitalism and the production methods of the old second industrial revolution, and therefore of the economic activities and sectors of industry they generate, even today in Europe, unacceptable levels of pollution. I cannot fail to mention the economic, social and environmental disasters that have made in my land the Ilva steelworks, the Enel coal plant, and today the TAP pipeline. Europe promotes a world that makes the latest technologies the mainstay of a new economic system, from 5G internet communication to the new driverless mobility. We need to change the economic model ASAP, otherwise we will be overwhelmed by a mass extinction, that caused by man and its activities. We need a precise political will, which sets up incentive mechanisms in cohesion policy for the dissemination of the technologies of the third revolution in the territory industrial.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí sé de phribhléid agam a bheith i bPáras don chomhaontú athrú aeráide, COP 21, agus anois tá sé de phribhléid agam a bheith gafa leis na trilogues maidir le hathrú fuinnimh in-athnuaite agus is léir go bhfuil mórán le déanamh ag ár réigiún agus ár gcathracha chun sprioc Pháras a bhaint amach. Indeed, it has been estimated that 75% of European cities are struggling to make steps to adapt to climate change because of a lack of awareness among decision—makers, lack of technical knowledge and difficulties in accessing funding. So I fully support the call on the Commission to provide increased support for cities and regions in the fields of training and awareness—raising, financial guidance, communication, etc., so that together they can play a decisive role in tackling climate change.  We should support them in investing in green infrastructure, mobility, public transport and smart grids to meet the targets set out the Paris Agreement.  Sa tslí sin bainfimid amach ár sprioc.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The sitting is adjourned at 1.34 p.m.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the joint debate on – the report by Jan Olbrycht, Isabelle Thomas, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the next MFF: Preparing the Parliament’s position on the MFF post-2020 (2017/2052(INI)) (A8—0048/2018), and – the report by Gérard Deprez, Janusz Lewandowski, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on reform of the European Union’s system of own resources (2017/2053(INI)) (A8—0041/2018).

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! Commissioner! The European Parliament shall take a position on the future financial framework through its own initiative report, which sets out a certain policy position on the future multiannual budget of the European Union or the multiannual financial perspective. We recognise that the European Commission is preparing to present a draft of its future financial framework on 2 May, which is why the European Parliament is making an effort to propose to the European Commission, but also to the European Council its position on this framework. We are therefore working on both the income side, as the rapporteur will talk about, as well as the expenses side. The European Parliament considers that the European Union should maintain the level of its ambitions after 2020 and act at the level previously adopted. It matters so much that Britain's exit from the European Union — Brexit — will, of course, affect the functioning of the European Union, but we believe that the Union should nonetheless remain at a certain level when it comes to the budget. At the same time, we remember that it is important not only about 1%, but also what Member States agree among themselves for the next seven years in all policy areas. The European Parliament therefore proposed a certain size of the budget, realising that the proposal could be controversial. However, it follows specific calculations on the nominal level of agriculture and cohesion policy, as well as strengthening those policies that we consider very effective, namely programmes such as Erasmus, COSME and the unemployed youth programme. But it is important for us to find resources for new defence and security challenges. The European Parliament refers to the very way of building a financial perspective. Therefore, with huge emphasis we are talking about strengthening the mechanisms flexibility. We believe that the flexibility mechanisms in operation today are working and that they should be broadened so that the European Union can respond efficiently to new challenges. In addition, the European Parliament is strongly in favour of a clear end to the whole procedure until the 2019 election, and we are mainly concerned that the new actions commencing on 1 January 2021 are well prepared, legislatively developed and secured financial resources. Therefore, we are ready to make all possible efforts to accelerate this procedure. And we are ready to work closely with the European Commission on this issue. Commissioner! We are counting on our proposal, which we will vote on tomorrow, to be thoroughly read and seriously considered by the Commission and the Council, and to form the basis for our continued cooperation.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, representatives of the Council — who are not here —, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to sincerely thank you. First of all, my co-rapporteur Jan Olbrycht, with whom we have been able to work in good intelligence, with respect for our convictions and in the interests of Parliament and European citizens, and who, above all, managed to support me, and that is not over. Thanks also to the shadow rapporteurs and the secretariat of the Committee on Budgets, as well as to the rapporteurs of the specialized committees. Tomorrow the European Parliament will have its mandate to negotiate the financial future of the European Union. Based on the analysis of the current undersized financial framework, heckled by incessant cuts or redeployments, we refuse to renew the lack of ambition and seriousness that characterized the exercise of this MFF. Our message is a triptych that wants to live up to the situation. Firstly, to maintain the political pillars of the Union, namely cohesion and agricultural policy, without which we will lose the link that unites us. Secondly, to strengthen the EU's flagship policies: Erasmus +, support for youth against unemployment, research and COSME. Finally, thirdly, open up the new challenges of the ecological transition of security and defence. This triptych is based on a principle that we want to enshrined in the marble: no new policy without additional means. Together, we are making new commitments: the Paris climate agreement, which will have to translate into a target of 30% of expenditure, the European pillar of social rights, and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. These commitments constitute a pact for the reorientation of all Union policies. Building on lessons from the past, we propose to expand the flexibility instruments of the next financial framework in the need to strike the delicate balance between predictability and budgetary flexibility. It must also restore the unity of the Union budget by restoring parliamentary control and bringing order to the budgetary galaxy by integrating financial instruments and other trust funds into the Union budget. The addition is without appeal and the calculation is economical in view of the stakes and expectations of Europeans. The next framework will have to be increased to 1.3% of GDP. In this regard, and to get out of the number fetishism, I want to restore a truth that some pretend to ignore: the current financial framework is limited to 1% of the Union's GDP, compared with 1.25% in 1999. The European Union has never had so much to do with so little. To get out of the vicious circle of this budget deflation, we exchanged our vows and alliances with colleagues Lewandowski and Deprez. This joint debate and tomorrow's vote on the own resources reports and the next financial framework send a clear message: Parliament will not be able to give its consent to the next multiannual financial framework without concrete results on own resources. It's time to get out of budget helplessness. The Council and Parliament have set the objectives. Responsibility requires that the Union budget be provided with the means to reach them, and the Member States are expected to be something other than the great speeches or, in any case, that the great speeches will be accompanied by sounding and stumbling species. We call on the Commission to draw inspiration from Parliament's work and we call on the Council to open negotiations tomorrow.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is time to put an end to the long drift that has taken place in the financing of the Union budget. However, the Treaty is clear: Article 311 states that 'the Union budget is, without prejudice to other revenue, fully financed by own resources'. We are far away. Today, contributions from national budgets account for almost 70% of the Union's revenue. Worse, since Margaret Thatcher's “I want my money back”, the drift of the system has resulted in a monster of opacity. The British rebate gave rise to discounts on discounts, which have been added over the years multiple and heterogeneous corrections, which it is totally impossible to explain to citizens. Indeed, the Union's budget is no longer the instrument of a common project. It has become a crate, heavy to feed for some, interesting to empty for others. The fair return tends to become the alpha and omega of the European budget. This situation has already been strongly denounced. Our colleague, Alain Lamassoure, brilliantly tried it. Our colleague, Janusz Lewandowski, tried to correct it when he was commissioner, in both cases in sheer loss. More recently, at the insistence of our assembly, the three institutions set up the Monti Group, which has done a remarkable job. Our report is consistent with the conclusions of this group, which were — I insist — endorsed by the representatives appointed by the three institutions. In doing so, we are pursuing a threefold objective: it is to respect — as I said — the requirement of Article 311 of the Treaty and to break the logic of fair return; it is a question of compensating for the negative effect of Brexit on the budget; and structurally, it is a matter of giving the Union the means to deal with the great and new challenges ahead of us. We therefore call for the gradual introduction of a package of new own resources in order to protect the budget from the vagaries and fluctuations of a single resource. We call for the selection, in this package, of new resources that are directly linked to the creation of European added value in the Union's strategic policies. We advocate the removal of discounts, all discounts, discounts on discounts, all existing or invented corrections. We call for a consequential reduction in budgetary contributions from Member States, which are expected to become residual in the coming years. Three key points to conclude: by voting for these two reports, you will affirm Parliament's determination when it announces that it will not approve the future multiannual financial framework if it does not include the implementation of new own resources to guarantee its financing. We also ask you to approve our request to amend Article 311 of the Treaty when it regulates the own resources decision-making procedure. The European Parliament, as a budgetary authority equal to the Council, cannot resolve itself to a simple consultative role in the introduction of own resources. This contempt for parliamentary democracy is not acceptable. Finally, parliamentary democracy also does not accommodate the situation in which the Parliament elected after the 2019 elections would have no say in the financial framework that will organize, for seven years, the use of the budgetary appropriations it provides. In conclusion of this statement, I extend my thanks to my co-rapporteur Janusz Lewandowski, and to the MFF rapporteurs Jan Olbrycht and Isabelle Thomas, my colleagues and friends, Eider Gardiazabal and José Manuel Fernandes, and to my colleague, Helga Trüpel, my budget associate, the secretariat of the Committee on Budgets, our political advisers and my friend, Pierre Verkaeren, for her valuable assistance.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! Commissioner! Designing and reconciling a multiannual financial framework is never business as usual. There are always special circumstances: either the historical enlargement of the European Union or, as with the current financial framework, the depth of the crisis and the talk of the Greek. Now the special circumstance is brexit. One of the net payers is disappearing, but the most ardent supporter of maintaining the European Union's funding way to date is disappearing. Our two reports go hand in hand. We know perfectly well that the position of the European Parliament on both issues is not the same. We have the strongest position in annual budgets. In the case of the multiannual financial framework, Parliament's consent is needed and, in the case of own funds, only consultation with Parliament. We are not just positioning Parliament. We, too, want to embolden the Commission, and particularly ermutigen Herrn Oettinger, to make an ambitious proposal on 2 May, which will not expose us to the kind of problems that I experienced myself from 2013 to 2014, when there was a shortage of money for the EU programmes implemented. Our two reports also link the will to conclude negotiations before the European elections. This is an extremely ambitious task, given that the negotiations previously lasted 2.5 years, and we have 9 months left for the final arrangements, which is to say great political will and synchronisation of the calendars of all the EU institutions, because the motive is noble, lest there be delays, so that there are no delays Do not waste the beginnings of the next perspective, just as the years 2015, 2016 and even 2017 have been wasted. On the side of the own resources I dealt with together with Gérard Deprez, we have a paradox. The system is extremely heavily criticised, but since the late 1980"s very stable. It is opaque, incomprehensible and indeed enforces logic juste retour. Causes the perception of budget negotiations as a zero-sum game, and contributions as a cost rather than an investment in the future of their own country and the European Union as a whole. I am a kind of living memory of the last proposal, which was based on two new own funds, i.e. simplified VAT and financial transaction tax, and was also based on a fundamental simplification of the whole system. Little is left of this, but under pressure from the European Parliament, a high-level group has been set up under Mr Monti's leadership and we draw on its acquis. We draw from Monti's acquis. Knowing that we are reinstating the proposal in a slightly better climate — at the moment there is no longer such belt-tightening as in 2011-13 — we respect the fiscal sovereignty of the Member States. We know that all own funds decisions must be approved, ratified by national parliaments. But we are opening up to the possibility of rethinking the system, because here in the European Parliament, too, people elected by people in 28 countries — still in 28 countries — so you can move the principle of no taxation without representation here. We postulate our own basket of own funds. Some we repeat. Seigniorage emerges, which is the most controversial. We postulate a special provision and a move away from discounts and adjustments. But first and foremost, I thank my co-rapporteur Gerard Deprez, all the advisers and all the shadow rapporteurs who participated in the preparation of the report.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. The Commission takes note with interest and pleasure in the draft two reports under discussion today. I see Parliament's groundbreaking considerations, structures, expectations and conditions in both reports, which, if you adopt them, will certainly be further included in the European Commission's final work on the way to May this year. I would particularly like to thank the four rapporteurs — Mr Olbrycht, Mrs Thomas, Mr Deprez, Mr Lewandowski — for their outstanding work with their staff, but also for good cooperation with my services and with me. budgetary frameworks will certainly facilitate from May. It is about the future of Europe, as Mr Arthuis always emphasises, and what can then be done to shape the future with budgetary resources, financial programmes and the multiannual financial framework. First of all, the own resources — an age-old story of who reads them: they have always been unsuccessful on the road since the 1950s. But the budget from national budgets, which once amounted to 10% of total revenue, is now 70%. That is why it is time to diversify our revenues. I'm talking about diversification, which does not automatically mean increase. I would like to reduce the contribution from national budgets somewhat and build up the share of new own resources as another pillar. Several proposals have been made in your draft report — Mr Deprez and Mr Lewandowski — which are also largely in line with what the High Level Group led by Mario Monti has developed. I should like to point out that this group is not a group of the Commission, no Parliament's group, not a Mario Monti group, it is a group of all three institutions, and there were also three representatives of the Council. And unanimity at the end of the proposals should actually mean that this should not be a zero-sum game. We will be finally discussing what proposals we are making in the coming weeks. But we will certainly define two, three, four proposals on the revenue side, and this would, I believe, make it much easier for the next financial framework. The topic of discounts was mentioned. Here, too, we think in harmony. A significant part of the discounts are discounts from the British rebate to reduce the reduction of UK payments for other net payers. So, when the British discount falls, this part of the discounts automatically falls away. We now have further corrective measures and rebates, and I would like to mention as a starting point, as our Commission proposal, that we will not propose any discounts. And for the sake of honesty, I do not rule out the way from the discussions that there may be a few, unbureaucratic, moderate discounts if we are to achieve unanimity in the negotiations. So far for the Own Resources Report. With regard to the main report by Mrs Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, I would say that 90% of your 167 pages are in line with what the Commission is going to develop. We cooperated extensively, too. I have been to your Committee on Budgets on several occasions, I have been to many groups, I am going to other groups, have been on technical committees. This means that it is no surprise that your report largely coincides with the rough draft that we are now refining and that some of your proposals will be included in our proposal. With our communication of February, we have tried to give the European Council, the Council, but also Parliament and all stakeholders — the Committee of the regions, the Economic and Social Committee — to show what is at stake. It's a kind of menu. Now you need to decide, now the advice will have to decide what to order. Jean-Claude Juncker, my colleagues and I — we are cooks and waiters, we are waiting for what you order. If you want to pick up a comprehensive menu consisting of border management and social policy, which consists of research and Erasmus, if you want to double Erasmus, to increase horizons, then we deliver. And we charge and expect to pay. It's like a restaurant. Now we actually have a problem that we should avoid in the best possible way. I would like to avoid a conflict in this House and also in the Council and in public, a conflict that could exist in cohesion against migration or agrar against defence. This would once again put the European family at risk of division. We have traditional programs, but traditionally does not mean that they belong in the House of History. Traditional programmes can continue to be sustainable. I believe that cohesion policy remains sustainable. Why? Take a look at the GDP per capita in the Member States and regions. On average, GDP per inhabitant of Europe is EUR 28 000, in my own country EUR 40 000, in Luxembourg EUR 100 000 and EUR 6 800 in Bulgaria. This does not hold Europe together in the long term, which is unreasonable in the long run. We need to reduce the gap in GDP per capita, not by bringing Luxembourg down to 30 000, but by increasing the competitiveness of Bulgaria, Romania, the new Member States and regions of southern Europe through investment, thereby increasing their competitiveness and thus bringing the GDP per capita up. That is what I call a solidarity union. Modern cohesion policy must do this. I do not know if cohesion policy will still be necessary in 2050 but I know that over the next decade it will remain permanently necessary for the accession of less developed regions to the average and to increase the competitiveness of all regions, as well as for social measures and for smart environmental measures and for infrastructure measures. That is why a baluding of cohesion would be completely wrong. The same applies to agricultural policy. In our proposal we will simplify agricultural policy, we want to improve greening, we want to reconcile the agricultural sector and the environment even more, we want to give the farmer money to ensure that he has good food of sufficient quantity and high quality, in compliance with our environmental and animal welfare legislation and the soil protection, water protection and climate protection regulations. This is also why agricultural policy remains viable for the future. Now we have very different agricultural structures. We have the part-time farmer, who owns 15 hectares, and we have the large company that manages 5 000 hectares. We have to master this balancing act. That is why the willingness of all parties to compromise is part of We have two gaps, the Brexit gap and the spending gap created by new challenges. Our proposal: We close the Brexit gap with 50% redeployances and cuts and 50% additional revenue. However, if we tackle new challenges, if we believe in the interests of our citizens and Member States that Europe can act and finance more efficiently in defence research, border management, border control, migration and aid to refugees, then we need the Member States' money for this. 80% fresh money and 20% of internal shifts is our proposal for this. A second last point, the ceiling: you suggest 1.3%. I think this is ambitious, but very factual. 1,3 is not beyond good and evil, on the contrary. Parliament is proposing a very, very justifiable serve. Our formula is 1.1x because we still have some uncertainties. The inclusion of the Development Assistance Fund is an unpredictability, the question of deepening the Economic and Monetary Union and the money to be invested in structural support, for the willingness to reform and for the accession of the euro. A second uncertainty: we still expect some advice from the Council, otherwise we will translate our proposal into concrete figures after Easter. And then we'll dissolve the x of 1.1x into a concrete number. One final point: the net contributor debate. She is increasingly meaningless. At a time when CAP and cohesion were well over 80% of expenditure, it was still possible to calculate the cash return relatively accurately. Next in the MFF, however, CAP and cohesion will fall to around 60-61% of all expenditure. And soon 40% will be accounted for by Erasmus, refugee aid, research where there is no reflux in this sense. If we invest in education, safety, clothing, food and protection for refugees in Turkey and their human dignity, nothing will come back. But the refugees are spared the difficult way to reach us via the Mediterranean, and the costs are not incurred here, but are much more efficient on the ground. That is why we should convince the Member States and also the media that the view of net contributors has long been outdated and no longer satisfies the new tasks and programmes. Thank you for your preliminary work. We would be happy to hear further oral expectations from you, evaluate them, incorporate them into our proposal and then join the Commission proposal on 2 May and with all the additional implementing provisions at the end of May. We are grateful for the fact that you have made the MFF one of your priorities in Parliament for 2018, that you appoint your rapporteurs early, that you are planning an intensive meeting schedule by February to March next year. 'Cause if it failing to adopt essential decisions or the whole package before Easter next year, I predict that nothing will happen in 2019, and then the MFF will be adopted by 2020 at the end of the year. And then 2021 would be a completely lost year for farmers, researchers, regions, mayors and Europe's economic development. This should be avoided. Then we would have learned from the experience of the past. We did this wrong in 2013. One more point: if the British friends are leaving us and 27 Member States and Members of many groups are able to agree on this controversial issue, they will send an excellent signal that Europe is alive and that it is a Europe of good governance.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Commissioner, thank you for a very complex and balanced introduction from your side. Like the distribution between the Council and Parliament and the chefs and the menu, I would only perhaps be tempted to say that it is also good for you to assess the ingredients on the menu and tell us from time to time whether it is healthy or less healthy, but that is just a side comment. But the message was clearly understood.

name: Neena GILL
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. – Mr President, EU leaders in Rome last year vowed to be big on big issues and small on small ones. That is why the Committee on Foreign Affairs is calling for an ambitious approach to foreign policy in the MFF. I don’t need to rehearse all the crises that the European Union is expected to deal with – they span the globe – but what I want to make clear is a call for sufficient resources to meet these expectations, for more flexibility in order to be in step with fast-changing global developments, and for better coordination. But let none of this be a blank cheque to undercut long—term policy objectives in favour of short—sighted goals, such as cracking down on migration or decreasing transparency.
