I have a few questions to the Commissioner. How will the Commission ensure better coordination of the external financing instrument? It should go hand in hand with increased transparency. Concretely, what evaluation mechanisms will be put in place to monitor the spending of taxpayers’ money on foreign policy and ensure that it is in line with clear and agreed objectives? Finally, do you agree that the role of this House is key in ensuring solid support for EU action and that it is really important that we have agreement before the end of this mandate?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — (DE) Mr President, Commissioner. For us in development policy, it is really crucial that these sustainable development goals are implemented: Objective 2 — Agriculture, Objective 6 — Water, sanitation and Objective 7 — renewable energy. Above all, we want public tenders to take place here so that consumers can clearly understand where the money is going. Auctions or beauty contests are also the basis for the efficient allocation of subsidies in this area. We also want to promote blending and PPP models in the future and also integrate the European Development Fund EDF into the EU budget. It is important for us to follow the more-for-more approach, whereby those who work well with us in development policy will get more, and that we encourage small and medium-sized enterprises on both sides in particular to cooperate with each other. This can only be achieved with public tendering, transparency, and the best are to win.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. — (NL) Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his extremely clear and clear presentation of the procedure. The opinion of the Committee on International Trade focuses on own resources. Own resources in international trade are often somewhat unpredictable, because taxes and trade defence instruments do not always lead to structural funding. Charges — look at the American problems at the moment — are not popular in international trade, and we have to take this into account. We also call on the Commissioner and the Commission to ensure effective control and levying of customs duties. There, however, we have a more structural own resource that we can use. I wish him every success in the further procedure on this very large dossier.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, first of all, let me congratulate Commissioner Oettinger on the very solid and sound speech that we have just heard. This is exactly what we need. My sincere thanks and congratulations to all the rapporteurs and shadows for the two reports – you have done an excellent job – but the key point is this: Europe needs a strong budget and a strong MFF.  We have a lot of challenges ahead of us. We are actually facing more serious challenges than we have ever faced since the birth of this Union, and therefore we have to do more together and we have to do more together especially in those things where we can deliver more and get more. This means that we will have to emphasise the clear added value of the EU in the MFF, along with proper controls. On top of all this, we have to draw a line: with no respect for European values, there will be no European money. All this we have to be able to do without forgetting the traditional tasks. This is no small order.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Mr President, in order to achieve maximum results through the overall planning process in the EU, the next MFF should be embedded in a broader strategy. This long-term vision, covering the whole period of the next decade, is more of a statement of general strategic direction. The MFF translates the EU’s policy priorities into budgetary means. EU policies are implemented through a wide range of programmes and, from this point of view, the MFF is not a budget for seven years, but rather a collection of resources geared towards accomplishing the Union’s main goals. The MFF should prioritise support for the common agricultural and cohesion policies, closing the gap between the Member States, as well as the emerging policy areas related to security and migration. To provide the resources needed, the system for financing the EU budget should be reformed based on the recommendations of the High Level Group on Own Resources. Resources have to be spent more efficiently and effectively and create higher European added value. In order to achieve our goals for a strong and more ambitious Europe in a rapidly changing political environment, we should increase the MFF expenditure ceilings, foster flexibility mechanisms and special instruments and simplify the EU budgetary system.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by voting on the texts under discussion, Parliament takes a position on the future financial framework and on its financing through real own resources. In the light of the new challenges facing the EU with respect to youth research and mobility, but also on the issues of culture and education, cultural and creative industries, migrants, social issues, Reality talk is needed on the completion of the eurozone and banking union, or security and defence issues and new programmes. After 2020 will serve a wider budget in absolute terms, not just percentages, despite Brexit, but also a more shared awareness: contributions to the European budget are not an expense but an investment. Surely we can do more together to make our action more effective, achieve economies of scale, better and greater public goods of a European scale, and spending less overall. But we need to increase the size of the budget, which must not be done by relying on more contributions from the already bound Member States, so own resources should be increased as has been pointed out ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — Mr President, a healthy living environment is a prerequisite for all well-being. The EU has made commitments and set goals in climate and environmental policy and also in terms of sustainable development. It is imperative that the Union's money spending is also aligned with those stated objectives. The next financial framework period must be prepared in such a way that these objectives are met. The Commission must submit a motion in respect of these objectives. Then a few words from outside the Committee on the Environment: I think the level of funding of 1% and 3% in the report is unrealistic. It even exceeds the Commission's estimates of the need for funding. The budget deficit caused by Brexit is a significant challenge. In reality, that means a scarcer budget. We can use the situation to critically go through all the EU's funding needs.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: Rapporteur for the opinion, Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. — Mr President, thank you to the rapporteurs. I think it is a very, very good, very balanced report and it is their merit that they have succeeded in doing so together. I also thank the Commissioner for his cooperation so far, and I hope that during the negotiation he will still be as open and in contact with Parliament. The term, as you said, must be before the elections, politically it is very important to discuss policies immediately after Brexit. The level is obviously going to be decided in the European Council, but remember, everyone is relating to the current budget, but now the budget has been decided by Cameron. So we shouldn't take that much into account. About ITRE, about research policy, I know that you are in favour of raising the Horizon ceiling, and I would also like the facility for connecting Europe in transport policy to be raised, because it was very low by that Cameron budget and do not forget about flexibility, please nice.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. — (PT) Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to highlight four points. It is clear the position of the Members of Agriculture and Budgets to increase or at least maintain the financial envelope of the common agricultural policy, so that it remains one of the main pillars of the European project, without national co-financing in the first pillar and without any attempts to renationalization of the same. Our position is clear to support the increase in the financial envelope of the POSEI programme, which guarantees the sustainability of agricultural production in the outermost regions and needs to be strengthened in order to meet the enormous challenges facing them. It is clear that we need to re-have an autonomous POSEI fisheries independent of the EMFF. In an initiative led by me, we have achieved the adoption of the final report in the Committee on Budgets and which I hope will be adopted in plenary tomorrow. The Commissioner continues to wave at cuts in the funds for agriculture. I would remind you that European farmers have suffered since 2014 from the Commission's diplomatic decisions that resulted in the Russian embargo on our agricultural products, and now the Commission wants to penalise them again. Mr. Commissioner, of course we can't cut agriculture. Listen to the European Parliament and join us in convincing the Council.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the current system of own resources is very complex, unfair, opaque and sometimes incomprehensible: a system is not quite complex. subject to any effective parliamentary scrutiny and therefore, in my opinion, completely legitimacy is lacking. The way in which the own resources system has evolved, gradually replacing real own resources with so-called national contributions, places an overemphasis on net balances between Member States, ignoring the contribution of the Union budget to achieving common European objectives. There is a need for reform of the resources of the imperative Union to lead to greater coherence between revenue and budgetary expenditure policies. In my report, I highlighted some proposals which I think deserve the support of the European Parliament and the Commission, and I am referring to the reform of the own VAT resource and the exchange system European Union emissions, the CO2 emissions tax, transport and electricity taxation, a tax on financial transactions at European level, a tax on financial transactions at European level, a tax on corporate income and revenue from the digital single market.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. — Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, I am delighted to hear its evolution since we started the debate on the financial framework. Having heard what he said today, his words, I must say that I love his evolution. On behalf of the Committee on Fisheries, I wish to stress the socio-economic and ecological importance of the fisheries sector, the marine environment and the blue economy. This fisheries sector — small in the budget, but very important — needs a specific fund adequately endowed, independent and accessible on fisheries to implement this policy — if not, it could actually be seriously affected. It is also necessary that the level of financial credit for this sector be maintained within the current financial framework and that, if new needs arise, financial appropriations for maritime affairs should be increased. This is important. And I join Mrs Ribeiro's point in relation to the CAP: we want a CAP that is sufficiently endowed and not renationalised.

name: Helga TRÜPEL
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. — (DE) Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. Budgetary policy is generally considered unsexy. But it's not, this is the powerhouse of politics. After all, everything that will decide in the European Union over the next few years is linked to this multiannual financial framework. In principle, I think Mr Oettinger's proposal on the overall architecture is correct: slightly less for traditional agriculture, slightly less for cohesion. But policy in this area needs to be speeding up, the application procedures must be simplified, and of course — I say this as Greens — they must become more environmentally friendly. At the same time, we must respond to the major questions: defence, the protection of external borders, the fight against global inequality in the European Union, but especially on a global scale in Africa and Asia. And then, of course, we will have to take climate policy and the Paris Agreement much more seriously than we have done so far. And we need to set new priorities, and here too I agree with Mr Oettinger. We need to spend more on research, more on culture and education, on Erasmus+, more on the European Solidarity Service, and we need to provide fresh money for defence and not take it from the research programme. That's wrong. But we as Europe need to develop a common European defence policy worthy of that name in the face of Xi Jinping forever and the increase in China's military budget and the terrible Trump, who today also kicked out Secretary of State Tillerson. Now I come to the own resources. I have twice taken part in the negotiations on budgetary policy and the multiannual financial framework. We need new own resources. And this means above all a digital tax, because we are the need to ask digital monopolies for checkout. They have to pay taxes in Europe — i.e. Google, Facebook, Apple and Amazon. And we need a plastic tax. This is really a green, an ecological proposal by the Commissioner for Budgets. I support this, and these various measures will make it clear to citizens as a whole for the next elections: the EU will deliver, the EU understands the need of European citizens.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: rapporteur for the opinion, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. — Mr President, the future of the Union also depends on how we use the money or, first of all, on how we use the money. From the LIBE perspective, a few things are important. Firstly, the security of the Union and the security of every citizen of the Union. We need funds for security programmes, justice agencies, agencies that protect external borders, foreign and internal affairs agencies and, of course, those that protect human rights, to ensure balance and European values. Next, we need funds to stop false Russian propaganda, which is also used to influence national elections in many countries, including Member States, for breaking some countries and even breaking the Union. And that affects security very much - it is the biggest danger to the security of the Union. The rule of law - here I propose financial support for the Venice Commission, which, as we know, assesses the rule of law, the laws of justice in Member States and in candidate states. To stop crime and confiscate billions of euros or other stolen coins, we need a European Fund for the Protection of Independent Investigative Journalists, who find all these funds, find criminals, risk their lives, are blackmailed and die... (President interrupted speaker)

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, from the AFCO Committee a message: we believe that in the reform package institutional which is being discussed is essential to amend the current MFF procedure, bringing to an equal footing Parliament and the Council, which means Parliament with full power decision-making and Council by qualified majority voting. It is a subject of reform, but very important if we really want to have equality between our institutions. Secondly, I am addressing the Council and the Commission again: new challenges and new powers, in an orderly budget, must correspond to additional resources, resources which must not be taken from policies that tend to reduce inequalities between regions. Finally, I believe that we can reach our 1.3% which we are proposing, through additional own resources that are added to the contributions of the States, which must not decrease.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. — Mr President, Commissioner, the financial framework is the most powerful political instrument that exists to make the European Union's political priorities possible and real. That is why, although no reference has yet been made during this debate, I am sure that they share with me the need for this financial framework to have a woman's face. Because policies aimed at eradicating discrimination between men and women must be incorporated into European policy. Because it is also necessary to make the fight against gender-based violence a priority in European policy. Because it is necessary to consolidate, from European policy, public services that promote a balance between family and work life. Because it is necessary to make European policy a place where we can achieve the fundamental principle of equality between men and women. I hope you will not forget it, that we will not forget it in the work ahead, to make these financial perspectives a real political instrument that will make gender equality a reality in Europe too.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (PT) Mr President, I would like to congratulate you, greet you all, give a special word to the Commissioner for his competence and also for respect for timings, for his involvement in this matter and for working together with the European Parliament. It is extremely important that this post-2020 multiannual financial framework responds to the European Union's aspirations, ambitions and challenges. We want a more competitive European Union, a European Union that is more cohesive and, at the same time, more solidarity. Challenges are identified. Cohesion policy must continue, as well as the common agricultural policy, and we must strengthen research and innovation, Erasmus+, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, and youth should be a priority and therefore also strengthening the Youth Employment Initiative. We also have the challenge of security and defence, and it is therefore extremely important that the European Union budget is up to these objectives and these political priorities. 1.3% of gross national income is nothing special and it is a realistic proposal that we make. Furthermore, this funding must be achieved without burdening European taxpayers, European citizens, and therefore the proposal we are presenting is essential for this purpose, where, for example, the ECB's fines and profits can be used. (The speaker agrees to answer a question 'blue card' (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure. — Dear colleague, I agree with a lot of what you have said. Neither from what the Commissioner said, nor from the peer debate, it resulted in us thinking for the next period of the multinational financial framework for a budget and for the development of tourism, although tourism in Europe brings an impressive number of jobs, contributes to GDP. You think it is good that, at least from 2020, we have a budget line for tourism too. And did you think that the additional sources that were mentioned here were also from tax evasion? (President interrupted speaker)

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Blue card response. — (PT) It seems that it has been agreed, because I myself, with other Members, tabled a proposal that the next Multiannual Financial Framework should have a line for tourism, and in our report... (Due to the lack of interpretation, the speaker finishes the speech in English.) We do not have interpretation. We have a line for tourism in our proposal, in our report. That's in our report.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I understand that it was not a set-up, that was not agreed.  (Interjection from Mr Fernandes: ‘I can try again’) No, that’s fine, sorry, it was a misunderstanding. It was just that you said that it looks like a set-up, so I was saying to you it was not a set-up, I understand it is not a set-up.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you of course to the Commissioner for his report which he wanted to do to us this afternoon, for the work he is doing and that we will do for the next few months. We are discussing something really important, because we are drawing not only two documents of our European Union, but we are drawing the future of the European Union itself. These are documents, Parliament's own-initiative reports, and then the work that will be done by the Commission, which must give a new signal of Europe, a different signal. But in order to give a signal, an idea, a different image, there must also be different policies, that they are new policies and policies that give a vision and a future. There are two jobs we have focused on in these months, these weeks: one on the new financial framework and one on own resources. On the new financial framework, Mr Fernandes said earlier, and you said that, Commissioner, the 1.3% horizon we give ourselves is not a dream, is something that is widely achievable. I don't think this Parliament is an exose Parliament, it is a very responsible Parliament, I think. We know what people are asking for and we know what the answers we need to give, and we must be the added value for citizens and for our businesses, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, on huge issues such as research, such as development, such as young people, such as growth, the environment, energy, agriculture: it has already been remembered, they are the huge goals we have to give ourselves. For this we need additional resources. You said that they must not be additional but they must be parallel; I say they must be sufficient resources to make these policies: ambitious resources. We have to ask for less money from the Member States, you said it well, and I think it is very corrected. But in the document prepared by the rapporteurs, whom I thank, the rapporteur of both the own resources document and the rapporteur on the economic and financial framework, these resources are there, their identification is very clear, and we have identified the areas of work on which we need to work. But we must be very careful and we must give a very clear message to the citizens, so we do not want to raise taxes to citizens, we do not want to increase taxes to citizens, we do not want to increase taxes to citizens, we do not putting new taxes on citizens and not even small and medium-sized enterprises. What we want to do is to rearrange the EU's own resources system and have a fairer and fairer Europe on the financial system, a greener Europe, a Europe where transactions financial ones are finally taxed. I'll close, President, referring to the times. You said that we need — and we absolutely agree with you — we need to close these two documents within this mandate, the one on the new economic and financial framework and the one on the own resources, but we need to close these documents quickly, but to close them well too, because we need the answers that will be given to citizens and the prospects that citizens will have Since 2021 are really sufficient perspectives and answers, which are in abundance for the demands that businesses and the world of research, development, and the citizens themselves make to us.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. The new multiannual financial framework is the test of which EU we want to have in the future. More or less everyone here is talking about more subsidiarity, de-bureaucratisation and austerity. But the present draft does not correspond to this right now. And the previous speaker from the Socialists said that we need more money because we know how to boost the economy, we know how to make startups successful, and so on. My honourable colleagues, I do not believe that. I don't think we know this any better than the real leaders of companies. They know how to drive the economy forward. We should create the right framework conditions, but we should not collect money in the Member States and then redistribute it via Brussels. This is exactly the opposite of a lean EU. We should create space here. Debureaucratization starts with less regulation and no more. And if I want to regulate less, then I can't provide for more budgetary resources. I always have to wonder what I can actually achieve. First of all, it is quite clear that the EU budget is mostly a programme budget. And in a programme budget, the most natural thing in the world should be that the programmes should be reduced accordingly if a Member State leaves. But instead, it is proposed to increase Member States' contributions to gross national income by 30%. This is the opposite of a lean and economical EU. Citizens, however, want a lean and economical EU. That is why I would only call for new funds if we have a genuine political approach to resolving crises, for example in the area of migration, for example in the euro crisis. But the political will for this must first be defined. Instead, we see that now the funds for the former ESM should be transferred to its own budget line, a temporary element... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I would like to welcome the Commissioner's promising commitment and to pay tribute to our four rapporteurs. If we vote on the two own-initiative reports tomorrow, we will take the means of concluding with the Council before the end of this legislature, which will avoid the inertia we experienced in 2014 and 2015 and also reduce the tyranny of the fair return. That being the case, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we must keep a margin of flexibility. We see how difficult it has been during the implementation of the current multiannual financial framework to deal with certain crisis situations. Globalisation puts Member States face unprecedented challenges in terms of security, defence, migration, the digital economy, climate and the fight against globalized terrorism. We must prepare ourselves to take on these issues collectively because we have European common goods to defend, and it is clear that a number of States at national level are now unable to cope with these challenges. It should therefore be possible, Commissioner, in the aftermath of the European elections in 2019, if we have a majority, if the Member States agree, to go beyond 1, 1.1, 1.2 or 1.3. A European world power with a budget of 1.3 will not shudder the continental states, nor the multinationals of digital or financialisation. Therefore, it should be possible to transfer expenditure that was incurred at national level, to make it available to the European budget, and there, Commissioner, you will have the means to demonstrate what European added value is because we will be more efficient by putting national resources into the European budget. We will demonstrate that we can increase the European budget without increasing overall public expenditure in Europe. That is the wish I express.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, this Parliament has to send a clear message to the Commission and to the Member States concerning the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). If we want an ambitious EU, a Union that is able to deal with key challenges of our times and to deliver real outcomes in terms of progress, sustainability, equality and fundamental freedoms, then we need to reverse the downward trend in the amount spent by the EU, a trend that has been aggravated by the current MFF.  If we need to fight against growing populism and euroscepticism, the worst thing we could do would be to adopt proposals from populists and from eurosceptics, because with a small budget the European Union will be unable to deliver. Thus it would be even more meaningless to those many people who already don’t see what the EU is here for. In other words, to demonstrate the added value of the EU, we need to invest more and more efficiently in policies where the EU can really make a difference. This has to be the first key message to the Member States: Don’t use Brexit to make further cuts in our budget and diminish our ambitions.  Secondly, the next MFF needs to focus more on delivering results in sustainability and in the fight against climate change. The EU must translate its commitment to the Paris Agreement into a real budgetary majority. That’s why our Group stressed so much the importance of aligning the EU budget with the sustainable development goals and to significantly increase climate-related spending to reach at least the 30% target as soon as possible.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, we are gradually getting closer to this fateful moment when there is no longer any doubt about the budgetary future of the European Union. I think I don't take too many risks by saying that after 2020 we will continue to be locked in austerity logic. Doing more with less, spending better, smart budget cuts, are the only logic — agree, not very dynamic, anyway — that fuel the current negotiations and are already mourning European ambitions, your European ambitions, our European ambitions. In this context, the question we are asking ourselves, which concerns us, is 'Will this budget be the one of the beginning of the end of cohesion policy and the weakening of the CAP? ' I want to tell you that if it is on the back of cohesion policy that we intend to find the necessary resources to finance new priorities which are not, moreover, obligations of the Union, then you will find us on your way to denounce it.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Brexit, the referendums you lose throughout Europe, the Italian legislatures, none of these events seem to have reached the ivory tower in which you live. I say this because, at the top of this ivory tower, I see the Europeans gagas that you are asking for a larger European Union budget. I see you zealots of the European religion asking for a Europe of defence and a European army. I see you fanatized ideologists calling for the introduction of a European tax. But how do you have to tell you so that you can understand it? Your European Union, the people do not want it. The 24 languages of the European Union are not enough, do you have to tell you in Esperanto so that you deny listening to those who pay you generously? Actually, ladies and gentlemen, this week you are multiplying projects, all wilder than the other. But let us not be mistaken: this breath of heat is not one that announces the bright summers, but of those from which menopause are made. Your Union will disappear and, believe me, this event will be happily celebrated by the peoples.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that when we talk about the new multiannual financial framework and own resources, we must bear in mind two guiding principles. The first principle concerns no aggravation in contributions to Member States, especially not to increase the gap for states already contributing sharply to the European budget. And the second principle is taxes: we do not want new taxes coming from Europe and affecting European citizens, because the EU has no legitimacy in imposing new taxation. Unfortunately, I see that in the majority position on these two dossiers, these two principles risk not being respected. Member States are being asked for further effort, especially those already contributing in a major way to the EU budget, and new European taxes are hiding behind the name “resources” own”. The CO2 tax is a tax, the plastic tax is a tax, the financial transaction tax is a tax, and we know full well the ability that multinationals have in overturning additional costs that we impose on them on the end consumers. Unfortunately, from this point of view there will be a wider discussion, because the trend especially in the electoral rounds of European peoples and European citizens is that they want less Europe and more states members, and we in the budget have to take this into account.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the European Union has repeatedly used presentable and somewhat abstract terms to describe things that are in fact simple and clear: the Union is a set of administrative bodies. It cannot therefore have its own resources because it does not produce anything or offer paid services. What is described in the reports as Union resources is only revenue deducted from public budgets or drawn from the citizens of the Member States. VAT, for example, if it did not end up in the Union, or the States would have more revenue or, if they had deducted the amount that ends up in the Union altogether, citizens would have a significantly lower burden. Furthermore, whether the benefits offered by the Union correspond to the costs which both states and citizens have to pay is a question which these reports do not address and, above all, has never been asked to the citizens themselves. In the end, are the benefits such as to justify the maintenance of a huge bureaucratic mechanism? Could we have the same benefits with much smaller instruments of simple coordination between states and using the existing parallel state agencies at a much lower cost?

name: Alain LAMASSOURE
text: — Mr President, I congratulate the Commissioner and the rapporteurs. We are finally in the time of truth. No one can claim that with 1% of national income, it is possible to finance traditional European policies, decisions already taken on migration policy, climate change or defence, and future priorities for the 2020 years. The best proof is that the European budget has already exploded. To the small Community budget which remained taped at the level of twenty years ago, there is now a constellation of satellite budgets under various names. There is the old moon of the European Development Fund, there are four various emergency trust funds, two aid funds for Greece, the European Stability Mechanism, the Eurozone Lending Facility, the Juncker Fund, etc., and 2018 opens with the announcement of an impressive new satellite: the Defence Fund. Thus, the negotiations on the next financial framework will have a threefold stake: how much are we willing to allocate to financing European policies? How will we finance them, by what economies, by what new resources? How will democratic control, that is, parliamentary control be ensured? Let's at least dare ask the right questions.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, today we are facing one of the most important debates of the entire mandate, because we are talking about what Europe we want to build in the next decade. This is not only a budgetary debate, but above all a political debate, because where we put the resources will be the real priorities of the Union. In this legislature we have signed many far-reaching agreements: the Paris Agreement to combat climate change, the Gothenburg agreements for a true social pillar; we have even signed the Sustainable Development Goals. And it is now when we have to decide how we are going to finance them, and therefore it is now when we are going to demonstrate the degree of our commitment. In recent months, we are hearing great philosophical phrases when we talk about the budget — Mr Omarjee also said — some say that it needs to be modernised and, others, that more must be done with less. This may look very well on a headline, but this, budgetarily speaking, is not possible — more with less, it cannot be done — and that we want to modernise a budget does not mean that we can cut it down, but rather the opposite. And this Parliament has the very clear ideas of what we want for the future financial framework and we could define it in three blocks. The first block: maintaining the financing of traditional policies, i.e. agriculture and cohesion. We are asking our farmers and livestock farmers to produce with environmental criteria; to offer us quality products at affordable prices; to keep the population in rural areas and to encourage young people to enter the sector. And all this cannot be done with less budgetary support. And we also advocate a strong cohesion policy so that Europe continues to maintain competitiveness, so that its regions reduce inequalities, so that it is invest in innovation and, above all, to ensure that competitiveness is not at the cost of wages and social rights of workers. Second block: the policies that we might call 'for the future'. Here we not only want to maintain funding, but we want to increase Erasmus grants, research programmes or investment programmes. And the third block — and this is a very clear message —: new needs need a new budget; and we do not want to counterpose, as the Commissioner said, some priorities against the other. In conclusion, I would like to highlight two ideas which I hope the Commission will listen carefully. First proposal: the conditionality of funds with regard to compliance with the rules, because we propose a system of sanctions for those countries that do not comply with the rules or their commitments, but we completely detach these sanctions from the cohesion funds — municipalities, regions or the unemployed are not responsible for the fact that and second proposal: taking into account the Union's commitments in the fight against climate change, many European regions will have to make a radical energy and productive transition. The Union needs to help these regions, and we therefore propose a fair transition fund that emphasizes not only the regions but also on the social challenges of this transition. And how do we finance all this? It has already been said here: with new own resources; with taxes on sectors that do not now contribute to the public sector; with taxes on the financial sector; and taxes on large companies that take advantage of that there is no European regulation to evade their taxes. And I end, Mr President, because I really want to thank the four rapporteurs for the excellent work they have done, for the negotiation and for the generosity in negotiating, because in this way we can have a strong, supported agreement by most groups in this House.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! When taking the floor in this debate, I want to stress very strongly that the Polish delegation in the ECR group is in favour of filling the financial gap after Brexit and also providing additional resources for new EU priorities. In our view, premium charges may reach 1,3% of Member States' GNI. We postulate the elimination of all rebates in connection with the elimination of the UK rebate, the cessation of reimbursement of unused funds in a given year to individual Member States, the introduction of the UK's access to the EU market into the budget and, finally, possible establishing an EU financial burden in the form of a digital tax. It is necessary to ensure in the Union budget beyond 2020 at least at the previous level of cohesion policy and CAP measures. As part of the latter, we demand an end to the discrimination against agriculture of Central and Eastern European countries for nearly 15 years and the level of direct subsidies in new and old Member States. We strongly oppose making contributions from the future Union budget subject to compliance with the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty because it is impossible to establish any objective criteria in this regard. Even the existing conditionality for adherence to the discipline of public finances, although based on a hard, objective criterion, the so-called Maastricht criterion, is applied selectively by the Commission: for another six years France did not follow it and was never punished. consequences arising from the Stability and Growth Pact... (The Speaker has answered the Speaker) (The Speaker has agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jens GEIER
text: Question about the procedure for the 'blue card'. Mr Kuźmiuk, I have listened intensively to your speech. If I have understood you correctly, your position is quite the opposite of what Mr Kölmel said to your group a few minutes ago. My question to you is therefore: is there a coherent position of the European conservatives and reformers, or does it not exist?

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Indeed, there is no uniform position in the ECR group. As a Polish delegation, we are in favour of a decidedly larger budget, leveling both the post-Brexit gap and financing the additional priorities of the European Union. As it happens, there is no budgetary discipline in the ECR group for fundamental matters. The Polish delegation in this group is in favour of a bigger budget.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: – Mr President, there is not much that can be said about structural problems in the multiannual financial framework in one minute, but I will try. There is a very interesting study out there: ‘Economic Challenges of Lagging Regions’, and there is a case study in that study about Campania. Campania is the region around Naples. There is a saying about Naples – see Naples and then die. As soon as the cohesion funds come to Naples, they die.  Naples has been part of the system for sixty years, since the start of the regional and structural funds, and still today Naples is lagging behind. A normal person with normal intelligence and a person with normal intelligence in the Commission should probably understand that this form of structural funds doesn’t work. (The speaker continues to speak in German) Das geht nicht so weiter! Und ich glaube und ich hoffe, dass Kommissar Oettinger das ein wenig verbessert.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: On the other hand, I must say that there are other beautiful things about Campania which are definitely on the peak. But anyway, I think we understood the message.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw the Commissioner’s attention to one concern that my Group and I have. We saw last week a paper, probably leaked, that the Commission is planning to combine 12 external instruments into one. My question to the Commissioner is: do you have a proper impact assessment on what this means for attaining, for instance, development effectiveness goals? What does it mean for defending such wonderful, very focused, rather small instruments as the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights? What does it mean for the goals that we want to achieve through the instrument contributing to stability and peace? My concern is that this new idea, which I think to some extent seems to be a response to the need for flexibility, will be a big mistake. I understand that flexibility is needed, but I don’t think it should be done like this. I also believe that the European Parliament will lose a lot of its scrutiny rights if you do that.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: Mr President, with one minute, I will be straight and clear. We need a larger European budget, but which is not to the detriment of the Member States' fiscal capacity: they must be complemented. And we must also have progressive models on capital rents. We need more public resources, not less, to meet the challenges that are of concern to Europeans and Europeans, mainly unemployment, the environment, precariousness and poverty or tax fraud; the profits made from the fight against tax fraud would be an excellent source of income, together with new figures of eco-taxes or a tax on financial transactions. However, the priorities appear to be different. It seems to be more like strengthening Europe's strength and its militarisation, increasing or even doubling defence spending. We do not share these priorities set by the European Commission. The priorities should be other: employment policy, supporting small and small farmers, complying with international asylum legislation, and the sociological transition of our economies and regions. And to do this, we need a stronger, but above all fairer budget.

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I share some of the words spoken in this plenary by the speakers on the priorities of the forthcoming budget and the multiannual financial framework, namely unemployment youth, management of the migration phenomenon and also the fight against global warming. The problem is that, from my point of view, before asking for money still from the states, and therefore taxpayers, citizens, we should in some way first of all make a serious assessment of performance, and I am addressing you, Commissioner, who is a German and on this you should take full care of how the money of European taxpayers is spent, evaluate individually each individual program to see if this brings results and is efficient, and do an internal spending review before you still go to the states to ask for sacrifices, especially with the states they have right now difficulties in managing public finances, not just because of their own fault, as Mr Torvalds says from the top of his position as MP for Northern Europe. But there are internal imbalances in the eurozone, which should be resolved before we go, in fact, to ask for other resources and manage these budgetary issues. So the heads of state on this need to find a solution or the situation risks a total implosion precisely because unemployment and demand problems cannot be solved only by a European budget which has a very low budget. And on our own resources, here too, we cannot have new taxes, because European citizens do not want new taxes, they want financial speculation to be taxed, rightly, they want them to be taxed You tax large multinationals, but they do not want to charge them with additional burdens that some bureaucrats here in Brussels have in mind. So we absolutely have to find a square, obviously facing the citizens, and not as usual towards the big bearers of interest.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: — Mr President, the remarks made earlier by Isabelle Thomas in the introduction are indicative of the failure of the European Union, since our colleague referred to an undersized budget, characterised by — I quote it — 'a lack of ambition and seriousness, and even a budgetary powerless'. Considering that European policies are ineffective for jobs, growth and purchasing power, considering that the Member States' financial leeway — which you have dieted — are reduced, common sense is that the European Union should concentrate exclusively on its CAP and on cohesion policy and that Brexit, elsewhere, is reflected in a decrease in EU spending. You are proposing the opposite by asking the Union to absorb new prerogatives such as security and defence. Under no circumstances should these two functions be transferred to the Union; they must of course remain within the framework of the Member States. Moreover, to finance this delusional federalism, you even go as far as to punctuate 2% of VAT revenues or even invent other new taxes. Therefore, before imposing austerity on the peoples of Europe, the European Union imposes it on itself.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, the next Multiannual Financial Framework should reflect the political priorities which we expect from the Union in the next decade. It should be a balance between traditional priorities on the one side and new priorities on the other side. Traditional priorities – agriculture and cohesion policy – continue to be important, because they are about rural development and food security, and cohesion is about competitiveness. It is about helping the least developed regions of the Union. To these traditional priorities, new priorities are being added. The citizens of Europe expect us to do more on security, defence, tackling the migration crisis and combating terrorism. If, at the end of the day, we expect the Union to do more, it is not normal to offer it a smaller budget. Commissioner, we also have to stand together in the negotiations with the Member States and the Council and tell them that, if we expect a more robust Union which has more tasks, then a smaller budget is not realistic. We have to spend money well, and we have to update and modernise our policies, reform them and convince citizens that the money is well spent, but at the end of the day, new competences also mean a robust budget. We have to tell those Member States who are concerned that paying more does not mean that you are in a worse situation. If the Union is to do more and if we are also to contribute more, then it means that we will also receive more in terms of security, combating terrorism and everything that the citizens expect. This is in the interest of all the governments of the Union.  Just to conclude, one sentence on timing. Commissioner Oettinger, we will vote on Parliament’s position tomorrow and then you will make the proposal at the beginning of May. The Parliament, our team, will be ready to negotiate. Commissioner, please stand together with us in Parliament in negotiations with the Council to convince them that, the sooner we adopt the next MFF, the better. The Council should not adopt the next MFF when it is politically convenient for them, but when it is good for the beneficiaries in the Member States – for farmers, students, researchers and young unemployed people. The sooner we adopt it, the better for the beneficiaries.  (Applause) (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: A blue card question addressed to Congressman Siegfried Mureşan. Thank you, too, for accepting my question. I did not quite understand in your view the reduction in the share of agricultural and cohesion money, but does it also mean a decrease in the amount of money in the light of a larger budget? My view is that they should not be reduced in amounts.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Szanyi, my position is the following: we have to start these complicated discussions with setting the political priorities. We should not start by speaking about the amount, because if we start by speaking about the amount, every participant in the negotiations will want to pay as little as possible and to receive as much as possible. Then the discussions will be divisive, difficult and inconclusive. Firstly, we should find a political common denominator on what we want to achieve with regard to the budget, and only afterwards should we speak about the precise amounts in absolute terms or in relative terms.

name: Jens GEIER
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. We are faced with a very important decision for the future of the European Union. Because — as we say in Germany, a budget is a policy cast in figures. And what is the point now: what policy should this European Union pursue in the years 2021 to 2027 and how do we intend to finance it in the end? Here we are also waiting for feedback from the Member States so that they can finally tell us which Union they really want, and then hopefully also provide us with the necessary resources for this. It is good if we create regulations here in this House to implement the EU's policy objectives. But these objectives must ultimately also be reflected in EU spending. This is no less important. The withdrawal of the United Kingdom is declining revenue and some Member States and, as we have also heard, some Members of this House believe that, as a result, expenditure should also fall. In view of the divorced tasks assigned to us not least by the Member States, the question arises: do more with less money? This can be done at best in LalaLand or perhaps in interviews in Scandinavian, Dutch or Austrian newspapers — and since I am shown a blue card, and certainly in British — but not in European reality. Unless, Mr. Oettinger, you have the famous gold donkey from the fairy tale of the Brothers Grimm in the basement, which eats straw in the front and leaves gold on the other side. But since this is probably not the case, the question is: how will we finance all this in the future? Frontex — this agency is to be converted into a genuine border management agency, the European Defence Research Fund is called for, we need the European Employment Agency to: finally being able to monitor compliance with the Posting of Workers Directive. We want to increase mobility for young people, we want to do more to tackle the causes of flight, and in research policy, the EU can only really fund every seventh promising research project. There is a lack of money in front and back. I could continue this list. If all this is wanted, where are we going to take the money for it? Therefore, if we want to have a strong Europe, then this can only be done with more resources, either from national budgets or — which I would support — with new European Union own resources. Let's start with this work! (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for accepting the blue card. You mentioned the reduction in revenues following Brexit. Would it not be sensible for you to be looking at actual reductions in the scope of the ambition of this Union, to suit the new financial reality that will come from the – far less – revenue you will get following Brexit, rather than seeking to continue to be all things to all men, even when you know that the money is going to run out?

name: Jens GEIER
text: Answer to a question about the 'blue card' procedure. — Mr Etheridge, you obviously just waited for a catchword and then stopped listening to me, because that is exactly the point I developed further. It is up to the Member States which EU we have here. I can imagine a lot. I can imagine — and I am probably in the minority in my group — that we renationalise agricultural policy and then only have competition rules so that we do not coordinate to death. I can imagine anything. I can also imagine the tenfold increase in Erasmus so that more young people have experience abroad. You can do anything. Only the Member States have to decide which EU they really want to have. My point is: wanting to do more, pay less money for it and collect as much as you got before — you really can't do that now.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: — Mr President, discussing the EU's financial framework should take into account the effects of Britain's EU difference on Union revenues and, in the same respect, tighten the belts. In order to deal with the decline in revenues without significantly undermining the achievement of targets within the MFF, focus should be on areas and projects with clear European added value, i.e. those where action at European level can substantially improve results compared to national level actions. Such as measures to reduce air pollution, such as fine particulate matter, basic science research, or the promotion of roboticisation that reduces health and elderly care problems. Getting immigration under control is also the best security policy in the Member States, as well as the best social and civilisation policies. Funding orientation should be based on non-financial impact assessments. Preference assessments should clearly list the assumptions on which assessments are based and impact assessments should be transparent and open to criticism.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, honourable Members, first of all, I would like to congratulate the authors of the reports on the fact that they have succeeded in preparing the European Parliament with a position and a timely position so that we can also enter into negotiations with the Council and support the European Commission in the expected a proposal for the multiannual financial framework. It is extremely important that these reports draw attention to the need to reach the “added value” element of the investments of the European budget of the European financial framework. Complementarity and combination of financial lines can lead to higher efficiency and would allow for flexibility in the future implementation of the financial framework. I would like to stress that this flexibility can also be achieved by attracting additional private resources and the combination of public and private resources in the future. The clear link between the European Semester and the financial framework of the European Union would provide the balance needed in future implementation.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, I really fear the outcome that you can already see being sketched. Coming from the Netherlands, I have a prime minister who is saying ‘oh yes, I want to make the budget future—oriented, but mainly there needs to be less money’. What I feel here is that people are saying ‘yes, we want to make the budget future—oriented but maintain the policies on the two big spending blocks, on agriculture and cohesion.’ I can tell you what will come out of those negotiations: it will be less money but maintaining the same old policies that we have right now. Then all the people that are critical of the EU will have a free—for—all day to criticise that outcome. Therefore, I also plead to this House to focus on what it wants on the contents. Focus on modernisation, on really making the EU budget future-oriented, on really making agriculture green and on making it deliver sustainable food. Look at the infrastructure to really connect us Europeans, really go for innovation, really fight youth unemployment. Then we can talk about future-oriented policies: otherwise, it will be less of the same.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. It is a question of how to compensate for a Brexit budget gap, but the essence of the question is: what is the future of the European Union? Will it be a Europe of solidarity where the approximation of living conditions is a top priority? If we translate this into the debate on the financial framework, the existing concrete solidarity instrument, cohesion policy, must be strengthened. I finally expect the Commission to make clear and unambiguous statements on this, rather than ever new reduction scenarios. We are calling for no reduction in the Structural Funds, no use of subsidies for sanctions and certainly not for armaments. No region must fall out of the support policy altogether. A responsibility, however, also lies with the national governments, because their sparideology has only ever exacerbated all crises. Cloudly calling for solutions from the EU in Brussels and blocking ways at home in the Member States, whether it is the transaction tax or other revenue changes, will permanently prevent investment in a fairer, more social, sustainable and peaceful Europe of coexistence.

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I can hardly believe that we disagree on what the EU's next budget should look like. After Brexit, there can be no more two opinions. The EU budget does not need to increase, as is being discussed here, but it must of course become smaller. The EU loses its third largest net contributor. The UK has contributed almost €40 billion net over the past five years, which is €8 billion net per year. Instead of cutting the budget, you are now also asking for EU taxes on plastic and diesel, plus higher taxes from the Member States. That really leaves me speechless. Are you sure you want to tell your constituents? If not, I'll be happy to take care of this. We have a clear and sensible alternative, which is to radically collapse the EU budget. No EU army, a radical reduction of the Cohesion Fund, a significant reduction of agricultural subsidies, these departments of the Commission close accordingly. Then we will have enough money — good Mr Geier, because you say what you need to have more money for — to continue feeding, for example, meaningful projects like Erasmus. You can easily save the money twice by cutting the nonsensical subsidies. Citizens simply have had enough of this remote EU. Listen to the citizens, otherwise you will soon see Servus to be called to the EU elsewhere.

name: André ELISSEN
text: Mr President, the main line of the proposals is that the multiannual budget must go up considerably, because of Brexit, sky-high ambitions and shady deals with Turkey, Libya and staff. That means that the Member States will have to pay more. In order to prevent the Netherlands from being affected, I have tabled the following amendments. The net paying countries are being called on not to pay any more euro than they are currently doing. And the current annual rebate for the Netherlands should be maintained. My party's position is clear: the Netherlands should not pay more, but much less to the failed EU project. When Prime Minister Rutte has balls, he is finally using his right of veto to torpedoate this multiannual budget. Finally, Mr President, it is scandalous that Juncker has messed up his official Selmayr. As far as we are concerned, this Commission should be sent home as soon as possible. Then the multiannual budget can also go directly to the trash.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Madam President, I do not know if I only have this sense of déjà vu when I listen to this debate, or if other colleagues have it. A colleague of Geier didn't talk, a colleague from the Netherlands, about wanting to increase the budget. He didn't say he wanted more money from the Netherlands. He talked about the fact that we need to look for our own resources to finance the European Union. When we look for our own resources, that means we will want less money from the Member States. If we don't listen to each other here and make political proclamations, this debate is absolutely pointless. Who have you experienced this debate about own resources here, so you know that it has been conducted here for four years in a very open spirit. Always that debate slides to the fact that we chop at some point, whether it's supposed to be an eco-tax or it's supposed to be a tax on some services, transactions and so on, but everyone's Finally, we agree that the European Union should be less dependent on the income of individual Member States. I'm not in favor of, like you said, colleague, raising the budget mindlessly. Siegfried Mureşan said here that the money here has to be used effectively and that's what this debate is about. We here are not talking about replacing the income of the UK with some income from the other member states after the UK shows. We are discussing here today what way we will find and that way should be long-term. We do not address the perspective of five years, but the perspective far longer. I'm sorry my speech was longer.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the four rapporteurs and say that in the face of the expectations of the citizens, faced with the risks that have appeared since Brexit, we must understand that the new MFF has a great political value. I think it is important, on the other hand, to finally activate the own, but additional, not just replacement, resources of national funds, although national funds, as some governments have anticipated, can co-finance cohesion more, provided that investment is taken away from the Stability Pact. But we can finally adopt taxes on financial transactions, the web tax, and thus not necessarily taxing citizens, but the large aggregations that often evade not only taxes, but also evade the recognition of intellectual work, as in the field of digital. We must, however, identify — the rapporteur in particular is right — the strategic priorities. The two sides in my opinion are young people and culture. We demonstrate every day how much investment in young people brings great hope to Europe, but also in the future and sustainable development. True, we have called for a tripling of the Erasmus funds. We would like to reach ten times as much, because today only 5% of young people can use this important tool, including for their future and work. And we also ask to be more courageous in cultural policies, investment in the European resource that is cultural heritage and cultural and creative enterprises. It seems to us that they are still too marginal in public debate.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: — Madam President, 1%, 1.05%, 1.1%, 1.2%, the enumeration of these few ratios is not intended to introduce us into homeopathy or nanoscience, but it is the quantified options that reflect the maximum that some Member States deign to give to the budget of the European Union. The multiannual financial framework is supposed to prepare for the future of our continent, we want more border security, more internal security, consolidate the cohesion of Economic and Monetary Union, more resilience to crises, more fight against inequalities, more investment to drive growth, make Erasmus accessible to a greater number of young people is very good to want, but you also need to be able to do so. We know that Commissioner Oettinger has many qualities, but he is not Santa Claus. Who is benefiting from the refusal to equip the European Union with the means it needs to meet the challenges to which I have just referred? To the populists, of course. They want the return to Europe of the nineteenth century. I would not want to be said in 30 years that the downgrading of the European states began around the years 2015-2025 because the political class at the time would not have been able to go beyond the low budget and other apothecary accounts. Commissioner Oettinger, our rapporteurs and the valiant chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Affairs, Jean Arthuis, who are very aware of the current issues, deserve to be supported with a little more conviction and fervour in the cause they are pleading with great talent.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President! We welcome the maintenance of funds for agriculture and rural development, provided that we are able to meet the key challenges of our time. We will not be able to meet the Paris climate targets if we do not greentialise European agriculture. We will not be able to sustain jobs in rural areas if we cut all the money for rural development and agriculture. We will not be able to save European biodiversity if we do not greensise European agriculture. That is why I call on you to maintain agricultural budgets only on condition proper greening of agriculture. A word about the additional revenue: something like kerosene taxation has long been around. I do not see why a train ticket here to Strasbourg or Brussels costs significantly more than a ticket. Such a tax can only be levied transnationally. The same applies to a financial transaction tax. Or do we want to wait for the next financial crisis, when we should know better?

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Madam President, the Multiannual Financial Framework is proof of the nine concerning the real political intentions of the European Union. Portugal has diverged from the European Union average. Wages in Portugal over the last fifteen years have fallen by more than 2%, while wages in Germany have increased by almost 3%, and this is the result of the current financial framework, where cohesion funds have already been cut substantially compared to the previous picture. So what we want is a strengthened multiannual financial framework, with more cohesion-oriented resources, and not a security and defence budget. In other words, our choice today is whether we really want a Europe of solidarity, a Europe of peace, a Europe of cohesion, or whether we want a fortress Europe, a militarised and increasingly warmongering Europe.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Madam President, cut your coat to suit your cloth; spend to suit your income. The anti-logic of this place rejects sound and sane economics. Instead, you look to ever more desperate ways to squeeze the taxpayer until the pips squeak. Interference in Member State tax systems, introduction of new EU-wide taxes, abolition of national vetoes. In short, spend, spend, spend and spend again.  Soon, reality will hit. The truth is that sooner or later you will run out of other people’s money. The time will come when the grand ideas of this project will be unaffordable, and this will reach even this place. Some reality is starting to come through now, but when the real truth of financial sanity really hits you, that will be the end of this place and this project.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger. At €14 billion, the UK's exit from the EU is tearing a huge hole that will not be easy to plug. After all, we are talking about 10% of own resources with a financial envelope of around EUR 1000 billion. In addition, there are new policy priorities in the areas of security policy, the fight against terrorism or migration, which are worth adding to the budget. The MFF 2027 is therefore a major challenge on both the revenue and expenditure sides. In the last financial framework, around 72% of the budget was allocated to the common agricultural policy and the Structural Funds. There may be cuts here, and the first resistance is already stirred. In addition, there are two programmes which are not sensibly intended to be cut, and these are Horizon 2020 and Erasmus +. Programming lines such as COSME and the Connecting Europe Facility are also important drivers for growth and jobs. Of course, there is resistance from net contributors on the revenue side. Parliament has earmarked a share of 1.3% here. A group of five European net contributors, including Austria, has already opposed an increase in net contributions and against a linear update of the budget. They are therefore faced with a difficult task, because without massive savings and a reform of own resources, it will not be possible to ensure sustainable financing of the EU budget, while at the same time launting all those projects and programme lines that are politically desired and which are actually a European European budget. Add value.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - Madam President! The safety of our citizens is among the EU's priorities. Let us remember that to its core form is food security, which has been achieved through the Common Agricultural Policy. The CAP is one of the first policies fully funded by EU funds. The determination of the level of funding of the CAP requires an analysis of the state of the situation in agriculture. Most member countries lack young farmers. Aging farmers follow. Where are the causes? That the income of farmers on average amounts to only 50% of the income of other professional groups, half of which are EU funds. If we don't provide adequate resources for agriculture, then there will be an intensifying collapse, a bankruptcy of farms. The model of European agriculture, environmentally friendly agriculture that meets high standards and standards will disappear. Agriculture also fits into a number of new challenges — renewables are improving energy security, climate — and gives new jobs. Agriculture is the production of a range of raw materials for industry, as well as the production of various public goods related to the environment and climate.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, budgetary choices must not be made, cannot be made — as we all know — to the detriment of food security issues and its corollary, food sovereignty. Yes, Europeans are changing in their consumption patterns, and yes, production patterns must evolve even more to guarantee the 500 million Europeans a healthy diet, synonymous with good health for today and for tomorrow. Yes, agriculture must evolve to be an actor of the climate issue, but also migration. Yes, agriculture must preserve our soil, our air, our water. But in order to change agricultural practices, the first and foremost need to secure farmers' incomes, and to do so, the CAP budget must be maintained, like that of cohesion. We cannot ask the agricultural world to change by removing the resources dedicated to the time when, in other continental states, the means given to agriculture and food are progressing. Thank you, Commissioner, for helping us convince the Council of the need for an ambitious budget.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, the name of the EU budget, the Multiannual Financial Framework, makes it seem that we are talking about something really technical, but in fact this Multiannual Financial Framework is deeply political and it will give us the possibility either to build a European Union for the future, based on values and principles, or to go back to the past. That is why the MFF should address the shrinking space for civil society that we are observing all over the European Union. Because human rights defenders have to be able to count on us. Faced with Donald Trump and with Vladimir Putin, the European Union is the stronghold of fundamental rights and values, and that is why, dear Commissioner, as well as keeping up the good work of, for example, the EU’s human rights instruments, we should also, within the European Union, create a fund to defend the rule of law and fundamental rights in the EU itself. The MFF is direly needed. We need it to build a Europe for the future.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as an Italian Member, I say no to the possibility of adding more taxes to Italian citizens. That is, no to other European taxes, no to the madness of continuing to feed the European carriage with taxes. Today if resources need to be recovered, resources must be recovered where Europe throws resources. This venue, the dual headquarters is an example of this, the waste we have seen to fund Turkey, the waste we have seen to fund the culinary culture of insects! Here, it is unthinkable to continue with this criminal direction. Look, in this vessel is depicted a family: a mom, a dad and a child. As you can see, the level of tax pressure in Italy drowns out Italian families. The child drowned, the chance to make children drowned in our country. Then we cannot think that in such a drastic situation, so dramatic, so terrible, other taxes are added which are what you see as European ones, that is other European taxes. they would obviously harm Italian families. Italian families in Sunday's election called for one simple thing: take taxation to 15%, reduce the level of taxation to 15% to give breath to children and families.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Madam President, I welcome Commissioner Oettinger and thank and congratulate all the rapporteurs and colleagues who have worked on the opinions on these two reports. Four are the main messages. First, the EU budget is really too small and we cannot solve all the challenges we face with it. The second message is that this is precisely why we need a lot more coordination and synergy with Member States' budgets. The third message is that cohesion and agricultural policies are key because they strengthen the single market, benefiting from all, the most developed Member States, which are also net payers to the EU budget. And fourth: with this message I join my colleague Mureşan, who pointed out that our goal must be as fast as possible agreement and adoption of the budget as quickly as possible if we want to have the implementation of the budget on time.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President! The same unworthy spectacle year after year: Member States would prefer to cut their contributions to the MFF and, at the same time, they demand that the European Union take on more tasks, such as the defence union. The time has come to say that if we can organise our defence at European level, then we can also organise a genuine European budget of our own, and this budget includes more own resources. Let's say the evil word: Own resources. New own resources for the European Union — it doesn't hurt to say the word. But own resources are not an end in themselves, they are not an omnipotence fantasy of pro-Europeans. They would break down the paralysing MFF process, they would be more efficient, they would be more effective, they would relieve national budgets and they would turn the EU budget into a real, European budget. They would ensure that we have more money for converging living conditions, that we have Erasmus, that we can fight youth unemployment, that we can bring to an end the digital transformation that is more than air taxis and broadband expansion. From here today, the signal must be sent to the Heads of State and Government: Europe must be worth more to us. I would immensely wish this message arrived.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: ). — Madam President, asking more and more of the European Union, to want more citizens to believe in it, and at the same time talking about reducing budgets is as if we were to break through the tank of a car and at the same time expect it to move forever. To be honest with each other and with the people watching us. Having a good road, a refurbished school and more jobs is not just a value of the new Member States. This is something that all people, all citizens from every country of the European Union want. And if that's a common goal and a common good, we need common activities. We need good funding for them. The main message today from this House must be that there is no longer eastern or western Europe, there is no northern or southern Europe. There is only one Europe and this is a united Europe. We need strong cohesion for her. The short-term solution: let's cut funds there because of Brexit, where people will least feel it. And the long-term solution: genuine own revenues that do not depend on Member States' contributions.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, the exemplary report before us makes the stark conclusion that the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) quickly proved its inadequacy to meet actual needs and political ambitions. It was pushed to its limits after only two years. There must be no repetition of the situation post-2020 or the Union will further slip into terminal existential crisis. Additional priorities, such as defence, should not be financed at the expense of solidarity.  Today, the Commission is presenting its so-called Social Fairness Package. This and the social pillar cannot remain toothless statements. There must be all the necessary resources for, among other things, a real child guarantee – overturning the paradox of a Union of riches with children in poverty – and, not least, resources for an upgraded European Social Fund able to foster social investment by also blending with financial instruments where appropriate and feasible.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: — Madam President, I am firmly convinced that, in order to be able to succeed with the new multiannual financial framework, we must aim for a more social, more efficient, safer, stronger Europe.
