In order to achieve this, I must say that we have to put forward specific policies that respond to the present and future of Europe, and these policies must be: firstly, the strengthening of all programmes and policies for our young people, because that is the only way we can Europe has a future and perspective; secondly, to do what we all constantly demand and demand, genuine equality between men and women; thirdly, to support social cohesion; fourthly, to implement policies that support small and isolated countries, such as Malta and Cyprus, which are disadvantaged on specific issues; fifthly, to implement an integrated defence and security policy that really safeguards the dignity of the European Union itself by safeguarding its borders and safeguarding the Member States; sixth, we must strengthen energy policy by supporting the energy reserves and natural wealth of all countries; seventh, to further strengthen our countryside, which is essentially what boosts the country's production; eighth, we must — and finally — strengthen our small and medium-sized enterprises. businesses and dynamically enter the new digital age. Only in this way will we really have a Europe of the future, which meets the demands of the people and the citizens as well.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: Madam President, dear Commissioner, we have a very important debate today which will mark the future of the European Union, because we need to expand and improve the European Union's own resources. And, within this own resources package, these reports point to the need for the European Central Bank's benefits to contribute to the euro area budget, which also contribute to the construction of that fiscal pillar throughout the euro area as a whole. It's a useful instrument. It is an instrument that could contribute around EUR 1 billion a year. An instrument which also does not have a tax nature, we would not be asking European citizens to have a greater tax burden. There are no taxes behind this own resources channel. Moreover, an aggravated reform of the Treaties would not be needed, as the House itself said, the legal advice of this House itself. We need to value membership in the euro. We need to dignify the euro. Parliament and the Commission are united on this path and the Council must listen.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Madam President, the forthcoming financial perspectives are very important for many regions and citizens. European funding has played a crucial role in the common agricultural policy and also in strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion. It has to remain crucial. We cannot disappoint our citizens and give arguments to anti-Europeans and populists. All Member States must therefore make an effort in this future financial framework, so that our farmers, livestock farmers and fishermen continue to be taken care of by European funding and also for cohesion policies to advance. I will mention some concrete challenges that require European funding: from demographic decline and the Erasmus+ programme to security and defence; also, research and innovation; also, strengthening borders and helping neighbouring and sub-Saharan countries to achieve stability and well-being that avoid the illegal immigration. The challenges, ladies and gentlemen, are many. European funding is essential. For this funding, the effort of all Member States is essential, all the more so now that the British contribution will be missing due to Brexit.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union needs a multiannual budget to meet the global challenges we face together, and that is why we need adequate own resources. The EU and its Member States continue to be the world's leading donor of development aid, and it is essential that the new multiannual budget lives up to the commitments made over the five years. Let's face the truth: the world has already changed much since the new sustainable development goals were adopted, the Addis Ababa agenda, the Paris Agreement, with big players parading. Either the EU will be able to lead and example in the implementation of these objectives, or they will remain on paper. Well simplification of financial instruments, but only in full compliance with the principles of policy coherence, transparency, and aid effectiveness, and keeping separate the specific instruments for the development and humanitarian aid. Trust funds are acceptable only for specific objectives, limited duration, with proven added value. Their use should not change the original objectives of the instruments which, as regards cooperation, must be primarily the eradication of poverty and certainly not to block migration flows. Last, let's realize: we need long-term investment in development to overcome global challenges, otherwise they won't lose others, we will all lose.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: — Dear colleagues! Mr Oettinger! This will be the first MFF when we first talk about what we want to do, and then look for ways to implement it. The most important thing for people is security, so it is necessary to find means to protect and control the external borders. Then Schengen will also function fully. Additional funding needs to be found for youth programmes, science, small and medium-sized enterprises, i.e. strengthening our competitiveness. People want to live better across the European Union, so cohesion policy needs to equalise the different levels of the economies of the Member States. Infrastructure is essential here. We must not forget the Connecting Europe Facility, including Rail Baltica. Our future is an environmentally friendly and resource-saving economy, so special attention is paid to new technologies and research. Member States' funding for the common agricultural policy is too different, so work needs to be continued to equalize these disparities, but to fill the shortfall resulting from Brexit, Member States' contributions need to be increased and new own resources must be accepted by saving administration costs .

name: Ivo BELET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I think we can say that Europeans are right to expect the European Union to work on security, social protection, defence and climate action, of course. People expect the European Union to protect them and all of us in all these respects and invest in European projects with very clear European added value. For this — we may say that — additional resources are needed. These could come from, among other things, the additional income from the growing revenues of the Emissions Trading Scheme, as we in the Committee on the Environment have also proposed. That is not to say, ladies and gentlemen, that we cannot save smart. Of course we can, and of course we must, but we must not fool people. Saving on cohesion funds, for example, means less than 250 million per annum in our region, in Flanders. That's what we can say to the people. We can also say that we must denounce those who proclaim fake news — those who say that Europe has not set its priorities and that we are spending too much money — and that the masks can finally fall.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: — Madam President, this is indeed one of the most important debates of this mandate, because we are precisely setting priorities for the next Multiannual Financial Framework. The European Parliament has drawn up and presented its priorities. We have done our job and tomorrow we will adopt compromises that essentially reflect the aspirations of the European citizens we represent. I therefore ask the Commission to accept, recognise and present, as early as May, a budget that is strong and consistent with this position, with the position of this Parliament. I would like to take this moment to make two highlights, two major priorities, which I would ask the Commission to pay particular attention to. The next multiannual financial framework has and must clearly include, in the post-2020 period, a strengthening of cohesion policy, especially in line with what is the new strategy for the outermost regions. We are talking about maintaining specific derogations for support in transport, fisheries, POSEI Fisheries, also in agriculture, in strengthening for young people and also for small and medium-sized enterprises. Finally, we specify the creation of a specific line for tourism, which is a very important sector and which we advocate and want the Commission to follow.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, there will be no more Europe with fewer resources. There will be no more social cohesion or territorial structure if we cut cohesion funds, if we cut the common agricultural policy or fisheries funds, as important for regions as mine, Galicia. New challenges, such as climate change, innovation or depopulation, will not be able to face with increasingly diminating resources. And we will not overcome inequality, that gap that has opened up with the crisis and which has led to many parts of the European Union rather than converging to have diverged, if we are not able to increase the budget. There are formulas to increase the budget: there is the financial transaction tax, there is the eco-tax, there are the benefits of the European Central Bank — as has just been stated. More resources to meet this great objective, which is to make more European construction, a more social, more cohesive and more territorial vertebrate Europe. That is the great challenge that we have to face with the new financial perspectives.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, there is no greater impediment to the creativity of an economy, no more destructive force to social cohesion in a nation, and no greater threat to the future of Europe than the fear and reality of unemployment. It is with a great deal of pride that I can support the priority my group is giving to combating unemployment, particularly youth unemployment, in the next MFF. We need, Commissioner Oettinger, the programmes that the European Union runs in this area to be effective and to be properly taken up.  The priority is indeed jobs, but the priority is also the transformation of the economy through investment in knowledge, technology, innovation, investment, science and research, because the old economy that we have will not do. It will not deliver the jobs that those young people need. If the future of Europe is the future of freedom, then it is also the future of hope for the next generation.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, the cohesion policy behind 2020 has been called into question, at least in the form in which it exists today. I agree with the rapporteurs that it should remain the main investment policy of the Union because without reducing the differences in development between the members we cannot have a fully functioning single market. As long as there is an obvious difference in development, there will also be perceptions that more developed states use the poorer ones and profit on them. Such perception necessarily leads to dissatisfaction and distrust, and a stable Union cannot be built on this. Cohesion policy must exist and strengthen, but also remain focused on what it is most successful at. That is why I cannot support the establishment of a European Fund for Democracy from which to invest in civil society, because there are much more effective ways to achieve cohesion goals. Linking asylum, migration and integration policies with cohesion policy is also not a good proposition because a broader focus on issues around which there is no consensus, which is detrimental to cohesion policy itself.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, what strikes me this afternoon is that we have not talked at all about how we can use European money efficiently, what choices we make and that we are making sure that our taxpayers' money is sparing. Don't get me wrong. I am very much in favour of a strong European Union, and I believe that we should invest so that we continue to do so in the future. What I am against is the automatic reflex of this Parliament to say that we need more money, without looking at where savings can be made. For every household, every company and also the national parliaments, it is very clear that they have to make choices. If we want to spend more money somewhere else, we need to go somewhere else and see where we can take the money away. I am sorry that we are saying here, in this House, that everything must remain the same and that we need fresh and new money. And not a little bit, no, as much as 30%. Where, please, is this discussion about whether we should not modernise our policies in this changing world and whether we should not be critical of how we spend European money?

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, at the bottom of this debate is the Europe that we have and the Europe we want to have. It is therefore important to clarify that the so-called net contributors have benefited most. Those who contribute must know that their taxes favour the concentration of wealth. The European funds did not achieve the development of the countries on their economic periphery, but have dismantled their productive fabric in the name of modernisation. This has happened in Galicia, with agriculture, fisheries or the naval sector, for example. The funds secured the occupation of the markets of the periphery countries, while ensuring that investment in infrastructure responds to the interests of European capital and its elites. Now that they have the goals achieved, they say we are already developed. What irony! When our youth emigrate again to be able to live. Of course, now they need the funds to try to do the same in other countries. Commissioner, so far there has been no solidarity. We need to change the priorities of the funds.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: — With European Union funding, we pursue common European objectives. A well-functioning European Union benefits all members. This must be said aloud and taken into account in European budget debates. Thus, we will provide sufficient resources for traditional challenges such as the internal market, agricultural and cohesion policy, which are also of great importance for Slovenia. Security and defence of external borders are key among the new challenges, because without that all of our four fundamental freedoms are at risk. In the current system of national contributions, the European focus is lost in national desires. The European Union thus remains a marionette, rather than being the main player, who is no longer children at his sixties, whose parents should dose pocketry. The UK's exit is an ideal opportunity to achieve the objectives of the Treaty of Rome on funding the European Union through its own resources. The European budget needs a reform of its own resources system. The High Level Group for Own Resources has prepared reports that the European Commission should examine as soon as possible.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: — Madam President, we are currently at a time when external propaganda, along with the populist trend, is constantly attacking both the competences and the credibility of the European institutions, and an effective and effective solution is to get closer to European citizens. When debating the multiannual financial framework, it is essential to set budgetary priorities in a manner directly proportional to the expectations of European citizens and, beyond migration and terrorism, the economic theme is a priority theme for our citizens. I support the continuation and strengthening of key programmes: the research programme, COSME, Erasmus +. We need more additional resources, in addition to potential new own resources, increased contributions from Member States, but also greater flexibility. However, I would like to draw attention to the fact that we must continue to support the cohesion funds, because both cohesion policies and agricultural policies are a fundamental binder of European construction, and they benefit an extremely important number of European citizens.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. We have listened and written down intensively over the last two hours and will evaluate all your arguments, speeches, expectations, but also your criticism and will include them in the further process of preparing a draft MFF by 2 May. In particular, I would like to pay my respects to those who, like me, have been and have remained present from the beginning to the end: Mr Arthuis, the chairman of the committee, colleagues Thomas, Lewandowski, Deprez and Olbrycht. Because I believe that the overall picture of all speeches is important. Why do I say this? You can't get a budgetary framework if you give your own opinion, but you don't see that democracy needs a majority or even unanimity. I need a majority of MEPs in this House at the end of the day, and I need unanimity in the Council: 27 finance ministers, 27 ministers in the General Affairs Council, 27 heads of state or government, all parliaments at national level. That's why I say to myself and you: friends, let's go in with dedication, but let's stay relaxed. If not everyone offered flexibility, we would not have a chance of a next budgetary framework for the next decade. I would like to propose that we go through the tasks that we have to carry out in the interests of European citizens — be they citizens in Rome, Stuttgart, Dublin, Warsaw, be they Italian, Polish, Irish, German or European citizens — in any case they all live on the European continent. Even those who do not like Europe so much live on the European continent. My suggestion is that we should have the tasks carried out where they can be best, most efficiently accomplish. We need a clear system of competence. Therefore, we offer the argument of surplus value. I don't want to promote a project, no program propose not to invest a euro unless we can demonstrate the added value at European level. And vice versa, I expect you to show that if the added value is demonstrated, we will also get the money for it, because it is spent in the interests of our citizens and taxpayers. Investing in Europe and realising added value is more cost-effective than 27 times in parallel, or 100 times or 200 times in parallel regions. Can we agree on that? We need the money to realize the added value — no less and no more. This is the best form of investment in the interests of our taxpayers. Let me give examples: we do not dream of a European army. We don't want militarism. But we know that for every dollar an American receives far greater consideration in the form of weapons and security systems than an Austrian, a German or a Frenchman, because we lack the scales because the economies of scale are not achieved. Would it not make sense for us to put some money in the European budget, standardise classes of arms, call out together, realise economies of scale and thus save money? Realize no more, but with less in return. My grandfather served in the army of Württemberg. I dream of a European security strategy, not a European army, a security strategy. Because in the era of America First, we must jointly ensure the external and internal security of our citizens. Secondly, I believe that the added value can be presented in the field of research. You in the House and we in the Commission are always talking about 3% for research — 3% of our GDP. We're close to 2%. I am from Baden-Württemberg and am proud of one one: 4.9%. 4.9% for research in my home country. And I say to our Italian friends — I love Italy — 1% is not enough. This will not be possible to compete in the competition in the long term. 3% would be equivalent to EUR 450 billion for a GDP of EU-28. We are at just under 300 billion. Horizon accounts for 12 billion. Would it not make sense to invest more in European research projects? That is why I want to avoid cuts in two programmes. I want to increase the Horizon Europe, Horizon Post 2020 and Erasmus+ programmes in the interests of our children so that they can learn and see the culture, languages and diversity of the European continent at a young age. Apart from that, I realize that Brexit is a game changer. I'll say it sporty: if a rich uncle no longer comes for Christmas, there won't be as many presents under the Christmas tree. But, converging everything through cuts would severely damage programs like agrar and cohesion. I was previously accused that the Commission wanted to punish farmers. This is exactly what we do not want! We want to help farmers to ensure that the next generation in rural areas also produces clean and good food for our food security, including on steep slopes in the Black Forest, in the Alps, while at the same time meeting requirements for climate protection, the environment, groundwater, soil and sustainability. We need money for that. My cut will be at 5 -10% — no less and no more. With a cut of 5 to 10%, we are closing part of the Brexit gap, but we are not destroying the Common European Agricultural Policy. Cohesion: If you look at the backlog of infrastructure, standards, refurbishment of buildings, the social and environmental situation in some Member States, for example in rural areas of Romania or Bulgaria, then I think that cohesion policy remains important. And we can demonstrate, using the example of Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania and Slovakia: cohesion policy is working to: the countries are increasingly on average in the European GDP per Capita. And if we give money to economically weaker regions and bring it to us, I believe that this is a contribution to a meaningful Union of solidarity. Basically, you have to see that everyone has a perspective, and not just some regions alone. Border protection — a very specific question. I always hear from national governments: we no longer need border management in Austria, then no longer in Germany, then no longer between Italy and Austria, and no longer those of Hungary if the external border management is effective, if the outer shell in Bulgaria, Greece, Malta, Cyprus, Italy and Spain is effective protects. It would be much cheaper to have a strong European Border Guard Authority that provides effective support to Bulgaria, Greece, Italy, Spain, Malta and Cyprus, and internally we would have free movement again. Yesterday I came from Kehl to Strasbourg and was in a traffic jam for half an hour. Impossible! I call for free movement within Europe for goods, goods and people, and border protection on the outside. But then we also need the money to be able to pay the employees accordingly. That is why my question, especially to the House: if I demonstrate added value, will you support me in spending the money at European level, which will be more efficient and cost-effective than 27 national or 250 times regional? But one thing can't. To tell me: no reduction in cohesion, as nine provincial capitals in Austria do and present signature folders to me, no reduction in agriculture, as the Minister has done, more pre-accession aid for the Western Balkans, more for research, and 1.0 as ceiling. So, Adam Riese should be a colleague of ours and advise us. Neither you nor me can't square the circle. And just, if you say we can cut in heading V. Dear friends, let us seriously! We should try to see the budgetary framework as a priority from 2 May. For our part, we offer all transparency. Also in the next few weeks we will present what you need to know so that you can prepare yourself. Because the election will give us a two-way period for the budgetary framework to enter into force. The worst would be that we do not have a budgetary framework. Because no matter where you stand, farmers, researchers, regions, municipalities need clarity. The sooner they have clarity, the better they can plan, the better prepared every citizen — whether he is a German, a Pole or feels like a European — goes into the next decade. We will evaluate your speeches intensively; thank you for that. And we look forward to the discussions that will begin on May 2. (Applause)

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: rapporteur. — Madam President! Commissioner! The Commissioner likes to talk recently about the Commission as a service provider. If the Commission is a service provider, then the question arises, how will it provide them? First, it must obtain the unanimity of the member states, but also the approval of the European Parliament. And I would like to say clearly here that Parliament has some questions that it wants to ask before 2 May. We didn't raise this issue at the time of the debate, and it's worth the question today. We expect the Commissioner and the European Commission to answer a question about the budget line for the euro area. What is it supposed to rely on, what sources will the resources come from, and how is it to be placed in the budget? So the first question is: what is the budget line for the eurozone supposed to look like? The second question for the Commissioner: what about cohesion policy and the European Social Fund? This is the question that the European Parliament is taking today. We look forward to a response on May 2. Third, we await a response regarding one mutual fund. What is this concept supposed to rely on? We also expect information from the Commissioner on May 2. We know well that we all have a very difficult task in the form of unanimity. I would therefore like to convey to the Commissioner that we are counting on joint action but also to answer our questions concerning internal arrangements in the European Commission.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, Mr Oettinger, I sincerely welcome your commitment and thank you for indicating that our work will make its way through the legislative proposal and — did you say — 90% of our work. Provided that the devil does not hide in the remaining 10%. And for example, cohesion, Commissioner, at random, is good to reduce the wealth gap per country, but to reduce the wealth gap between cities and rural areas and also in the poor neighbourhoods of our rich countries is even better. Do you know that in your country 100% of the Länder have signed an open letter to maintain the amounts of cohesion policy. Imagine that 1.3% is little, it's even economical on our part, and we must be aware that if we were to go below this threshold, there would be sacrificed policies. I repeat this figure: 1.25% in 1999 with half the number of missions from the European Union and with the contribution of the United Kingdom. I am not surprised to see anti-European MEPs stand against our parliamentary reports, but at least ladies and gentlemen do not do so under false pretexts, assume! None of the reports proposes an increase in Member States' participation, on the contrary! That is why we have linked consent to the report of the multiannual financial framework to the report on own resources. Similarly, the resources we propose are not based on citizens. What surprises me much more is to hear my colleagues who boast of being European, sometimes more European than all, explain to us that we can do more with less. That is not correct. As our colleague Mr Lamassoure said, the hour of truth is approaching. In budgetary matters, there is no possible loophole and we will see who is really European and who pretends. If we succeed in this House to gather hundreds of Members on a compromise despite our differences, Commissioner, we can hope that the Member States will be able to do the same at only 27.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Madam President, I am very pleased with this debate and the general tone of the statements made by a large majority of colleagues, particularly with regard to the need for new own resources. Yes, the budget of the European Union needs new own resources. Yes, we are right to link acceptance of the multiannual financial framework to the incorporation of new own resources. I am pleased to note, Commissioner, that you are subscribing to this line. If my memory is true, you have suggested that the Commission is already working on four or five possibilities for new own resources. Continue along this path, Commissioner, persevere! You are in the right place, and if you stay in the right, you will receive massive support from our Parliament. I would also like to respond to a few speeches by colleagues who strongly warned, when new own resources were introduced, against an increase in taxes paid by citizens. Own resources, ladies and gentlemen, does not necessarily mean additional taxes for citizens. If tomorrow we reach an agreement on the taxation of large digital companies that are currently playing with our feet and paying almost no taxes, while they make billions of profits, we do not tax citizens any more. If tomorrow we find the right way to levy a few euro cents on speculative financial transactions, we do not tax citizens, on the contrary. If tomorrow the profits of the European Central Bank are allocated differently, we do not tax citizens. We have to stop with fantasies. We need new own resources and we need these new own resources, because we need Europe more than ever.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I hope for a solid vote tomorrow in this House. Once more, many thanks to everybody who has been involved with this dossier.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The debate has ended. The vote will take place on Wednesday 14 March 2018. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, the Commission will propose in early May a draft multiannual financial framework for 2021-2017 (MFF). The next MFF will have to be all the more ambitious given that it will face the challenge of absorbing the loss of the UK's net contribution of €6 billion to €9 billion. Many actors call for the “old politicians” to be deceitful. In this sense, you have already announced a 7% reduction in the CAP budget. Such a decrease of EUR 4 billion per year means putting the entire loss of the British contribution to the current CAP on tomorrow's CAP while asking it to contribute 20% to the new policies. I would like to remind you, Commissioner, that this policy is essentially an income support policy. Such a decrease will have a direct and quasi-proportional impact on peasants' incomes. How many farms will disappear due to lack of support? We defend in the European Parliament to maintain the CAP budget while reforming it: better distributing aid, refocusing the CAP on economic policy and integrating environmental and climate issues intelligently are our objectives.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - We welcome the fact that the European Parliament states that the current financial framework for the Common Agricultural Policy and Cohesion Policy must be preserved, and responses at EU level to new political priorities should be financed from new sources and not to the detriment of existing programmes. We managed to find that, according to Parliament's resolution, the Common Agricultural Policy needs to be retained in its separate budget chapter, but we do not support the EP blending Cohesion Policy with migration under the heading 'solidarity' and putting it in a budget chapter in the management of migration with spent resources. It is feared that this would allow the European Union to allocate sources of catch-up for migration purposes. When allocating cohesion resources, it is important that Parliament states that the development of the regions must remain one of the criteria. At the same time, we do not support the introduction of unfounded indicators selected on a social, environmental and demographic basis. The risk of the additional conditions proposed by the EP that the resources allocated to Hungary could be reduced, one of the aims of the demographic condition is to link the allocation of funds to the proportion of immigrants. Regarding the revenue side of the budget, we support the fact that revenues lost due to Brexit need to be replenished, the EU budget cannot decrease, and Hungary is willing to increase its contributions. We consider it important that the introduction of new sources of revenue in the EU must respect the financial sovereignty of the Member States and the fact that the tax burden on citizens cannot increase.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. – Cohesion policy is an important tool of solidarity within the EU, reducing differences of development among MS. The European flow of sources had a great effect on the economic and social circumstances of most of the new Member States. There are various discussions on the efficiency and effectiveness of the cohesion policy, which included suggestions to link cohesion policies to conditionalities related to the rule of law, to the participation in certain common European policies or to the EPPO. However, that cohesion policy is an economic tool rather than a political one and that the potential suspension of payment will punish first and foremost the citizens, thus leading to an unfair situation. Given that corruption hinders the core of the aims of the policy, an ideal mechanism would include institutional guarantees and conditionalities linked to fighting corruption and ensure the capacity to issue sanctions. EPPO would be instrumental in this sense, as corruption often lies at the top of the political caste, which generally holds control over law enforcement agencies. Additionally, a system of ongoing evaluation and analysis of corruption and anti—corruption performance, as well as intervention based on direct management upon necessity, are to be put in place.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. — The long-term budget is an important element of the debate on the future of the EU because we cannot realise European political priorities without having sufficient and predictable financial resources. The next Multiannual Financial Framework must clearly reflect our priorities. I believe that the share of the general EU budget allocated to cohesion policy measures after 2020 should be increased, taking into account the great contribution of European funds to improving the living standards of European citizens and to overcoming the socio-economic differences between regions. The legislative process for adopting the next MFF must be completed before the European Parliament elections to allow sufficient time for negotiations on sectoral EU legislation and to avoid delays in implementing the new programmes. The EU must continue to provide financial assistance to Bulgaria for decommissioning the suspended nuclear facilities in order to ensure effective protection of the environment and public health. No Member State can tackle cross-border health challenges alone. The European budget must support Member States in combating health inequalities that undermine social cohesion and impede European integration, as well as ensure an effective European foreign and security policy.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. — The first important task in reforming the MFF is to ensure that Brexit does not have a negative impact on the financing of programmes that have proven their European added value. Such a programme is Erasmus+, which, despite its undeniable success, represents only 1.36% of the EU's total budget for the period 2014-2020. During the current programming period, only four million young people will benefit from it, mainly students. I stand for the Erasmus+ budget to increase several times in the future MFF and make the programme more accessible, covering not only students, but also students, trainees and young people with modest financial opportunities. In addition to strengthening successful programmes, we will also need funds for new education and skills policies. Currently 70 million Europeans lack basic skills and 44% are digitally illiterate. Functional and media literacy in the era of fake news is also a big challenge to tackle. If the EU does not invest in the education of its citizens, it cannot expect prosperity.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. — The European Multiannual Financial Framework has demonstrated several shortcomings almost since its beginning. The high level of outstanding commitments starting in 2014 and the lack of resources for new priorities, which the Commission and the Council decided to unsystematically address on an ad hoc basis by moving envelopes from successful programs, ending. I welcome the report on the future FR: preparing Parliament's position on the FR after 2020, because I consider it necessary to avoid such mistakes in the future. Europeans need a strong Union that can respond to fundamental problems. Union with sustainable economic growth, quality jobs and support for economic, social and territorial cohesion. Member countries' representatives must no longer block Union contributions to measures to combat climate change. These, by the way, are still well below the level of 20% that the Member States themselves have committed to. There is a need to increase the resources of LIFE, which has a high success rate but which suffers from chronic underfunding against other European programmes. I am very pleased that Parliament has managed to establish a strong position. I am also personally very pleased that the European Parliament has openly recognised that funding for a new agricultural policy must go hand in hand with the introduction of more environmentally friendly practices and towards health of the population.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. – I call for the next MFF to be feminist – to be non-discriminatory and promoting human rights. I call for maintaining the designation of ´Roma people´ as beneficiaries of the ESF and the ERDF fund, and to explicitly exclude segregational practices from funding. I call for an improved regulation of the YEI and Erasmus+ to safeguard non-discriminatory participation for young people coming from a disadvantaged socio-economic background, thereby closing the gap between the Roma and non-Roma youth and guaranteeing that also young Roma can fulfil their true potential. And similarly, any other groups, such as people with disabilities, who are now not reached by these programmes. I believe that the internal aspect of the security of European residents, such as the right to live free from gender-based and interpersonal violence, has been neglected by the EU, so I demand that the next MFF should provide relevant solutions. I call for human rights, democracy, and rule of law to be integral in the next MFF, including the protection and support of NGOs and human rights defenders, who are under pressure; the next MFF must maintain a dedicated EIDHR, one of the strongest tools we have to promote human rights and democracy.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: in writing. — When we debate the new EU budget, it is also said that bargaining for power and money begins. I would argue that we have an honest discussion on the EU budget. In the end, there must be a sensibly designed budget that can cope with the current challenges. When Minister Köstinger says that there should be no loss for farmers, I expect the same for the employment initiative. Agriculture must not automatically take priority over unemployed young people. 700 million for unemployed young people account for the lion's share of the EU budget. Long-standing unemployment is one of the biggest social problems of the present. The fight against youth unemployment must also be reflected in the EU budget. We have already made a clear distinction in favour of additional financial instruments in the European Parliament — now, at last, the Member States must also seriously discuss these instruments for the EU budget. European-coordinated levies such as the FTT, the Digital Tax or the CCCTB could support the EU budget without any additional burden on national budgets.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: in writing. — Mr President, the EU's future financial framework for 2021-2027 is being proposed to increase from the current 1% of gross national income to the level of 1.3%. Pressure to grow the budget is tough because of Brexit, as well as increasing tasks such as defence co-operation and managing migration, but I still see the proposal as outsized. Today, 70 per cent of the EU budget is spent on agriculture and cohesion subsidies. Funding focus should be shifted more strongly to projects that will support future growth, such as innovation, research and security. In Parliament's proposal, funding for the future research programme will be increased by 1.5-fold and funding for youth programmes such as Erasmus will be increased by up to tripling. The direction is completely correct. These are key and important areas for the future of Europe. At the same time, however, there would be no desire to cut This is not realistic. Clearly, it is not only possible to increase the allocation, but also to be able to change the focus. At the same time, funding criteria must also be reformed. It is absolutely unsustainable for us to support countries with giant cohesion resources that are making a fuss about the common values of the European Union and violating the rule of law. Respect for the fundamental values of the European Union must be conditional on funding.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: in writing. — It is important to acknowledge that Europe faces two major challenges: the ageing population and the depopulation of rural areas. Country life is no longer attractive to young people from an educational, economic and social point of view. There are huge problems related to infrastructure, but also to the lack of quality health services in rural areas. The massive migration of rural population to urban areas has led to important holes in the economy. The majority population remaining in rural areas is people of high age who no longer have work capacity. The post-2020 financial framework must necessarily maintain the Common Agricultural Policy and Pillar I is essential. Only with massive investments in rural areas will we manage to attract young people, investments that will materialize in well-paid jobs, good quality educational institutions, high-speed internet connections, entertainment centres, infrastructure. Otherwise, we will face an acute shortage of workers in the agricultural sector. We want not only food security, but also food sovereignty. This can only be achieved through a process of reforming trade policy and development policy for the benefit of the citizen.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. — (PT) The report on the multiannual financial framework reflects a broad political commitment and contains common sense and ambition positions that must be considered throughout the decision-making process. I would particularly like to highlight the proposal to increase national contributions to the EU budget to 1.3% of GNP and the principle that new priorities should be financed from new resources, whether national transfers or own resources obtained by the Union. The proposals contained in the report safeguard European commitments to sustainable development, compliance with the Paris Agreement and the implementation of the social rights pillar, as well as advocating the same level of funding and greater efficiency in the implementation of cohesion policy and agricultural policy common. I stress some of the priorities contained in the resolution, namely strengthening policies for young people, including doubling support for youth employment and tripling the funds for Erasmus, the protection of children at risk of poverty and exclusion, incentives for refugee countries and the transition fund to support energy sector conversion and decarbonisation. It is a proposal for convergence for a good agreement for the future of the EU.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the report by Daniele Votti, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the guidelines for the 2019 budget — Section III (2017/2286 (BUD)) (A8-0062/2018).

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if you allow me a personal data just before I start: it is a great honour for me to open this budget year and this first debate, and it will be an honour for I would like to thank the example given me by the rapporteurs of previous years — with whom I was able to work as shadow rapporteur last year — my colleague Mureșan, but also colleague Geier, colleague Fernandes and colleague Gardiazabal. And of course I wish Commissioner Oettinger good work, with whom I imagine we will work in the coming weeks and months throughout the year. It is difficult of course to summarize in a few minutes the content of the guidelines we have worked on in recent weeks with colleagues, and I also take advantage of this to thank the shadow speakers with whom we have been there a fruitful work and also a frank and fruitful work in recent weeks to arrive at a document that can have the widest vote in this House. I will mention only a few themes, because it is impossible of course to re-read all the document and all the text. Of course, we have a duty, as Parliament, as the European Union, to turn our attention especially to those who are still suffering from the economic and financial crisis that has affected our continent, which has affected the whole world in past years and on which probably not enough has been done. I am thinking in particular of workers and women workers, I think in particular of young people, I think of small and medium-sized enterprises, who have often had to close or who are still in difficulty today and with great courage try to move on despite the crisis and despite few reassurances and few interventions that have been made towards them. I also think, and I would like to summarize especially on the youth issue my content attentions in particular. We've talked about it until now, compared to the debate on the forthcoming multiannual financial framework and the subject of own resources: we absolutely need, as Europe, to aim all our possibilities, all our efforts, all our efforts and all our resources, not just economic, on the younger generation. That is why we need that from next year, beyond the new financial framework, the young initiative is an initiative that has a full endowment and has a real endowment, Commissioner, so that initiatives can truly be implemented in the Member States. And I am thinking of Erasmus and Erasmus+, on which we must give assurances to all young people who ask for access, because you said it very well, responding to an Italian colleague who has a little vision. distorted the European Union: we need as many young as possible as possible to become part of this continent. I am moving quickly on two other elements: one is the issue of defence, on which the European Union is doing a great deal, and we must, of course, commit ourselves to this and on the issue of migratory phenomena. We must, yes, look from within the migratory phenomena, and therefore be able to accommodate how right it is to accommodate and have the resources to be able to accommodate, but we must also look outside and be capable of preventing migratory phases in the long term. Two final points: I would like to talk again about the environment, of course, 20% of our financial framework to be devoted to the environment, and I would like to talk above all about a social Europe. There are two budgets that go hand in hand: one is the Europe of investment and the other is Europe which must stand alongside the citizens who do not make it, who are poorer, who have difficulty even in access to health, or they are in the process of unemployment. Our states are unable to give answers and we must be close to our Member States. The Ultimate Two Considerations: the first is a principle that we must give ourselves, which is a cornerstone principle of our Parliament and which we want to bring ourselves back in the next negotiations. New resources and new money must be provided for each new project. You first made the example of cooking, European Commissioner, we are only the cooks and we are the kitchen. Well, if more courses are asked for this kitchen, if more dishes are asked for this kitchen — I arrive at the conclusion, President — this kitchen must also have a galley that has many more resources. Finally, on the negotiation: if the Commission — and I end — if the Commission is an ambitious Commission, it will find this Parliament, as you know, absolutely ally. If the Council wants to deal from the outset, it will find this Parliament very ready to deal from the outset. Popusms don't fight — look, President — populisms are not just fought with words, but you fight with policies and we can fight them with next year's budget as well.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking Mr Viotti and to express my respect for the valuable technical and substantive work with which he has prepared Parliament's guidelines. And I am pleased to say to you, Mr Viotti, my interest in a regular exchange of views over the next few months, because we should try to maximise the Commission's work and parliamentary priorities from today, from March to the autumn, when decisions between the Council, Parliament and also the Commission are to be taken. to vote. On the one hand, I would like to say that your priorities and those of the Commission for the 2019 budget are largely comparable to those of 2018, and what was important to you this year will remain important to you next year. On the other hand, it is a budget in which British friends are no longer members all year for the first time — Brexit is likely to take effect from the end of March next year. However, following the consultation of the negotiators and my contact with our chief negotiator Michel Barnier, we believe that the British are ready to participate constructively not only in the advisory process in the Council as one Member State, but with all the rights and obligations of the budget next year also for the whole of the year. to participate. This can make the work easier. Our main focus is on our priorities. It is about growth and employment and thus about combating unemployment, which is still too high in many regions of Europe, including youth unemployment. Secondly, we also fund approved measures and say precisely that we keep our word where we have programmes. Our partners have expectations for the programmes and need to fund their programmes in such a way that the funding will be included in the commitments made. is guaranteed. This applies to Horizon 2020, which applies to the Connecting Europe Facility, it applies to COSME, to small and medium-sized enterprises, and it applies to Erasmus +. Just one example: Connecting Europe, an infrastructure, whether road, rail, energy, is applied for, tested, approved, awarded, built and billed across borders. This means that we have large projects that we reviewed and approved a year, two or three years ago and which will now have to be served with a corresponding financial share next year. This is the expectation of the Member States, has the investors and has the corresponding construction company. Keeping word on the commitments made is part of our budget proposal and what you will then have to approve later. The aim is for us to use the possibilities of flexibility next year to finance the performance of tasks, especially where new tasks are becoming increasingly important: providing humanitarian aid, migration measures, strengthening controls at the external borders, support for the most affected Member States, when it comes to refugee tasks. I can tell you this morning that the Commission intends to propose to you this morning the Facility for Refugees in Turkey in a second tranche. Now the time is right. The three billion that you and the Member States provided two years ago are now fully occupied by commitments and payments will soon reach the three billion. We now need to discuss and decide on a second tranche of these three billion. Just one example: we have school offers for hundreds of thousands of refugee children, classes in the appropriate accommodation centres and camps. We now need to prepare the salary bases for 5000 teachers for the next school year, which begins in September, so that you can get their contract for the will be able to sign accordingly next school year. For this we need clarity, the second tranche, and proportional co-financing will be included in the Draft budget for 2019. We propose that the European budget should allocate one billion on the way to the end of the MFF and that the Member States should be ready to add two billion. The Council, your partner, our partner, adopted its guidelines on 20 February this year. If we compare the Council's guidelines and Mr Viotti's draft, there are no too many differences. There are bridgeable differences between the position of Parliament that you are discussing today, that of the Council that has been adopted, and what we are preparing, which should be reconciled on the way to October/November, given the goodwill of all parties, although the day of European elections is slowly approaching . In order to reach this joint decision for a 2019 budget in a timely manner by November, we want to make every effort to provide you with information on what you need to know in more detail in the coming weeks for your discussions on the implementation of the budget for 2018 and our budgets for 2019. We will probably present the Draft Budget 2019 to you and the Council in May. The timetable until autumn is already being prepared by all of us accordingly. Thank you very much for your cooperation!

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, I would like to start by thanking my colleague, Mr Viotti, not only for the good cooperation, but also, above all, for the fact that he has really presented a very good basis of guidelines for the financial year 2019. Commissioner, I am pleased that we have such a broad common ground, particularly with regard to Horizon 2020 and Erasmus. At Horizon 2020, you mentioned the topic of COSME in particular. I would also like to mention Future Emergence Technologies — a great program, but which is quite underfunded and has a lot of outstanding project proposals, where we also need to consider whether we can provide assistance in any way in 2019. We have also placed a very intensive priority on how to avoid young people being unemployed. I hope that, together with the Commission and the Member States, we will be able to further strengthen the Youth Employment Initiative so that young people can really find permanent jobs and not just temporary accommodation. Our aim is to permanently qualify young people and then to give them a secure workplace or promising jobs in the long term. We also continue to deal with security and migration. Security will continue to play a very, very important role in the context of the ongoing terrorism and will challenge us. I believe that next year we must pay particular attention to the fact that we are not guided by discussions such as Brexit and other, but to work intensively on the further development of the European Union in order to cope with the tasks ahead.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, I would like to begin by warmly congratulating our rapporteur Daniele Viotti on his excellent work. By adopting the guidelines for the 2019 budget of the European Union, Parliament assumes its role as budgetary authority and sends a firm signal to the other institutions for the forthcoming negotiations. Two regrets that are all alarms for future procedures. The first concerns the European Commission, which did not play full transparency during the last conciliation for the 2018 budget by concealing that it planned to turn the increase on the Youth Initiative into a simple advance of the 2019-2020 budgets. We remind the Commission as the budgetary authority that this is indeed a cash increase in this programme. We expect our partners to be more sincere in the forthcoming negotiations. I would also like to alert to an ambiguous wording which suggests that Parliament would abandon its historic position, on which new initiatives could be financed by cuts in other programmes. For my group, this is not the case. Thus, the new security programmes will in no way be a substitute for solidarity programmes. Parliament must stay on course and thwart all sorts of manipulations. We will be more cautious in the next budget conciliations.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger. Thank you for your designs. I agree with you in many areas. You have given two wonderful examples: migration policy, we really need to focus on this. Budgetary priorities mean that we need sufficient money, at different levels. On the one hand, we need to strengthen Frontex, for example, because we need to secure the external borders. We also need sensible procedures for all arriving people. At the same time, however, we must, of course, also set priorities for expenditure in the countries where these people come from, because every euro we invest there is invested much better than if we wait for these people to make a dangerous crossing across the Mediterranean and we invest here first. There are also investments in cross-border projects. The EU can clearly deliver added value. Nevertheless, I believe that the overall structure of our budget is still wrong. We are giving citizens completely wrong impressions when we pretend that we can definitely fight unemployment in Europe with an EU budget. We can take individual measures, but they are not as sustainable on a regular basis as if we were actually rid of many bureaucratic shackles if we were to create the framework conditions for the economy to grow. This includes, for example, tackling disparities in the Eurozone. We would have to start there and not on any subsidies that are actually just a flash in the pan.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate our colleague, Mr Viotti, on his investment, his creativity, his all-Italian style and his sense of compromise. And I want to say to him, “Mr. Viotti, you are blessed by the gods.” I have just heard — if the translation is correct — Commissioner say 'Mr Viotti, you have placed your accents, they are ours', and then I heard the Commissioner say, in examining the Council's proposals, 'they are practically yours. ' But this is remarkable, Mr Viotti. So I will not take this opportunity to repeat what my colleagues and the Commissioner have said in terms of priorities, but I simply want to stress two things that I think are important at this stage. Firstly, young people, all young people must experience concretely, in their lives, that the European Union is made for them, that it invests in them, that it relies on them. That is why, as we all reiterate, the resources available to Erasmus + must be considerably strengthened and it should be extended to young people from the popular backgrounds by apprentices. Measures taken to support youth employment should be evaluated and the most successful programmes should be strengthened. The European Solidarity Corps must be rapidly implemented in order to strengthen the values of mutual help and solidarity among young people. Secondly, the popular classes that have gradually been won by Euroscepticism and populism must be reconciled with the European idea. Europe — and you are told by a member of the ALDE Group — cannot be just the business of leaders, entrepreneurs, academia and the intellectual middle class. The three institutions recently solemnly proclaimed the European Pillar of Fundamental Rights. Proclaiming is good, but implementing is better. We must seek, all together, where he there is a way to add a European value in the social field.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as so often happens in the Committee on Budgets, I agree with Mr Deprez – so I could save the next 50 seconds and not say anything – but I will still make four quick points. I appreciate that the rapporteur has brought to the attention of the Commission and Council the need for a properly managed negotiation process, and I hope this serves as a warning to encourage the full engagement of all parties. We need to do that. I am glad as well that the Youth Employment Initiative, Erasmus, research and climate will lead these future negotiations because it was about time to acknowledge that our climate action goals are falling short and it is about time we engaged decisively to achieve them. Finally, I am speaking on behalf of my group, but I have a slightly different approach to defence issues. So give us more defence. Otherwise, we will all be killed by some kind of nerve agent.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, for all the posturing that went on in the Chamber this morning during the Brexit debate, one might suppose that the EU is in a position to send Britain packing with no departure agreement. However, this motion blows such an idea out of the water when it notes that the December deal to launch phase two of Brexit talks included an undertaking that the UK ‘will contribute to and participate in the implementation of annual budgets for 2019 and 2020 as if it had remained in the Union’. In cold hard cash over two years, this equates to nearly EUR 20 billion net, yet as Brexit Secretary David Davis made clear, nothing is agreed until everything is agreed. Were the UK simply cut adrift, you would have an enormous immediate financial black hole and no obvious means of filling it. The conclusion surely is that it is time for the EU to drop the brow-beating and the bullying and come to a sensible deal. The truth is that it cannot afford to do otherwise.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, this report on the general guidelines for the 2019 budget is emblematic of the dogmatic vision of the European Union. Your political arguments to justify your unnecessary budgetary spending are a litany of intentions totally disconnected from the realities and needs of Europeans. European leaders live in the illusion of believing themselves indispensable. As if, before the federalist European Union, there was nothing! But you're the only ones who believe it. Your existential concern now is that the majority of citizens are increasingly rejecting your globalist and ultraliberal European Union. In Austria, Italy — Mr Viotti —, in France, in the countries of the East and even in Germany, people are waking up and no longer accept your globalist ideology and the migratory overwhelm you impose. In your anguish, you attribute this phenomenon of popular revolt to the Eurocritical political movements that defend each country's culture, national identity and economies. But who has been in power for decades? Who is responsible for mass unemployment, deindustrialization and social devastation? Who organised the Atlantist submission of the countries of Europe? Who has fostered the emergence of Islamist terrorism and the insecurity of Europeans? These are not the “populist” parties, it's you! So do not come and throw at us your own turpitudes and assume your incompetencies!

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate the Commissioner, congratulate the rapporteurs, the lead rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs and to remind - and it is always good to remember - that the European Union budget is an investment budget. Only 6% are earmarked for administration and operating expenditure. This means that this is a budget with great added value. In some Member States more than 70% of public investment comes from the European Union budget. Although it accounts for only 1% of Gross Domestic Product, it has enormous added value, I would insist on this statement. The 2019 budget should be a budget that should continue to promote economic, social and territorial cohesion, solidarity, and should be a youth budget. Young unemployment has values that are unacceptable. The budget of the European Union, through the amounts it makes available, even in cohesion policy, through Erasmus+, the strengthening of the Youth Employment initiative, should help to make this scourge undermined. In addition, support for small and medium-sized enterprises, research and innovation is essential. I will conclude by saying that, if we agree, the Council and the Commission, as far as priorities are concerned, it will not be difficult for us to agree on the amounts needed to implement those same priorities.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: Mr President, after having had an intense debate on the financial perspective, we are now addressing the general guidelines for the 2019 budget, and I would like to join the congratulations that have been made to the rapporteur, Daniele Viotti, for the excellent work he has done with the shadow rapporteurs. These are guidelines that continue to emphasize the main challenges we have for next year. Because, despite the fact that we have emerged from the economic crisis in macroeconomic terms, it is true that inequalities are only growing, and we have to put the budget on the side of the most disadvantaged. And we have to see in this budget the agreement on the social pillar signed in Gothenburg so that this does not remain, once again, in a beautiful statement of intent. And youth unemployment must also remain a priority. It remains very high in many of our regions and, of course, it is intolerable that my country is not able to use these funds to end youth unemployment. And I take this — others have already done so — to reiterate that Parliament's will in negotiating the 2018 budgets was to increase the money available for the Youth Guarantee. And I would like to ask the Commissioner to clarify what the Commission's position is. And I finish: we also have to continue investing in our planet. Because our commitments against climate change, for an energy transition and ultimately for a sustainable development model must be reflected in this budget. One last sentence: Parliament and Council priorities often coincide, but then when it comes to putting resources, Parliament always puts the money and the Council always wants to cut it down.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Mr President, I will tell you four things. Firstly, Commissioner, please take into account the main elements from the guidelines drafted by our colleague, Daniele Viotti, that will be approved by a large majority in plenary when you put forward the draft budget in May. I can say, speaking as a general rapporteur for the 2018 Union budget, that last year, when you presented the draft budget, you took account of the conclusions in our guidelines in a more than satisfactory manner, and that made the budgetary procedure much easier. The more you take into account, the higher the likelihood that we can find a good agreement in the conciliation procedure at the end of the year. My second message is that trust is important. Trust between Parliament and the Commission and all of the Commission departments is important. Let’s use the beginning of this budgetary procedure to establish such trust. Thirdly, Commissioner, last year we jointly decided in the conciliation procedure to increase the amounts for heading 1A – research, innovation, Erasmus scholarships, and small and medium—sized enterprises – because money was needed there. But in the 2019 budget guidelines the Council is now asking you to try to find ways to redeploy – and hence reduce – the budgets for 2019 and 2020 in those areas. Please stand together with us in defending the increases. The amounts were needed for that heading, and any reductions are a move in the wrong direction.  My fourth and last message, very briefly, is let’s find ways in the budget for next year to finance measures to tackle fake news and disinformation propaganda. Fake news is a threat to the Union and to our Member States. Let’s find ways to act.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, yes, sketching the contours of a European budget within the constrained framework we know is not easy, and I would like to thank my friend, Daniele Viotti, for the proposals he is making which can help meet the most pressing challenges facing the European Union now: migration management, of course, combating youth unemployment, combating climate change, supporting basic research and innovation, encouraging mobility and investment, all of which should not, under any circumstances, be financed at the expense of structural policies such as cohesion policies and of the CAP. As I have repeatedly pointed out in this House, our Union deserves the means of its ambitions. The ball is now in the camp of the Commission and the Council, which must hear the call of the European elected representatives who absolutely want to avoid the rise of populism and extremism. They must agree to finance these policies with their own resources. I would simply like to point out, in conclusion, that the fight against tax evasion and what some purely call tax optimization would deserve to have a proper budget for the European Union.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the choices on the Union budget for 2019 will take place in parallel with the choices on the forthcoming multiannual financial framework and the reform of the resources system own. Seeking an ambitious and comprehensive agreement is indispensable to influence parallel negotiations in a positive way. Safety and unemployment problems, particularly youth, should be the focus of attention. Worrying are delays in implementing the cohesion policy, as well as those in implementing the Youth Unemployment Programme. The increases in appropriations are well, but we need to improve synergies between this programme, the social fund and national budgets, so as to prevent the youth employment initiative from simply going to replace national funding for young people so-called NEETs. Finally, a mention of the fight against climate change and the green economy: at a time when the United States is no longer willing to meet its commitments to fight climate change, I believe that the 2019 budget should strengthen the EU's frontline role by providing for example additional financial support for the LIFE programme.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President! Commissioner Oettinger, thank you for your comments on the 2019 budget, which was previously on the multiannual financial framework — a real basis for discussion. I would like to quote you: Mr Ober, I would like to order on behalf of the citizens of our common country, Germany, a round of red houses for the Stammtisch. We should sit down by that together to listen to what the people outside are saying about what you are saying here: Germany has to pay more. One third of the Brexit hole is to fill our taxpayers. This means three to four billion euros more mice per year. 13 existing plus 4 makes 17, up from 82 million makes up 208 euros per capita or converted 13 boxes of fir zäfles for every German citizen — a proud price! Let's save this! Top edge! Germany's taxpayers can no longer pay, not a cent more, Mr Oettinger. Please take this into account, and you will continue to be welcome in the local beer garden. Cheers!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the Union budget is the expression of an outdated and counterproductive system, which cannot be corrected by fragmentary interventions or by tackling only the symptoms of distortions and not their causes. It is utopian to believe that the effects of the financial, economic and social crisis are now in the past, as is the collective targeting of political movements and political opponents through the budget. The objective of the budget is not only about the formal allocation of appropriations but remains entirely theoretical. It does not lead to sustainable development, does not adequately address existing challenges or emerging threats and intensifies economic disparities between the robust and weaker Member States. Unfortunately, in a united Europe, where the Member States practice their economic and fiscal policies on dictation and have now lost their full sovereignty, the welfare of citizens is entrusted to third parties without guarantees for the sound, impartial and independent management of the available resources.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union is constantly subject to a number of challenges and, in order to remain competitive, it must take into account the rapid changes that are taking place, the intensification of global competition and the profound changes caused by digitisation in all sectors. Research, competitiveness, innovation and active SMEs are essential to enable growth and jobs in the European Union. For this, however, it is important to provide these companies with a favourable environment to build a truly competitive European Union economy at global level, namely programmes that take into account their specific requirements and low administrative resources. The 2019 European Union budget should strengthen all relevant instruments for combating youth unemployment, particularly in the regions of the European Union economically lagging behind, with particular attention to improving entrepreneurial skills and , recognition of qualifications at all levels of education and training, including the promotion of digital skills and digital entrepreneurship.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Mr President, the 2019 budget has many challenges: youth unemployment, cohesion, migration are three main issues. For youth unemployment, the funds allocated are crumbs. If one takes into account that Mr. Draghi has so far allocated EUR 2.5 trillion in quantitative relaxation, the amounts allocated by the European Union to support youth employment do not really create any potential for significant employment, especially for countries such as Greece, where at the moment we are champions in youth unemployment and over five hundred thousand young people have emigrated. At the same time, funds must be made available to support the region, to have regional cohesion, and, finally, funds for migration — support for Greece, which really cannot afford other refugees and illegal immigrants, Mr Oettinger.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I would say to the Commissioner that while all these things are very important – youth unemployment, immigration, Brexit – I would like to refer to the European defence plan that was recently established.  The European Union cannot continue to be a soft power only. The European Union needs to build security and defence capabilities because the main concern of European citizens nowadays is security. We have to respond to these concerns, giving more money, more funds, to European defence and security institutions like Europol, like the European Counter-Terrorism Centre, to Frontex and so on and so forth.  Of course, the new PESCO policy has to play a very important role because, as I said, we cannot continue to rely only on economic relations, on trade or on humanitarian aid or development aid. Europe, if it wants to become a global actor, needs stronger security and defence capabilities.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. On the last speech, I can say that I see this the same way. Europe must do more for its external and internal security than in the past, because the dangers and risks to our European citizens have not digged, but have increased. PESCO is an approach to this that is widely supported by the Member States and we will use a pilot phase 2019/2020 to test the added value in the field of defence research and defence industry and will include significantly more money in our proposal, building on the experience of the next 2021ff budget, with the request to: to advise and support them accordingly. Several colleagues have referred to the subject of youth work. I very much agree with you that the sustainable and further fight against youth unemployment is crucial for many young people in many regions of Europe. That is why we will also propose appropriate funding within the 2019 budget framework for the continuation of our projects. We note two points here: firstly, the concern that in some Member States where these European funds should actually be highly welcome and are also welcome, absorption is far from 100%. This means that it is not possible to call up the funds and translate them into projects, into jobs. Either because the capacity and absorption capacities in the market do not exist or because the administrative force is insufficient. That is why this issue of absorption, the levy, is at the forefront of me, because more resources only make sense if it is also called up and can be implemented through projects in jobs for young people. We still have a significant difference between the appropriations and the use of funds in many Member States. The second topic is discussed in the course of the Negotiations must be discussed with the Council. You know, before I became responsible for the budget, there was the midterm review; that's your credit. And in this midterm review and revision, we agreed €1.2 billion on the way to the end of 2020 in additional funding together with the Youth Work Council. In 2017 — this was also before my time — 500 million were entered into the budget for this purpose. On the way to 1.2 billion, we now have the balance of 350 million. If you divide these into the two years, you can not increase a lot of funds. If we use them next year, we will have a problem in 2020. So the question remains: is the capping of 1.2 billion fluent by the Council, or can we reconsider changes, redeployments or increases here? We will certainly come back to this in the trilogue and in the conciliation in the autumn. A small addition: a box of red house beer, fir suppositories, costs 19.60 euros. This will only give you eight boxes of the amount, not 13, as you estimate.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: It probably depends on the kind of beer!

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I can speak as an Italian speaking of the cost of wine, more than beer, but I would come back to the subject. I do not know if I have been blessed by God, as Mr Deprez said, of course it was that the debate was very useful, I was pleased to hear the words of the European Commissioner's opening and even now in closing, and also the words of my colleagues who pointed out those points I could not go into in the course of my initial report. I want to say that we have two duties, and that is clear from the discussion we have made this afternoon and the goals we give ourselves, which are not always the same, change from year to year but go always in the same strand. The two objectives are to give growth and development to our businesses and our continent, and on the other hand it is to make our European citizens a little more serene. I believe Mrs Gardiazabal mentioned the fact that we have a duty, which the Member States have also taken, to give content to the so-called social pillar of the European Union.
