Our political dialogue and cooperation agreement is the tool we need to better accompany and support a process of economic and social reform. It is the best tool we have to work for sustainable development, social justice, democracy and human rights. We do have disagreements as I said, and I am sure our Cuban friends would say the same. But there is also a lot that unites the European people and the Cuban people. We both believe in international cooperation and dialogue as the best way to address international disputes. We believe that a multilateral global order is possible and it would help us build a more sustainable development world-wide. And I won’t mention here all the cultural, historic links, the social links that are there between our people. So let us continue to engage, aware of the differences, ready to address them, in a spirit of dialogue, respect and frankness, aware also of the opportunities for our common work in different sectors of cooperation, and continuing to work on our side in unity. The European Parliament, together with all other European institutions, continues to invest in dialogue respectfully, without hiding the differences and the difficulties, but also while taking all the opportunities that this dialogue can bring about.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, it seems that, although relations between institutions continue to advance normally, Cuba is not fulfilling its commitments. It is true, Madam Vice-President: the path of dialogue is the best way to address disagreements, but I think there is no political will. The Cuban regime continues to use arbitrary arrests, dismissals of officials and harassment to silence criticism. It's not my words. With this forcefulness begins the report Amnesty International published a few weeks ago on Cuba. At a time when the country is facing an alleged generational shift, the reality is that 605 members of the National Assembly have been elected from 605 members previously appointed by the regime. Despite Cuba's alleged opening to the world, the island maintains internet censorship, as well as undue restrictions on access to information and freedom of expression. Last year alone, the Cuban Commission on Human Rights and National Reconciliation recorded at least 5,155 arrests of opponents. Meanwhile, Eduardo Cardet, a member of the Christian Liberation Movement, has been in prison since 2016. We believe, Mrs Mogherini, that, along with diplomatic forms, you should, at least, demand compliance with the agreements on the regime. Many believe that the end of Castroism opens an opportunity for the new generations of the Cuban people. And this despite the fact that there are indications that nothing is wanted to change. The European Union cannot look aside. Realpolitik has boundaries, and not everything should be red carpets. Let us remain hopeful that all dictatorships come to an end. The European Union can not only contribute, but must participate actively, with diplomacy, yes, but not endorsing new totalitarian forms.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, eight months ago we adopted in this House the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation with Cuba. That approval was difficult. A few months later, at the beginning of the year, the High Representative traveled to Cuba. I think it was an important journey and demonstrated the European Union's willingness to establish a constructive dialogue with Havana. Sure, things aren't going to change in such a short time, that's obvious. But our impulse from the beginning has been that: to try to build a relationship that essentially aims to improve the lives of Cubans and Europeans, because it is a relationship that has to be symmetrical. Certainly, there is still a political blockade in Cuba that will have to be resolved, probably in the coming months. And then, when the exchange has been resolved in Cuba and the Joint Council meeting has been held in May, then I think it will be time to tell Mrs Mogherini to come to this House and explain how much we have made progress. I have not quite understood the obsession of any group with holding the debate today, when that Council has not yet met, that is, when the mechanism has not yet been implemented. Today all we can do is congratulate Mrs Mogherini on her trip to Cuba, because that makes a fundamental difference in what our relations with the island are going to be, with Latin America as a whole, because we all know the strategic importance of that island, however small it may be. So I would ask Mrs Mogherini to later, when we have really been able to measure and build that work that we have decided to do, come to this House — to which he always comes, on the other hand, when it is called — to explain to us what progress has been made. We are going to continue to demand from the Cuban authorities democracy, freedom, development and balance in the country, because that is the role we have as Members in this Parliament. I thank Mrs Mogherini, once again, for her efforts.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, in the run-up to this debate — and I always try to prepare this seriously — I have spoken to a number of people from my own country, the Netherlands, who have been there every year for many years. And what I have heard about — and this is not about democracy, Mrs Valenciano, this is about basic issues: food scarcity, no possibility of accepting direct foreign aid because the state is blocking it. It's just — I heard it from many mouths yesterday — a harrowing situation. Where's the foreign aid money? Is it invested in tourism? Meanwhile, the population suffers and is in need. A soup kitchen in the industry in the port city of Cienfuegos is not allowed, because the state blocks it. It is very difficult for me to talk about 'Cuban friends', because such friends are uncompassionate towards their own people. We are not talking about the more than 300 arbitrary arrests that took place last month, 347, and this morning a Cubakenner asked me: 'What exactly is the EU doing in terms of human rights? ' He was truly appalled at the silence of the EU. Mrs Valenciano,... (The President interrupted the speaker.)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, on your first visit following the signing of the first EU-Cuba Agreement, you did not find time to meet with opponents, the Sakharov Awards, or with any representatives of civil society, who have been suffering the consequences of the island's dictatorial regime for years. There was talk about the benefits of this Agreement to increase European Union trade and investment, but what about the human rights situation? Where is that modernization you were talking about in your first statements? Cuba remains a politically closed society, where political parties and independent civil society organizations cannot function legally. Annual human rights reports from international associations, such as Human Rights Watch or Amnesty International, warn us that the situation has not improved. The latest victims of the Government's practices have been, for example, Mrs. Dulce Amanda Durán, threatened to go to jail if she does not give up her work at the Cuban Commission for Human Rights and National Reconciliation; Mr. José Díaz Silva, leader of the opposition movement for a new republic; and priest Jonniel Rodríguez Riverol, who has also suffered physical violence by regime forces. That Cuban commission warns us that in February the number of arbitrary detentions has increased: it has reached 347, which means more than twelve per day. Since the start of the European Union-Cuba dialogues, there has been no progress in the human rights situation, and it is not clear to me what are the expectations of the open human rights dialogue. What I am clear is that we cannot say that the European Union is closer to Cuba and the Cuban people if it turns its back on all that part of society we ignore and that Political Dialogue Agreement is becomes an agreement with purely economic objectives.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (ES) Mr President, I must also start by saying that I do not know exactly what the urgency is due to this debate, given that the Joint Council has not yet met, which is due to meet in May. I agree with the socialist partner that we should have waited for that meeting to make an assessment and then have a debate with the high representative. Unless there are some groups in this House more concerned about torpedoing the Agreement, along the lines of the Trump Administration, than for really looking to the future and trying to make this Agreement a real success, which is what we all want. It is simply for me in this debate to congratulate Mrs Mogherini on her work on this. I believe that the new relationship with Cuba is a success of European diplomacy, one of the greatest successes of this mandate. I congratulate her on her trip, and I would also like to say that I am very pleased with the questions raised for the next Council. He mentioned the area of renewable energies, sustainable agriculture and culture. It seems to me, of course, three areas where progress can be made. And above all, I would like to ask you to insist on the progress of this Agreement and that cooperation can go as far as possible, because we all know, of course, that we have the Trump Administration, which wants to torpedo that Agreement, and it is very important that the European Union... (the chairman withdrew the floor).

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (PT) Mr President, Cuba and its people have been victims for almost six decades of an aggravating criminal blockade, with brutal impacts and consequences. No area or sector is spared. Nevertheless, the Cuban people have affirmed with determination and confidence the sovereign choice to fulfil the values of the revolution for the development of the country. It is from this collective effort and an incomparable capacity for resilience and overcoming that Cuba has achieved remarkable and recognized advances, particularly in medicine — achievements that few countries in Latin America or even Europe have achieved, especially if thought in the context of the atrocious aggression that the blockade represents. The European Union, now Cuba's second largest trading partner, must contribute to the overthrow of this blockade and consolidate the dialogue and cooperation agreement, ensuring ratification by all Member States with a view to cementing relations between the two parties on the basis of mutual respect. The European Parliament should value the positive advances in bilateral relations between the two parties and contribute to their success.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, whilst the collapse of the Soviet Union heralded an advance in democracy, in individual liberty and economic wealth unprecedented in human history, as we know, its ideology lingered on in some quarters. Having visited Cuba and knowing how warm and welcoming the people are, I was pleased to see the thawing of relations between the Western world and Cuba, led by the United States. They have suffered for too long under a dictatorial communist government, and I have no doubt that their reintegration into the global system will highlight once again the benefits of the Western liberal order. Madam High Commissioner, if the EU is to help in the process of reintegration it must do so by working with the Cuban people in a fair and equitable manner, and not impose the usual neo-colonialist trade agreement that benefits the few and penalises the majority. Mr President, it is my fervent hope that as Cuba develops the last echelons of this particularly nasty brand of Socialism practised in Venezuela, North Korea and elsewhere will likewise follow suit.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, as previous speakers have already pointed out, the signing of the political dialogue and cooperation agreement established a new legal framework for the relations between the European Union and Cuba, while maintaining our EU’s interests. The agreement attempts to support human rights, to improve the living conditions and social rights of Cuban citizens, and to strengthen trade between the EU and Cuba. So far so good. But, obviously, the success of this agreement depends on its implementation and compliance with it. In my opinion, we should not just focus on economic relations, but work systematically in promoting the values of democracy and human rights, including the rule of law and good governance. I would like to point out that, in the past 15 years, this European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize three times to Cubans who fought for fundamental human rights. The Castro regime represses nearly all forms of political dissent; its rank of freedom of expression is among the worst in the world. Just to point out one recent example: last Wednesday, the former Presidents of Colombia and Bolivia, Andrés Pastrana and Jorge Quiroga, tried to travel to Havana to receive an award on behalf of a democratic initiative of Spain and the Americas. They were detained at Havana airport and denied entry to Cuba. With these actions, the Castro regime once again unsuccessfully tries to silence the voice of freedom and democracy in the country. A final remark: I regret, especially after the adoption of the European Parliament’s July 2017 resolution, that it has so far not been possible to organise a visit of a Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) delegation to Cuba. Those responsible sit in Havana. (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: question of “blue card”. — I would like to ask you what human rights you are talking about, because I would like you to tell me whether you know that in the Spanish State there are political prisoners and whether you know that in the Spanish State the right to housing and the right to health are seriously questioned.

name: David McALLISTER
text: blue-card answer. – Honourable colleague, I don’t know whether you expect an answer to this kind of question. I think it is completely inappropriate to compare the situation in a democracy like Spain, a valued Member State of the European Union, with a regime in Havana led by the Castros, who have been suppressing people for decades. There are political prisoners and much more. You should go to Cuba and look for yourself at what a devastating state this country is in. How dare you ask a question like that!

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Mr President, I do not know if the intention of bringing this debate here today was to question Mrs Mogherini's work and the agreement that the European Union signed with Cuba, but if so, I really have to say, on behalf of our group, that we would like to congratulate the High Representative on her work and we would like to congratulate the High Representative on her work, and we would like to congratulate the Agreement that we are we did with Cuba. I think this is an important agreement. The question is not whether there are human rights or not in Cuba, but how we defend that human rights are guaranteed in Cuba, how do we secure freedoms, and this Agreement is precisely in that direction. Ladies and gentlemen, the United States has just retreated, Mr Castro is leaving next month and the European Union has an agreement with Cuba. And, in that context, that Agreement does is open relations. Europe is a friend of Cuba and that friend from Cuba is going to open up its democracy and will open up its technologies; it will open up its economies and businesses. The idea is that this Agreement favors the development of these ideas and rights, does not harm them. Because those who question this Agreement, what do they want? Back to the blockade? Do those who are defending human rights and freedoms in Cuba believe that with the embargo on Cuba or turning their backs on Cuba those rights will be guaranteed? Is it not, on the contrary, what we are doing in Europe and what Mrs Mogherini is doing that favors the development of freedoms and rights for Cubans?

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I say to the Vice-President that you have referred to friends in Cuba. Well, I have also met friends, but very different from the ones that you spoke of. Our representatives of 30 organisations, including those that hold the Sakharov Prize, have come up with a declaration which I will read out to you, at least the major part of the content. ‘Through this declaration we manifest our total rejection of the spurious and anti-democratic process that is about to take place in our country of birth. In these Cuban elections, millions of Cubans who reside outside the island are not allowed to vote. For those within Cuba, the choice is limited to the one and only candidate listed for each available position. That leaves Cuban citizens, of course, with no freedom of choice. We also recognise that the most important issue in the process of Cuban democratisation is the holding of free elections with a plurality of political parties and programmes allowed to compete on equal terms. Cubans within the island and those abroad should be allowed to participate and the elections should be held in the presence of supervision of international observers. We appeal to High Representative / Vice President Mogherini to finally and unconditionally support the plea for free and democratic elections.’ (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Telička! I didn't warn you because you were a lot over time. But you spoke way too fast. It is impossible for the interpreters to translate. You should take this into account as someone who occasionally leads the session.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: Mr President, we welcome the progress of the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation signed between the European Union and Cuba, because this Agreement definitely buries the infamous Common Position of those who do not want normal relations but surrender. This Agreement is a good example of the good development of international relations, when they are addressed from respect for sovereignty, peer dialogue and the umbrella of the Charter of the United Nations. It is also an example of what can be achieved by a European Union that does not follow the unilaterality of the United States and is committed to an independent foreign policy. Let us hope that the meeting of the first Joint Council in May will deepen that path, and we hope that this model of international relations will replace the interference drift of disrespect with other countries in the region, such as Venezuela.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Mr President, the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement gives the opportunity for better cooperation between the European Union and Cuba in the future. We should continue to promote such dialogue but in a responsible way, with focus on the sustainable development, democracy and human rights. Our aim is to stimulate reforms in this country but their actual implementation is no less important. Respect for human rights in Cuba remains our biggest concern. An improvement in this area will be necessary in order to achieve the proper implementation of the agreement between Cuba and the EU. The agreement still needs to be ratified by all the Member States. So, we have time to observe the ongoing reforms and, if necessary, to put additional pressure on the Cuban authorities. I believe that the EU-Cuba Cooperation Agreement opens up a new space for improved relations. But the European Union must keep its human rights and fundamental freedoms as a basis of this new relationship. Substantial improvements must become a condition for further talks with the Cuban Government. If we want Cuba to become a modern country, this process must begin with respect of their fundamental rights and freedoms. Hence, the EU policy towards Cuba must remain conditional on democratic changes in this area.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Mr President, the conclusion of a dialogue and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Cuba was in itself a positive act, which, I am convinced, gives rise to the majority support of Europeans and can help to strengthen political, economic and commercial relations with a country with which we have strong historical links and which are of significant strategic importance. Now, there's one thing I need to say. These advances cannot mean forgetting those in Cuba who continue to be victims of the repression of a highly authoritarian system, which has given no signs of openness from a political point of view. On the contrary, as has already been said, there are still situations of completely arbitrary prisons, freedom of expression is completely undermined, the right of association does not exist and there are many men and women of culture, in this culture, around which we want to engage in dialogue with Cuba, there are many men and women of culture who, for the simple reason of disagreeing with the regime, have seen their voice silenced. The expectations that changes in recent years could lead to a greater openness of the regime have so far been completely questioned. That is why the European Union must, in my view, invest in increasing this relationship, but at the same time it must be an absolute demand for respect for human rights, because these are systematically called into question in Cuba.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President! I also think that dialogue is better than no dialogue, especially if you have different views. I have also been opposed to US sanctions for a long time, and I also support what we have already put in place in projects. But I think this is more than just expanding the space for civil society. Nor is it about human rights abstractly, but specifically about civil rights. Cubans belong to a nation that really belongs to the European cultural area, speaks Spanish and should also develop a tradition in genuine democracy. The country is the only country in the Western Hemisphere where opposition per se is illegal. And you can't do that! I think that if we correctly criticise Venezuela and the regime there, then we should criticise Cuba all the more, because in Venezuela the opposition is suppressed, but it is not illegal per se. I think what we experienced on 11 March, this election farce was a step backwards and was not a step into the future. This has been an expression of political immaturity in which these people are kept there. I saw a picture of Reuters, where two young pioneers, maybe 10 years old, stood in hab-eight position next to the ballot boxes and received the voters there. That's something that really reminds me of the past. I ask you, do you meet with the opposition at this meeting? Are you prepared to specifically demand that the next election be a democratic election? That would be a specific question.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime, to reiterate — it has already been said but I want to reiterate it too — how this instrument we have adopted here, ratified last summer, as is a fundamental tool, colleagues. Fundamental for so many reasons, some of merit, which have been well illustrated by Commissioner Mogherini, but also for other reasons a little deeper, I would like to say. Because history has taught us that isolation always helps extremism and never helps populations who are always penalized by the absence of dialogue. And for another important reason in the same way, I believe, because dialogue is the only way to strengthen positive trends and to counter negative trends, even more so in the field of human rights. So, I can only express appreciation — thanks, I would like to say even — to Commissioner Mogherini for the important work she has already done, for the new season of reports she has inaugurated, for this capacity for strong dialogue, because I mean — and I have closed — dialogue is the only possibility... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement with Cuba put an end to an exceptional situation: the lack of such an agreement with the island. The next meeting of the Joint Council, Mrs Mogherini, takes place at a very special time, just when the veteran leaders of the revolution are being relieved. In my view, the changes in the top offices should go further: they should entail, promote political and economic changes in Cuba, changes that bring it closer to the principles and standards that Europeans consider universal and which, in any case, are already the majority in Latin America — I mean multiparty democracy, respect for fundamental rights, the rule of law, the open economy and also the social State. This dialogue in the Joint Council must promote the interests of the Union and its citizens and also those of Cuban citizens, without abdicating our principles and values. That is why human rights must be present on its agenda — and it is enough to quote one figure, already mentioned by Mr Luis de Grandes: the figure of Eduardo Cardet, an opposition leader who is still in detention after fifteen months. Cuban citizens are very close to Europeans. I remember the large number of people of Spanish origin and from my Galician land residing in Cuba. It is logical that I want for them everything I want for us, that is, the framework of freedoms and welfare which Europeans generally enjoy. This is the Parliament of the Sakharov Prize for Freedom of Expression, which has so often awarded Cuban citizens — three times, if I remember well. I trust that this fact, Mrs Mogherini, will serve as a guide, an inspiring force in your forthcoming dialogue with the Cuban authorities.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Mr President, the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA) between the EU and Cuba can be seen as a new chapter in EU-Cuba relations. This agreement provides for enhanced political dialogue, improved bilateral cooperation and joint action in multilateral fora. For the EU, the PDCA is a tool for supporting a process of change and modernisation in Cuba. For Cuba, it represents the so-called normalisation of the relationship with important and economic and trade partners and helps to diversify its external obligations. The forthcoming EU-Cuba joint ministerial council is an important gathering which should aim to discuss important political issues, trade and investment, as much as human rights. Economic, political and social modernisation is vitally important for the country. However, protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms must go hand in hand with placing EU-Cuba relations on a higher level. We know that the human rights situation is getting worse. Violations of freedom of religion or belief in Cuba have been on a steep rise. In this situation, the EU cannot be sidelined. The possibility of applying human rights clauses as an integral part of the agreement must be clearly and openly discussed during the Joint Council meeting. And the EU should raise the question of religious freedom in Cuba and should encourage Cuba to fully ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, relations between the European Union and Cuba could be a new historic opportunity for both sides, provided that the European Union is prepared to pursue a new framework of cooperation. In the economic sphere, cooperation must be based on mutual benefit and fair trade. The European Union should not seek to establish a new colonial regime in Cuba. The Cuban people have suffered from colonialism for centuries and have shown how they react. Cooperation, peaceful coexistence, respect for national sovereignty and the principle of non-interference in Cuba's internal affairs must be strengthened at political level. Of course we need to consolify democracy in Cuba and strengthen human rights. However, the defence of human rights must not be an alibi for the West to impose solutions from the outside and to reverse the situation which the Cuban people themselves have developed and shaped.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, 'let's be realistic and do the impossible, 'said Che Guevara. The Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation, Madam Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative, is a historic moment because it opens up a new chapter in relations of reciprocity, and that is why we also congratulate it. Finally, the European Commission ceases to follow a dark position, as was promoted by President Aznar — the one in the photo of the trio of the Azores — because Cuba does not need tutelage, but a new cycle that begins. The lifting of the blockade is an example. Europe must not be the international champion of any blockade. Moreover, Cuba ceases to be the only country in Latin America and the Caribbean that does not have a bilateral relationship with the European Union.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: Mr President, of course, this Agreement must serve to consolidate stable relations between Cuba and the European Union within the framework of international law and the Charter of the United Nations, within the framework of legality, respect for the sovereignty of States, and within the framework of the values and principles set out in policy outside this Union. From my group, we wish to see continued steps towards the normalization of political and trade relations, respect for Cuba as an international political subject, its own identity, and respect for its economic and social model as an alternative way to capitalism. Finally, Mrs Mogherini, I ask you to always keep in mind the words you said during your recent visit to Havana, because the European Union, in its foreign policy, must build bridges and open doors through cooperation and dialogue: it is the only way and the only diplomacy. Cheer up.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, in January 1959 the movement of 26 July overthrew the Batista regime and initiated the first socialist state in Latin America. Today, nearly 60 years later, Cuba is preparing to open a new chapter in its history. The EU-Cuba Cooperation and Dialogue Agreement is a first goal towards a future of closeness between Cubans and Europeans, a strong signal of sustainable development and collaboration against Donald's short-sighted policy Trump, dogged to perpetuate an anachronistic bloqueo with unacceptable consequences. I therefore agree, High Representative, with the words you said in Havana: we must build bridges and open doors through cooperation and dialogue, enabling Cuba to emerge from isolation and open up to the world. Our hand is outstretched, but let's remember that it is a two-step. The European Union expects concrete answers from Cuba, facts and not words, especially in respect of human rights and the role of civil society, which must be able to operate freely. It will be up to us parliamentarians to monitor that the rudder bar remains straight towards defending the rights of Cuban citizens.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, many of you referred to Cuban civil society, and I agree that it has a critical role to play and to fulfil in cooperation with our delegation. Indeed it is not true and it has never been true that we do not have bilateral relations between the European Union and Cuba. There is a Cuban Ambassador in Brussels who is accredited to the European Union, and our delegation is active in Havana and all over the island, not only for diplomatic exchanges, but also for running the various projects, including the humanitarian and development projects that we run on the island. We definitely have a strong and active diplomatic channel and presence, both of Havana in Brussels and of the European Union in Havana. Through our delegation in Havana, the role of civil society is constantly being encouraged. Meetings and regular exchanges take place. I myself, during a recent visit and previous visits, have always managed to meet members of civil society, although my visits were always extremely short. As many of you have said, that it is clear that our ideas, principles and practices in terms of human rights and democracy are different. This is no mystery. Isolation has never proven to be a way to encourage positive development. What can encourage positive development and channel our approach, our principles and our expectations is a strong, open, frank and constructive dialogue based not only on respect, but also on very clear messages that we never hide. It is more communication and more cooperation that will bring about positive developments, including in the area of fundamental freedoms. It is no mystery that Cuba, the Member States and the European Union as a whole have different political systems; this is obvious to all of us. The role of civil society and the issue of human rights and fundamental freedoms are part of our dialogue and our common work. One key element of the agreement we have is also the formalisation of the human rights dialogue. This is also one of the reasons why this Parliament approved and backed the agreement we negotiated. As I said, isolation has failed over decades to bring any positive developments, either in the island, or in our relations, including as regards relations between the European Union and the region. Some of you referred to the fact that Cuba also has a regional role in the Caribbean and in Latin America. Having this channel of dialogue open can be useful and helpful. Isolation, on the contrary, has traditionally strengthened conservative forces. This is why we all consider it important that this agreement has entered into force and why this Parliament gave its consent last year to adopt this historical agreement, which the Member States by unanimity adopted it. This is the expectation with which we enter into this process. Some of you rightly mentioned: now we have the agreement and the institutional backing on the European side to this agreement, we know all the opportunities and challenges are still in front of us. We simply have the instruments to enter into a different phase. The point is now to implement this agreement using this instrument, and I count on this Parliament to accompany this process as we proceed with the implementation of the agreement in all its different sectors, which also means holding the first Joint Council in May. When I was in Havana in January, we also discussed opening different sectoral dialogues, exploring the different opportunities that open up, as well as addressing the difficulties we might have, including the formulation of the human rights dialogue. I would expect that this Parliament will accompany us in this implementation phase, keeping clear our perspectives, our differences and our points of convergence. Let me finish by supporting very much what David McAllister, Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET), mentioned about the opportunity to have an AFET delegation visiting Cuba. I raised this personally with the Cuban authorities during my visit in January, including with the President of the National Assembly of the Parliament there, who welcomed this idea. Obviously, I will continue to encourage a move in this direction, because I believe that contacts need to be deepened in respect of the differences and in openness of the differences at all levels – institutions, civil society, human rights activists and the Parliament have an important role to play here. I thank you for this debate and I thank you most of all for the work you will continue to do to accompany me in the implementation of this agreement.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the basis of the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the new agenda for EU-Central Asia relations at the 13th annual ministerial meeting (2018/2526 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, last summer, the Council of the European Union asked me and the Commission to propose a new EU strategy on Central Asia, to be adopted next year. As you might know, a few months ago, during my second visit to the region, I visited three of the five Central Asian countries. I was in Samarkand, where we had a very positive EU-Central Asia ministerial meeting. We have that ministerial meeting every year, which proves to be extremely useful and I am glad for the European Parliament’s continuous contribution to our work and also for your efforts to put this issue on the agenda, where it should be. Central Asia is often perceived as a remote part of the world but, in fact, Europe and the five Central Asian countries are now closer than ever. I believe this is more important now than before. Their neighbourhood is our neighbourhood. The Silk Road is not only a literary memory of the past, but one of the most important global infrastructure projects. Central Asia is, even more than in the past, a crossroads between Europe and the Far East, between Russia and South East Asia. Events in Afghanistan or in the Middle East are as important for us as for our partners in Central Asia. Their security is clearly also our security. We see clearly that, as the world is changing, this region is changing, too. Free elections and peaceful transitions of power are becoming a more regular feature. Central Asia has become more independent and stronger, a partner for the East and for the West, not the chessboard for some great game among empires. Today, Central Asian countries are seeking a closer partnership with the European Union. This is the clear message I got from all the leaders and ministers I have met from the region, especially in the last year: they are eager to deepen and increase cooperation with the European Union in all the different sectors. I believe this is a political will and the political signal we should get. They see us, the European Union, as a reliable, predictable, cooperative power with no hidden geopolitical agenda. And they see us as an indispensable partner for sustainable development and for modernisation. I would like to focus on three aspects of our relationship where we have already achieved a lot and where I see a lot of potential for greater progress. First, we are partners for change. For instance, we have supported Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Kazakhstan on their way to joining the World Trade Organisation, and we want to do the same for Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan. European companies are keen to invest in the region, to the benefit of both the European Union and Central Asia, and improving the business environment is an interest we share. Also, to this end, we have launched a new generation of enhanced partnership and cooperation agreements. We signed one with Kazakhstan, we are negotiating one with Kyrgyzstan, and we look forward to opening negotiations soon with Uzbekistan. These agreements are also an incentive for domestic reforms, in line with international values, norms and standards, so I hope that the European Parliament will soon give its consent to the ratification of our Partnership and Cooperation Agreement with Turkmenistan. When we talk about change, it is not just about business. I want to be very clear on this. It is, first and foremost, about expanding rights all around the region for the sake of the people of Central Asia. With independent media and an open space for civil society, institutions in Central Asia will be more credible, states will be more resilient in times of crisis, and economists would be more solid and attractive. Uzbekistan and Kyrgyzstan are engaged in important reform processes. We want to accompany them on this path. This is what I discussed during my visit last December, if I am not mistaken, to both countries and we want to work for that example to be followed by others in the region. Second, we are partners for regional cooperation. Central Asia remains one of the least integrated regions in the world. In Samarkand I saw great interest in our European experience on how to solve common problems through regional cooperation. Central Asia faces many challenges that no single country can address alone, from water scarcity to the fight against international trafficking, from trade to the issue of foreign terrorist fighters and the radicalisation of, especially, the younger generations. When it comes to intercontinental trade routes, Central Asian countries want to be more than just transit countries. They hope that these big infrastructure projects will bring sustainable development to their countries and support trade within the region, not only through the region. These are demands we can only support. It is also for this reason that I intend to present to the October Foreign Affairs Council a new strategy on connecting Europe to Asia. It will highlight the key principles which we believe should guide international work to promote connectivity. This new strategy will aim to give our partners, including Central Asian countries, more than one choice. It should help them avoid the debt trap and the trap of poor-quality projects. Last, but not least, the third sector of cooperation. The European Union and Central Asia are partners for security. We have a shared interest in supporting, for instance, an Afghan-led and Afghan-owned peace process. Uzbekistan will co-host a regional conference on Afghanistan at the end of March, in a few weeks from now. This is essential for our own security, and I will be there, personally, with the Afghan Government, with our Central Asian partners and with all our international interlocutors. International cooperation is the only way to tackle challenges that are cross-border by definition, such as radicalisation or the phenomenon of foreign terrorist fighters. We cooperate on border management with Central Asian countries and we have recently decided to deploy an EU counter-terrorism expert to Central Asia, who will be based in Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan. We will also participate in the high-level regional conference on counter-terrorism which Tajikistan will be hosting in early May. It is quite clear, also from the debates we have had previously, that we live in a world that is moving fast but not always in the right direction, which is quite dangerous and challenging. We are probably living in the most delicate moment since the end of the Cold War and there is very little space for positive news. Still, when I travel to a region like Central Asia I see more opportunities to take than threats to tackle: opportunities for change, for democratic perspectives, for economic growth and for cooperation on the different sectors I have mentioned now. This will be the core of our work, and our new strategy that the Council asked for, and the European Parliament has an important role to play in this process. So let us invest together in this partnership because security and development in Central Asia is also our own security and development.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Central Asia has the potential to be a major gateway between Europe and Asia with a growing market and significant potential for investment and trade, so the EU’s new Strategy for Central Asia should provide a more forward-looking and goal-oriented vision and supporting tools. It would also help to respond adequately and timely to current challenges such as the ongoing democratisation processes in the region, fighting terrorism and extremism, as well as environmental issues.  In general, over the past years the geo-political environment has changed significantly in the region. The US has lost prestige, and its presence and its interest is decreasing in the region. The European Union, in spite of losing a bit of attraction because of the financial and refugee crisis and Brexit, can stay as active as China and Russia in the region – of course, not in a similar scope yet, but the EU is still key to Central Asia and its future.  Two new regional initiatives, China’s OBOR and the Russian-led Eurasian Economic Union, are taking the lead in investment and could potentially transform Central Asia’s political landscape, so the necessary instruments should be implemented in Central Asian countries in order to keep Russia’s and China’s political and economic influence under control. The EU should focus on realistic initiatives that fit with the existing regional projects, and the EU needs to be more actively present in each country of Central Asia in order to address the emerging geopolitical challenges and expand cooperation with the countries of the region.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, there is too little good news in the world at the moment, and a small glimmer of hope is now contained in this area of Central Asia and development. Exactly, when High Representative Mogherini said, there is a desire for cooperation and stability in the region. That is very important in this day and age. This key EU strategy is therefore important in its desire to commit more countries in the region to this whole. I would ask the High Representative whether it could be thought that Russia, with all the problems that currently exist, could also be more involved in this process. Indeed, special attention must be paid to the impartial judiciary, good governance, the implementation of human rights and the standards of the International Organisation for Work ILO. This is an important issue, and there is a lot new here.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — President State! Post-Soviet Asia is a very important region, a diverse region, though maybe we're not talking enough about it. There are five former Soviet republics and there is also Mongolia, which was not formally part of the Soviet Union. This is a country that is fought for — there is nothing to hide — a geopolitical war. Turkey's influence is growing there. Once a host in Brussels, a representative of the parliament of one of these countries told me: well, one Turkish nation and two states: Turkish and just his. Iran's influence is growing. Our European influence is vital. There are also American influences. The only question is if they aren't maybe a little smaller than they were. And there are Russian influences too, although I think they are getting smaller than they used to be. It is an economically important region. It is also a region relevant in our relationship in the context of China.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. — Mr. President, Madam High Representative, the characteristic of the position of Central Asia today is the negative legacy of Soviet times, undeveloped democratic institutions, uncompetitive economy, environmental problems, incline between two great powers, China and Russia, whose geostrategic interests do not have to be consistent with the progress and prosperity of Central Asia, economic and energy dependence on Russia and exposure to instability and terrorism from the South. I support the Commission's statements and the Council's conclusions on Central Asia, especially those concerning encouraging the use of renewable sources, increasing energy efficiency, strengthening the fight against terrorism, effective border protection, full use of the educational initiative, and I think that we should especially emphasize the necessary assistance from the European Union in the peaceful resolution of open issues and disputes that exist among the five Central Asian countries. However, I would like to commend the prevailing positive tone that the High Representative, pointing to all the problems, nevertheless expressed when she spoke about the prospects and potentials of Central Asia. But much changed in 2007, when the strategy of relations between the European Union and Central Asia was adopted. China is much more ambitious and robust today, Russia has a more aggressive policy, and the threats to terrorism are far greater than they were those in 2007. I therefore support the Council's request and the position of Parliament to adopt a new strategy for the relationship between Central Asia and the European Union as soon as possible.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative. The Joint Communiqué of Samarkand shows that the successful development of the new Central Asia Strategy requires at least two breaks compared to the EU's previous policy: If the new strategy is to emerge together with the Central Asian partner countries as desired, this can only be achieved through a balance of interests that will be achieved. depicts the concrete challenges and framework conditions of both sides. The current approach, which is primarily aimed at enforcing and safeguarding primarily economic interests, is not a model of success. If the new strategy — as stated in the Council document — is to be genuinely aligned with the SDGs, then our view on the level of development of the countries must inevitably change. It will then be less a question of the state of infrastructure and the availability of natural resources, but rather about the relationship that will make a relevant contribution to the solution of the existing serious socio-economic and environmental problems, as well as to modernisation and modernisation of natural resources. democratization of societies and the state.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, do we have to deal with Central Europe and make Member States and their citizens pay perhaps the price of our failures? Because we risk failure. We have no skills to deal with a complex area worked by Islamism and at the crossroads of the big game between Russia, America, Iran, India and China. Afghanistan's bitter failure is a testament to this. Furthermore, we have no legitimacy to interfere in those areas which are not European of culture or history and have no reason to become so. We also risk failure if we have the same deadly logic as that of the Eastern Partnership in the Caucasus, where the European Union has tried to uproot nations from their historical environment, or in Ukraine. On the other hand, we must bring our stone to the economic development of the region in a balanced way, because if we remain in these previous logic, we risk a catastrophic assessment of external action again.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, in the past few years the relations between the EU and five Central Asian partners have intensified. This is documented not only by the frequency of high-level meetings, but also by the amount of upgraded agreements that this House has passed. I think it is an encouraging development, notably in regard to the new EU Central Asia Strategy anticipated next year. The EU should continue in this trend of active engagement with the region. It has a unique balancing position in Central Asia, and is perceived as a positive force. Our bilateral relations should focus on common security challenges, supporting the resilience of partners, enhancing our economic relations and backing regional cooperation. Particular attention should be dedicated to improving the rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms in five countries. The EU should be clear of the areas where improvement is needed and should stand ready to assist.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Central Asia is an evolving region, a strategic partner for Europe. It is an area where our action can make a difference, in which we have achieved several results, such as the almost eradication of child labour in Uzbekistan in the textile sector, also thanks to the work of this Parliament. In view of the new strategy, in addition to economic and trade opportunities, which have just been consolidated by the ratification of the partnership with Kazakhstan, we must continue cooperation on consolidation institutions, the fight against corruption, but above all we need renewed attention to social aspects and human rights, on which there is still much to be done, as the many cases of persecution show politics. For example, I think of Maks Bokaev and Iskander Erimbetov, referring to Kazakhstan. A stable and resilient Central Asia is crucial, given also the security challenges posed by the Afghan border, or by water control clashes, for example. From this point of view, the new impetus in infraregional cooperation is certainly to be encouraged and is Europe's interest.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, since the collapse of the Soviet Union, the Central Asian region has been consolidating itself as a kind of emerging subcontinent. Its geographical location, its huge natural and economic resources, as well as the challenges it faces, make it an area of considerable interest to the European Union. And I welcome the interest — as you have told us, Mrs Mogherini — that exists in the region for the European Union, and that work is under way to renew the European Union Strategy for Central Asia in 2019. We must continue to accompany these countries in their reforms towards political and economic modernization. They are countries, I was going to say, in transition. Some of its challenges have already been recalled here: improvement in terms of democratic governance, security and the rise of jihadism, illicit trafficking, natural resources — both energy and water — and their management. We can help in all this, and we must continue to promote their regional integration and strengthen our presence and visibility there. The European Union must persevere in its position as a global actor, in particular in those nearby regions — our neighbours — given that what happens there has a direct impact on our daily lives. We see it in the case of the Sahel, the Middle East, and we see it also in the case of Central Asia.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini. Thank you for your commitment to Central Asia. For too long, that has been a white spot on the political map here in Europe. We have heard of the zones of influence around the world, Russia, Turkey, Iran and China in particular. There is, of course, direct and massive influence. You say that the Heads of Government welcome a closer partnership with us. But what do we have to offer? We are a SoftPower, we urge them to reform, more democracy, more human rights, and China is making the big investments. So, in addition to SoftPower, is there anything else we can offer these countries? From the eastern neighbourhood we need to learn that we look at the countries individually. I believe that we need tailor-made programmes for each country. I would also like to welcome what you said, however, that we are strengthening regional cooperation. We have done this successfully in Africa, and we can also do this in Central Asia: to offer the countries there the example of the EU, then they will be stronger overall.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: – Mr President, I first want to thank Ms Mogherini for her statement on Turkmenistan. As rapporteur for Turkmenistan, I can only express my concerns on the situation in this country: lack of respect for human rights, corruption and low democratic standards. Such topics are indeed sensitive and difficult to approach through direct talks, producing little or no result through the classic diplomatic tools. A constant new presence in Turkmenistan would be constructive and efficient, more than isolation, if we want to achieve our goals and not just talk about them. Most of my colleagues share this position, and this is why the European Parliament has already requested a fully-fledged delegation in Ashgabat. If we all consider that a Partnership and Cooperation Agreement (PCA) with Turkmenistan as a legal support will offer a strong platform for constructive relations, then I can only ask High Representative Ms Mogherini to give us full support to achieve this goal as soon as possible.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, the European Union strategy for Central Asia, which is currently under revision, must become a strong instrument for our foreign policy. The security challenges in this region are also our security challenges, and we need to work collectively against Islamic radicalisation. Among the five countries, only Kazakhstan has an enhanced partnership and cooperation agreement, which includes strong provisions on security. I hope that in the near future we will be able to develop similar agreements with the remaining four countries.  High Representative Ms Mogherini, I know that during your last visit to Samarkand you laid the basis for the creation of common counter-terrorism action, and we really appreciate your diplomatic efforts in this. Indeed, there is no place for geopolitical competition when we speak about security—building, because China, Russia and Afghanistan all have a role to play in it, and I am sure today that you have enough diplomatic leverage to promote regional security cooperation.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Central Asia is a kind of subregion that would seem to have been left to itself, or at least to Russia and China. Little has changed there since the Soviet Union, especially on body issues. There are dictatorships, authoritarian governments, there is no democracy. By contrast, they are rich in different resources: not only gas and oil, but also metal ores, also precious metals. The nations and communities of these states deserve to join the family of the democratic nations of the world. For this to happen, there is no doubt that the cooperation of the European Union has to be increased with these countries. This is the only path towards democracy. Economic cooperation, as it will serve the communities and peoples of these states.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, I have listened very carefully to your speech. I like as much as some colleagues that you are trying to strengthen cooperation with the countries of Central Asia. I consider this very important because, as already said here, today there is growing interest from the great powers in this region and we should not leave this region to China and Russia and we should be in this region economically much more engaged. That's the first reason. The second reason was also mentioned here, that is the question of the danger of terrorism. If we let Central Asia be, it may happen to us in the future that many more young jihadists will be recruited in this area, that Islamic radicalism will grow here, and that there is already a specific threat to Europe. So the theses of some colleagues who say that we may not be interested in this region, that it does not impact Europe. In terms of international security, this is, in short, an area that potentially, if we don't care, may be a risk for us. So I welcome your higher activity and please continue it further.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the thirteenth annual ministerial meeting of the European Union with the countries of Central Asia really is an interesting meeting; it has to deal with serious issues — and, when we talk about the countries of Central Asia, we are talking about rich countries with natural gas, oil, minerals, but at the same time with poor peoples. Of course, the agenda must also address political dialogue with respect for the sovereignty of these States and peaceful coexistence, the economy, with the aim of mutual benefit and fair trade, but at the same time measures must be taken to strike crime and corruption, imposing conditions for the implementation of labour law, banning child labour, providing environmental protection and at the same time a comprehensive strategy to tackle jihadism and Islamic extremism.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, very briefly because I’ve seen that there’s large convergence among you, amongst us, on the need to continue to invest strategically in our relations with Central Asia – as a region to increase their regional cooperation, but also with each individual country of the five. I am determined to continue to do so. I have seen, as I said in the beginning, clearly a trend in these last three years in all our ministerial meetings, in all the bilateral meetings I’ve had with them – Presidents and Foreign Ministers – that the intention from their side is to do more with us in all fields.  I will only say that I count on your support to continue doing this. I commit to doing this more and more in all the different fields from the economic to human rights and rule of law, to security and to regional developments, including the security issue, the geo-political dynamics, the crossroads between east and west and north and south, and obviously also on sustainable development and own resources, including water.  There is one question I would like to answer: what can we offer? What I have seen, what they expect us to offer, is the European way, is the standards, is the quality. They know I believe that this comes in a package. It’s European standards on human rights and rule of law. It’s European standards on economic investments and business climate and rules of the game for the economic environment. It’s European standards and the European way on the way in which institutions work. It’s the European way in which society develops.  The feeling I have is that they would like to take the European Union as a model for their societies, for their economies, for their regional relations, for their security models. They know it’s a long way, but this is the direction I feel they intend to follow, without necessarily being trapped into the geo—political spheres of influence competition, but being able to move towards that kind of European way that we could offer. It is somehow a declination of the soft power we have, but it’s also very concrete. It’s true that from other places money could come more easily, but I think countries around the world, and in Central Asia included, are starting to realise that it is not necessarily the money that comes easily which is the best investment long term. I think this is the thing we can offer, which is sometimes complicated but always worthwhile trying.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – As you know EU-Central Asia relations are developed under the EU strategy for Central Asia signed in 2007 and reviewed in 2015. For nearly 11 years this EU strategy has played a vital role in reforming Central Asian states and making them important partners of the EU. Progress achieved in the countries under the partnership with the EU should be saved and build up. Therefore, I believe that the EU has to create and implement a new agenda which will develop stronger relations between EU and Central Asia states through strengthen dialogue and cooperation on important topics for both sides such as human rights, education, development, environment and security, particularly in the context of endless conflict in Afghanistan and growing threat of terrorism and Islamic fundamentalism in the region. In this context, it is important to note that region’s stability and prosperity can be achieved only through active participation of the EU and its readiness to cooperate with Central Asia states on common challenges and interests. The new EU strategy towards the region should be based on this assumption.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The next item on the next item is the joint debate on፦ the report by Hugues Bayet, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Annual Growth Survey for 2018 (2017/2226 (INI)) (A8-0047/2018), and - the Krzysztof report Hetman, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Social and Employment Aspects of the Annual Growth Survey 2018 (2017/2260 (INI)) (A8-0052/2018).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank all those who negotiated this text and made it possible to achieve this result. Thanks to Tom, Bernd, Caroline, Miguel and Bas. As you know, the report on the European Semester that we are going to vote tomorrow is a breakthrough on the economic and budgetary policy to be pursued and provides solutions in order to reduce the increase in socio-economic inequalities within the same country and to limit the growth of the phenomenon of poor workers or to move towards a stronger convergence between Member States. I think we can rejoice: the economic situation is improving and a new course is beginning to emerge. This is obviously what is requested in this report and the Commission — which I thank — has included some of our remarks in its country-by-country recommendations. It decided to place more emphasis on integrating the social rights pillar and environmental issues into the guidelines of its recommendations. As we know, the European citizen is in need of a stable and healthy socio-economic climate, the main objective of which must be full employment. Europe remains the richest continent in the world, with still significant development potential, such as energy transition, but it is essential that our socio-economic instruments serve the cause of citizens, their jobs and their well-being. Workers face the impact of the rapid change in the economy every day and, as politicians, we must be able to respond to these changes and accompany them to prevent them from being the first victims of them. That is why we have included in this report a whole series of points, but I would like to highlight five points that I think are major. The first point focuses on the importance and need to increase private and public investment in order to invest in the real economy. Private investment only reaches the 2008 level, public investment is still 40% below the 2008 level. We have also asked the Commission to assess the obstacles to the implementation of major investment projects, which are often public-private partnerships, and to their depreciation over time. Without public investment, for example in terms of infrastructure or health care, there is unfortunately no private investment, and if these two factors are added, there can be no job creation. The second point relates to responsible public finances. Indeed, we insist that the budgetary guidelines, at national and euro area level, must ensure the long-term sustainability of public finances and their sound management. This good management must go hand in hand with an increase in wages. This is a proposal that is also supported by ECB President Mario Draghi, in order to enable workers to have higher purchasing power and thus to revive the economy as a whole, perhaps more effectively than the current measures. Secondly, we discussed the issue of structural reforms, in particular to strengthen the youth guarantee, the importance of education policies, support for microenterprises and to guarantee the sustainability of social security systems. In short, everything that makes the added value of our continent in the face of the rest of the world. Let us not hide, this added value is in danger and we must not only preserve it, but also intensify it so that Europe is once again synonymous with hope for these millions of young people. Of course, we are talking about European tax harmonisation, all the work that has already been done by Parliament and the need to go further, towards a common system of fair corporate taxation and, finally, the last chapter deals with greater integration in the Semester negotiations of the various actors, such as the European Parliament, but also national and/or regional parliaments and the social partners. I really believe that the ownership of the Semester by these different actors is a sine qua non prerequisite for better implementation of country-by-country recommendations. This is obviously just a first step. Other measures still need to be taken, such as reforming the Stability and Growth Pact in order to enable States to reinvest in services to citizens and boost employment. But I think we are on the right track for real economic and social change in Europe, and I hope that this report will have a large majority tomorrow.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! The annual growth analysis formally begins the implementation of the 8th cycle of coordination and management of economic policy of the European Union, the European semester. In its Communication, the Commission proposed priorities on which Member States should focus their attention in implementing national policies and reforms in order to achieve sustainable inclusive growth within the framework of the so-called noble triangle, increasing investment, implementation structural reforms and the provision of adequate budgetary policy. The main signal from this year's report on the annual growth analysis indicates that the European economy is strengthening. After many years of economic slowdown, GDP growth is greater than forecast. Unemployment is falling steadily. The situation in the public finances of the Member States has improved and we are seeing an investment recovery. These positive signals show optimism, so the European Union and individual Member States must seize this favourable moment to continue reform and strengthen the positive trend. There is no doubt that there is still a lot of work ahead. Youth unemployment remains worryingly high at more than 16% all the time. As many as 6.3 million people aged 15—24 are not working or studying. Poverty and social exclusion levels remain high, too. There is an apparent problem with long-term unemployed people returning to the labour market, while as many as 44% of workers lack basic digital skills. We also face a mismatch of employee skills to employers' needs. Please note this paradox. On the one hand, in many places we still have high levels of unemployment, and on the other, entrepreneurs are increasingly reporting the problem of having no hands to work. So far it has been an employer market, now it's an employee's market. And this problem, that is, people still without work and employers seeking workers, it occurs in regions both rich and peripheral. We are also not making the most of the potential of SMEs and new technologies. Meanwhile, we need to be aware that rapidly changing labour markets will require reform and new developments in both education and training and labour organisations. Challenges also include demographic problems and a broad balance between private life and work, including parental leave and childcare, but also a return to the labour market or care for the long-term ill and elderly. I believe that the issues I have listed should be the most important priorities on which Member States must focus their attention in implementing national policies and reforms in order to achieve sustainable inclusive growth. Further intensive action is needed to improve the competitiveness of the European economy and increase the productivity of our businesses. However, we must not forget that a man must be at the heart of our actions, so work to improve the health of the European economy must go hand in hand with the work to strengthen our social policy. I believe that the inclusion of a pillar of social rights in the European semester cycle can be an effective tool for achieving this objective. I therefore hope that the pillar's assumptions will be permanently combined with the recommendations for Member States during the semester. However, I would like to emphasise that even the best formulated objectives and recommendations will not be translated into real positive change if they remain solely on paper. It is therefore essential that Member States improve the level of implementation of the recommendations made during the semester.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, strong economic governance and better policy coordination between the Member States could not be done without the European semester. This year, the process of macroeconomic budgetary and structural policy coordination is particularly important for the Union in the context of the preparation of the next MFF. In this regard, a real synergy between budgetary and monetary policies should be introduced in order to stimulate growth and job creation as well as to revive investments. Ambitious reforms of the euro area governance should be proposed, including the introduction of a special instrument to support the adoption of the euro by the non-euro Member States who have committed themselves to adopting the euro. Important is the evolution of the European Stability Mechanism towards the European Monetary Fund. Public and private investment in infrastructure, research and development, innovation and education should be encouraged in order to achieve the goals of budgetary growth and employment policies. Most effectively, those goals could be achieved implementing a strong and well-resourced cohesion policy. Having in mind the situation with the jobs for young people in the EU, we should underline the importance of the implementation of the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to discuss today the European Semester, a topic of particular relevance in these times. The Council attaches great importance to the Semester, and I am pleased to exchange views with Parliament on this subject.  If we are to make Europe relevant to peoples’ daily lives, we need to achieve good results on growth and jobs, high-quality education, social protection and inclusion, as well as environmental sustainability. We should stress here that it is question of ownership. Implementation of structural reforms under the European Semester is key for strengthening the resilience and potential growth of Member States and the European Union as a whole. An agreement on common objectives is therefore important. Your reports show that we see these common objectives, and I am glad that we have this opportunity to discuss them with you today and that you have done so recently with national parliaments. To start on a positive note, evidence suggests that Europe’s economy is strengthening, employment is growing, investment is recovering and public finances are improving. Yet, clearly, many challenges remain. You have identified a number of them in your reports. While the recovery is turning into expansion and is becoming more broad-based, some Member States still face major structural challenges. High debt levels and high youth unemployment rates remain a source of concern. Also, investment activity has not yet reached the levels we aspire to.  Boosting investment remains a priority in order to promote a more robust recovery and to secure healthy growth rates in the long run. The extension of the European Fund for Strategic Investment in terms of financial capacity is an important step towards achieving this goal. Let us continue to work together to stimulate social investment and human capital, to lift the remaining barriers, and to foster a truly favourable investment climate. Furthermore, we need to support growth with smart fiscal policies while paying close attention to the long-term sustainability of our budgets and debts.  We also need to implement the necessary structural reforms on our product and labour markets in order to prepare our economies for the challenges ahead. We must provide our young citizens with high-quality education and invest in their skills today. The Single Market is a great EU asset, and we should join forces for its further development. During the presidency, we plan on making progress on the initiatives of the Digital Single Market Strategy, as we think digitalisation is crucial for the competitiveness of the industry in the European Union. In view of these challenges, the Bulgarian Presidency has outlined the digital economy and skills for the future as one of our four priorities. We are committed to contributing to the process of completing the Digital Single Market as a source of growth and competitiveness, while also focusing on the development of skills and competences of the 21st century. As we are now leaving crisis times behind us, the legacy of the crisis remains a concern. Some citizens are trapped in a cycle of poverty and social exclusion from which they cannot easily escape. This is an important issue for the presidency. Our policy efforts need to be geared toward those with the most disadvantages. They also need to be geared towards those regions and sectors which are undergoing the most difficulties. We need to think of new solutions to new problems whilst seizing the opportunities ahead of us.  The collaborative economy represents a huge potential, but it cannot be a reason to backtrack on employment and social rights. Employment and social policies need to adapt to the changes in the labour markets, but at the same time workers’ rights should remain protected. Environmental policy, together with the greening economy and greening the European Semester can contribute in a very significant manner to the broad policy objectives of stimulating sustainable growth and creating jobs. The environmental implementation review initiative will be again on the Council’s agenda next year. What is key is to focus on the full implementation of the reforms and to carefully monitor the progress in each Member State. We should share our experiences and use best practices examples to learn from each other. Only by closely working together to constantly push for reforms, and to continuously support inclusive growth and job creation, will we be successful in creating tangible benefits for every citizen and in rebuilding trust in a strong and prosperous European Union.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a pleasure to talk this House today, and a special pleasure because it is nice to be able to bring some good news. This year’s Semester takes place amid steady economic expansion. Europe is seeing the highest growth rate in a decade, investment is picking up, employment is at record levels and the unemployment rate is almost where it was before the crisis. The share of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion fell to the pre-crisis level. Public finances are improving and the banking sector is well capitalised. Our strategy of investment, structural reforms and responsible policies is working.  Still, in some Member States the legacy of the crisis is visible in the high levels of debt and non-performing loans, and in the unemployment rates.
