Indeed, also, the risk of poverty and social exclusion remain high in some countries and 18 million people are seeking a job. We need to use the current good times to strengthen our economic foundations, improve resilience and support convergence.  I take from the two reports on the Annual Growth Survey which we are discussing today, that we share views on the challenges and where the European Union and Member States should focus their efforts. We must make sure that today’s growth is inclusive and sustainable and that our economies and societies are prepared to harness the opportunities and address the challenges that technology and globalisation bring.  So let me thank the two rapporteurs, Mr Bayet and Mr Hetman, and the rapporteur for the Committee on Budgets for these excellent reports.  Raising productivity is the only way to achieve higher living standards and greater prosperity. For this we need investment, not just in infrastructure but also in human capital, research and innovation, and this requires ensuring an investment-friendly environment including by tackling corruption and ensuring respect for the rule of law. Beyond that, only an educated, skilled labour force can seize new opportunities when the labour market changes, and only with proper social security can people make the necessary transitions in the new world of work. Human beings is indeed what Europe is about.  In terms of fiscal policy, we stress the need for the right balance between supporting growth and ensuring sustainable public finances. Good times should be used to build buffers and reduce high debts. Fair, growth-friendly taxation and well-targeted spending remain crucial. The European Semester has proven instrumental for the coordination of policies in the Union. We run it in a spirit of cooperation and partnership. We engage in discussions with the national authorities and stakeholders at national and at European level, including the national parliaments and social partners.  Last week, the Commission issued its assessment of the economic and social challenges for 27 Member States, including the relevant detailed analysis of macroeconomic imbalances. We see that the imbalances are receding in the context of a favourable economic environment. We de—escalated the macroeconomic imbalances procedures for four countries. Slovenia has successfully corrected its imbalances and left the procedure. France and Bulgaria were de—escalated from excessive imbalances to imbalances. So was Portugal, which still needs to address the high levels of public, private and external debt.  We also see that the implementation of country specific recommendations has slightly improved as compared with last May. Since 2011, Member States have made at least some progress on more than two-thirds of their recommendations. When implementing reforms, Member States can count on the support of our Structural and Investment Funds as well as our Structural Reform Support Service.  Last week we adopted the Annual Work Programme for the Structural Reform Support Programme to support 24 Member States, with more than 140 projects.  Maybe the most important message of this Semester is that economic growth and social progress go hand in hand. This year’s Semester is a landmark. Our country reports have never been so social. You know that we proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights at the Social Summit a few months ago, and this is our joint political commitment by the Commission, by the European Parliament and by the Council to move forward with the stronger social Europe. But the success of the pillar depends on the extent to which we implement it at European level, but especially at national level. The Semester is our key instrument to make the principles and rights included in the pillar a reality on the ground.  Following the proclamation, for the first time the principles of the pillar are now embedded in the Semester. To help with monitoring and implementation we have developed, together with the Member States, a social scoreboard with 14 headline indicators that cover the three dimensions of the pillar: equal opportunities and access to the labour market, to education also, dynamic labour markets and fair working conditions and public support, social protection and inclusion.  Ladies and gentlemen, we need to use the good times to build a resilient economy – one that is less vulnerable to economic shocks and more able to respond to them. For this, we need reforms that combine the goals of stability and efficiency with a strong focus on fairness and inclusiveness. That is why we are now starting the second phase of the 2018 European Semester by taking the dialogue to the Member States on the basis of the country reports, and such strengthened dialogue will be very valuable in the preparation for the 2018 set of country specific recommendations in May.

name: Nuno MELO
text: draftsman of the opinion of the ENVI Commission. — (PT) Mr President, I do not wish to repeat recurring arguments every year, I would like to underline an aspect that I insisted on in my report of opinion. Between the years 2000 and 2017, nearly 200 people perished in fires in Portugal. In 2017, more than 440,000 hectares burned, which destroyed areas of forest, businesses, homes and vehicles, in my country alone. Countries like Italy have been regularly shaken by tragic earthquakes that cause countless victims. Northern Europe is experiencing flooding, just as drought is worsening in the south. Since 1980, in addition to the loss of human life, the Member States of the European Union have suffered more than €360 billion in damage due to extreme weather or weather events. Civil protection is precisely one of the areas in which the European Union can and must intervene, with the benefit of all, helping to prevent and combat these phenomena more effectively. As is understood, it is a question of strengthening European reaction capacities and helping Member States facing disasters and whose national capabilities are insufficient. It is something that this purpose makes perfect sense to be considered by the European institutions.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. — Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, the Committee on Regional Development in its opinion welcomes the fact that there is a positive dynamic to promote the continuation of the recovery through economic growth, social cohesion, structural reforms and territorial cohesion. We welcome a better focus on country-specific recommendations, expressing concern about the uneven level of implementation in the Member States. We underline the important role of cohesion policy in the recovery process, as it is the main investment policy in Europe, and I believe that its interaction with the European Semester should be improved in order to increase the additional multiplier impact of investments for cohesion and their contribution to sustainable and inclusive growth. Complementarity and synergy is needed between the Cohesion Funds, the Fund for Strategic Investments and the other Community instruments and programmes, which will contribute to the promotion of investment. Country-specific recommendations should better reflect Member States' specificities. I also stress the role of the programme in supporting structural reforms.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – This year’s annual growth survey takes place in a new political landscape, with the recent adoption of the European pillar of social rights as well as the November communication from the Commission on strengthening European identity through education and culture. I welcome this political shift, but we must make sure it translates into concrete measures and results. The annual growth survey shows an overall reduction of unemployment, a reduction of early school leaving and a rise in high education attainment. This is good news, but we should not be fooled by raw figures: this progress does not benefit people from different social backgrounds in an equal way. Vulnerable young people and young people from lower social and economic backgrounds are still at high risk of unemployment. Their background and postcode still massively impact their educational path, as well as their future economic and professional opportunities. We must ensure that the jobs that are created are of high quality, in line with the ILO’s Decent Work Agenda, and continue to fight precarious employment situations.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. — Mr President, Commissioner Thyssen, Mrs Panayotova. The messages of the Committee on Women's Committees are quite simple and clear. Unemployment, cuts in public expenditure, poverty and social exclusion continue to affect women. It is sad that we still have to demand one thing in 2018. But do not worry, we do not get tired of doing it: equal pay for equal work. And the European Semester must be an instrument for this. However, the gender-sensitive perspective is lacking in the European Semester. Equal treatment and equal opportunities for women and men must be guaranteed and promoted in all areas. This is the second principle of the social pillar, and this must be fully integrated into the European Semester.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Mr Bayet for his good cooperation and his hard work on this report, which he will undoubtedly do until tomorrow's vote. We found a good balance, I think, in this report around three key points: first of all, the report strives for a good balance between public and private investment. Investment can stimulate demand in the short term, which is crucial in the current economic context. Secondly, responsible fiscal policies are essential for sustainable economic growth. If we want to keep public finances under control, we really need to start preparing for the elephant in the room: the growing ageing population. If we do not take our responsibility now and do not make the affordability of pensions and care priority number one, then this is guilty of absenteeism towards every young person in Europe. Thirdly, structural reforms. Productivity-enhancing structural reforms will not only attract investment, but also increase real incomes. Digitisation and technological progress ensure a thorough redesign of our labour market. We must go for dynamic labour markets, supported by accessible social security systems. The Commission shall publish its country-specific recommendations on 23 May. I can only advocate greater involvement of all national parliaments in this process, as well as of the social partners.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, the analysis of the European Semester from the perspective of employment and social affairs gives us the opportunity — a golden opportunity — every year, in this Parliament, to have a shared diagnosis but, above all, to give concrete answers to the situations that Europeans suffer in this regard. field. We must remember inequality, poverty, job insecurity or unemployment. Therefore, in this situation, today, more than ever, more than a shared diagnosis, concrete answers are necessary. Why? Because we are beginning to see the end of the European term of office, for this legislature, because growth is accompanying so that today we can put answers on the table very clearly, and because every time we open the polls we find the anger and disenchantment of the voters who cry out at us demanding answers. In this regard, we in the Group of European Socialists and Democrats have been very clear by proposing fiscal flexibility to promote social investment, proposing a minimum income framework that is a tool to combat poverty, and proposing mechanisms to address the gender wage gap in the centres of work and also promote dialogue and collective bargaining. These are clear proposals which have to go hand in hand with not to take a step back in the commitments that Parliament already has in the area of the European pillar of social rights or fiscal flexibility. Because we want this Parliament to be ambitious and accompany the Commission's proposals. We must remember new proposals, such as the European labour authority, or a framework of minimum conditions at European level. These analyses, these messages must be accompanied by the proposals and responses that Europeans already need to problems.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, I should like to begin by speaking on the Rules That's why I just made the mark. So if you wouldn't count that on my speaking time yet. On a point of order, I would like to comment and request that the German translation of the report be reviewed and corrected. I don't think it's right. I would like to refer here to paragraph 18 of the report. According to the German translation, “points to the fact that the rise in real wages has recently lagged behind productivity growth, even though there have been improvements in the labour market;” This is not the English original. I would like to point this out because the English original wording was intensively negotiated in the shadow rapporteurs meetings. In the original in the original, the simultaneity of these two developments has been recorded, i.e. productivity growth was stronger than wage growth, and at the same time the situation in the labour market has improved. In the German translation, on the other hand, the impression is given as if this is somehow a contradictory development or as if there is a backlog in real wages. This is exactly what we wanted to prevent in the report. I therefore believe that a German translation should mean 'during this improvement'. Thank you for your patience with this point of order. If you will allow me, I will start my speech now. Ladies and gentlemen! We have heard two very different opinions here, on the one hand from the Bulgarian Presidency and on the other from Mrs Thyssen, and I wondered how different that has been. Mrs. Thyssen, you have painted everything in the most rosy colors. Did you really say: “The banks are well capitalized”? I think there are a lot of people who see this very differently. Did you really say that unemployment is back to pre-crisis levels? I'd like to ask you to take a look at the statistics. In Italy, Spain, Greece, unemployment is now more than twice as high as ten years ago, more than twice as high as before the start of the crisis. I do not understand how you can draw such a picture. What Mrs Panayotova said was very interesting. She said: 'The internal market is a big trump card in the EU. 'I fully agree with you. But what you didn't say is: 'One big trump card is the EU's other major integration project: the euro. 'Why didn't you say 'the euro is a big trumb'? Have you forgotten to say that, or do you agree with me that the euro is not a big asset, that the euro may even be a barrier? If we look into this report that has been adopted here, paragraph 2 says exactly what is suffering in the euro area. It says: 'We have structural problems, we have insufficient growth in production potential, productivity, competitiveness, we have a lack of ambitious and socially balanced structural reforms.” Yes, you cannot talk about these things without saying at the same time: we have a currency that does not allow depreciation and thus makes it very, very, very difficult to restore competitiveness.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (NL) Mr President, where I come from, Rotterdam, the largest port in Europe, we have a very clear moral: say what you think and do what you say. Not words, but deeds. Europe can learn something from this Rotterdam mentality and can use a little Rotterdam. If we make agreements, we have to keep them. If we have a problem together, we should not talk about it endlessly, but solve it together. Only then will we be stronger. Only then will we really help Europe forward. As far as I am concerned, 'deal is agreement' should also apply to the economic policy of the European Union. Because economy is also being able to rely on each other. In order to prevent another crisis, the Member States must reform so that their economies are very resilient, even when it is down. They must put the hell to the nering and prepare for the future. Above all, let us keep each other to these agreements. Then we pull each other up instead of down. I am convinced that this is the way forward for Europe. Then, as far as I am concerned, matters such as a budget for the euro area or a further transfer of powers to Brussels are not necessary. The primary responsibility must lie where it belongs, and that is with the Member States. If the Member States reform their economies, we will benefit together. And that is exactly what people expect from Europe and from me.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I think the Employment Report acknowledges the need to bring together the Semester, the Social Pillar – as we were hearing – and also the Sustainable Development Goals: I do not think we should forget those. I welcome the Council’s recognition of the need for the greening of the economy, employment and society, and that echoes some of what is in the Employment Report. I look forward to seeing us strengthen that dimension – that just transition dimension – within the Semester. It is important for the direction of amounts of investment, of training and, indeed, the development of the society in which we live. We heard some of the challenges from a colleague earlier. Also, I think we do need to be looking to see Member States adopt national action plans to reduce child poverty, because I think when we are looking at breaking that cycle we need to be doing much more. I think it is appalling that we are still seeing in Parliament reports requests for decent nutrition for children in one of the richest regions of the world.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, although we are talking about an alleged recovery in the economy, the real question is who is benefiting this recovery in the economy. The usual ones? Multinationals? Billionaires? Because the reality that is lived outside these carpets, on the street, is a permanent crisis. The rights lost during the financial crisis have not been recovered, job precariousness continues to increase and pensions are at risk. The dizzying rise in inequality is the real challenge facing Europe. This inequality is the result of the current economic architecture of the European Union, the Stability and Growth Pact, the European Semester or new institutions, such as the European Monetary Fund, which are part of the problem and not the solution. And these are elements that are precisely separating us from this report. Because this is not settled with a small reform of the governance mechanisms. Ladies and gentlemen, in order to end the deep inequalities that are affecting Europe, we need urgent reforms, which will allow a change in the productive, socially and ecologically sustainable model, capable of creating quality employment in all Member States. A plan that cannot be implemented within the narrow frameworks of the Stability and Growth Pact or in projects, such as the Juncker plan. We regret, therefore, not being able to support the report, although we agree with many of the assertions it makes.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, the European Semester is a step towards the full economic control of France and the other 18 euro area states. Since the so-called independence of the ECB, the power of democratic control has been withdrawn from states and peoples. The 2011 debt crisis was the direct consequence of this, as the monetization of public debt has become impossible. Secondly, the irrevocable exchange rate fixing has led to deep and growing macroeconomic differences among euro area States. No corrective mechanism exists, which explains Germany's super-surpluses! Thirdly, with banking union, the power of control of banks is based in Frankfurt. Blackmail to the financial stability of banks can thus be exercised without the State being able to intervene. Cyprus in 2013 and Greece in 2015 are the cases of school. Finally, States' budgetary margins for manoeuvre are being phased out. Since the Maastricht 3% criterion, Germany has obtained both the fiscal pact and the European Semester: a tank tank that does not work. The next step will be the establishment, with the help of Mr Macron, of a European Monetary Fund which will be a camisole which will force states to submit to a “schlagger-like” fiscal policy.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, the report on the European Semester's inexpensive wishes for so-called wage increases are reminiscent of the anecdote of the fair development of SYRIZA in Greece. He says we will get out of the memorandum, but we will return to the European semester of the supremacy of permanent guardianship and memoranda. The European Social Pillar, its social indicators, require another increase in retirement ages, a generalisation of flexible employment and mobility, i.e. migration and uprooting, a friendly business environment — see the abolition of the right to strike, led by SYRIZA in Greece— abolishing collective agreements and linking wage to profits — that is always a victim of earnings — poor the unemployed, the few employed, now poor and the fully-employed with medicine — the minimum income of misery. You say 'chance to recover, to deal with debt', other measures and thousands of auctions in Greece; free money and tax breaks for capital. Fight against tax evasion? Foolery! Panama is excluded from tax havens. Respect of the Stability Pact and reforms, which workers are supposed to make their own assumption, are a permanent cause. Workers have one affair: organising and fighting for increases and collective agreements, overturning this policy.

name: David CASA
text: — Sur President, iva matul is-sena li gЂaddiet rajna li FL-unjoni Ewropea l-qagda tal-impjiegi qiegЂda titjieb. Qegdin ukoll naraw inqas faqar FL-ewropa u inqas esklużjon sojali kif qalet tajjeb il-kummissarju, però dan biżejed? Użgur li le. Naturalment kif intqal qabli gandna rata golja ta' enodiema żgilli mhumiex qegdin isibu x-xogol. Gandna problema tal-faqar fost it-tfal kif qalet il-kollega tieguttai Lambert, però naturalment irridu nkomplu u u ma nieqfux hawn. Irridu nkomplu naraw illi pereżempju l-investiment isir wiearvaed illi jara titjib fis-swieq tal-prodotti u s-servizzi u dan biex iwassal giheal tkabbir fit-tul u anke biex jgihein biex l-infiq tal-fond pubblio jsir iktar sostenibbli. Irridu naraw kif nginu lill-kumpaniji żgЂar u medji gŵyl aliex naturalment dawn jothe olqu enoafna impjiegi FL-Ewropa. Irridu naraw illi l-ekonomija tagna u l-iżvilupp tagЂha jimxu id f'id iva mar-realtajiet so- jali lil hinn mill-politika tal-populiżmu, imma rridu ngarfu li s-sathe the the tal-ekonomija tagthe tiddependi fuegq kemm inkunu qi in nitrattaw l-ekonomija fir-realtajiet illi jeżistu bthe alissa FL-ewropa. Jiena nashort seb illi jekk nadmu flimkien u ma mmorrux la f'estrem u lanqas f'iethe the f'ie- or, is-suessi li kellna matul din l-aar sena terthe a' tirrepeti ruto ha jekk Alla jrid is-sena d-diethe.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you have made the European Semester a good element for analysis, but you are unable to solve the problems you denounce through the Semester. They denounce the high precariousness of employment, but refuse to put on the table a directive on fair conditions that will end it throughout the European Union. They denounce low wages as a risk to economic growth and also to social cohesion, but refuse to pursue a policy of coordination of wages or to establish a European minimum wage framework that will end low wages. They denounce the high risk of social exclusion, but refuse to put on the table a minimum income directive or to finance national income policies that end the risk of poverty that exists in the second economy in the world. They must step forward and stop being good analysts and become good politicians, good politicians who solve people's problems. This is why the European Semester was created, not only to analyze reality, but to end the inequalities we denounce through this political instrument.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President! The European Semester is an annual process designed to improve the economic and social performance of the EU. The main report this year is appropriate and we will support it. However, as shadow rapporteur for the EMPL Committee, I only have to assess the labour and social policy recommendations. Eight years ago, the euro crisis broke out. It has caused permanent damage to Europe, and more specifically to the eurozone Member States. It has shown that, in a very heterogeneous economic area, a single currency does not make sense for all countries and regions. States and regions have specific problems and need specific solutions to them. My committee's proposals go in the opposite direction. All demands are aimed at increasing competences and responsibilities at EU level. Wherever there is a problem, the call for centralisation and intra-European redistribution is being voiced. Examples include calls for European unemployment insurance, more skills for the new European Labour Market Authority, and more resources for the social pillar. In no case is there any need to reduce EU competences or even save resources. This is the wrong signal with regard to the lack of cash flow due to Brexit. Citizenship, citizen-centred democracy and national or regional responsibilities need to be strengthened and not undermined.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, the proclamation of the European Pillar of Social Rights opens up new opportunities for us. Among the goals of the European Semester are structural reforms to create more jobs and growth. The pillar aims to provide equal opportunities on the labour market to improve social protection and inclusion.  The challenges of balanced economic growth and social protection are closely interconnected, since poverty undermines economic development. In addition, poverty is a security risk. Poverty reduces the people’s trust in the European project and prevents support for important reforms. Poverty degrades human dignity and is not compatible with the European values that we defend in this institution. Poverty distorts democratic processes and gives a chance to irresponsible populists. Therefore, the pillar should become an important and necessary tool for ensuring a better future for Europe.  At the moment, the 20 principles of the pillar are important, but not legally binding declarations. To start the work of the pillar, we need legislative initiatives from the Commission. The progress of the country-specific recommendations shows that the Member States are reluctant to implement advice that is not based on legally binding norms. If there are no legislative initiatives, the pillar becomes an empty formality. Without a doubt, we cannot afford that now.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Bayet, for his great work in trying to get Parliament together on a European Semester report, which is not always very easy. I think we managed to do very well, and I would like to thank him for that also – although he is now very much occupied, of course, but that is all right! On the plus side, what the report very clearly states is that there is more room for public investment. What is also a very important message to the Member States is that we really have to take the public investments agenda seriously now. Also, if you look at the Pillar of Social Rights and the implementation of that, I think the report has some good recommendations, equally that the reforms should be socially and environmentally just and also with the implementation of the Paris Agreement. Where the report is a bit weaker is on the reform of the Stability and Growth Pact, where we really know that reform is still very much needed. Also, on tax avoidance and the fight that Europe has to lead there, the report should be strengthened. On the annual anti-corruption report, I think the Commission should really take its responsibility to fight corruption within Europe. We tabled some amendments, and with that we can have a very good report adopted.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, last November at the Gothenburg show we celebrated the declaration of the European social pillar. Now no more fiestas and down the masks! The time of truth has come. We are adopting the report which calls for economic policy planning for the Member States to finally incorporate economic policies. The progressive groups in the European Parliament have managed to improve the text considerably; we have adopted the self-evident legislation, the funding to achieve the objectives, as the pillar says in its preamble, that it is needed to make the declaration a reality. However, the Conservative groups want to abolish them in tomorrow's vote in plenary. Mr. Tear off his clothes. Verhofstadt for Europe but let us say: How can we have social policies without legislation? Today Mr. Timmermans ended the debate on the summit by saying that the Europe of values must come to the fore. We are waiting on 22 March for the Heads of State or Government to tell us how we are going to build this Europe of values, and that is where the position of each country and every party will be clearly seen. This will show which part of society each of us supports and who is pulling Europe back.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner. The current analysis of the European Semester is positive in terms of economic policy. The economy has grown steadily over the past 18 quarters. An upturn is evident in all Member States. Unemployment has reached its lowest level in ten years, almost pre-crisis levels. This applies to both longterm and youth unemployment. The good economic situation is conducive to public finances and investment. In the 2018 European Semester Country Reports, three Member States report excessive imbalances and only eight Member States. Progress is being made in key areas such as fiscal policy, fiscal governance, financial services and improved access to finance, leading to a higher level of implementation of the country-specific recommendations. However, there are also weaknesses, namely the continued high level of public and private debt and the sluggish implementation of structural reforms, lack of productivity and competitiveness. Further reforms are therefore necessary, especially in times of good economic activity.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Madam Minister! I would like to say, first of all, that I very much share the theses in this year's economic growth analysis, as well as both reports prepared by our colleagues Mr Hugues Bayet and Mr Krzysztof Hetman. I would like to thank them so much for that. In its analysis, the Commission forges an optimistic picture of the economic situation in the European Union. We have reason to please. Growth remains fairly high, exceeding the eurozone's growth rate even in the United States for the first time. However, please note that every recovery has its end, and the current period of economic recovery in the United States is already over 103 months. This is, at the moment, the second ever longest period of prosperity. Therefore, sooner or later there will be a slowdown. And in this context, I want to say that Europe is not quite prepared for this economic downturn, which will surely be affected by the European continent in four, six, eight quarters. I see two threat areas. Firstly, investments where we see weak momentum. The level of investment is still below the level of the 2007-08 period, which is 10 years ago. And that's the first cause for concern. The second reason is very high debt, especially the private sector. I would like to point out that the ratio of borrowing to GDP in the private sector in the European Union has increased by 10% over the past seven years and 20% in the euro area. These are two areas we need to address through structural action because otherwise we won't be prepared for the coming recession.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Mr President, if it were up to me, the Annual Growth Survey would be called the Sustainable Growth Survey, because that is what we should be aiming for – not just any growth, but sustainable, inclusive growth: growth that benefits not just the top, but also those at the bottom. Growth based on quality jobs, not on precarious jobs which will pay the rent but harm the soul. I am an optimist by nature, but in my view the picture painted in the eight years is overly optimistic. Doing better does not yet mean doing well when it comes to poverty precariousness and inequality, and I am sure that the pensioners in Greece and the young graduates in Spain will know what I am talking about, as will the Romanian truck drivers and the workers in the Bulgarian garment sector.  Our internal market has brought some benefits, but also a huge number of disadvantages. We need European social policy to counterbalance this, which is why I am glad that today the Commission presented a recommendation on access to social protection. This is a first step towards the social sustainable Europe that I have in mind, but more is needed: we need binding social floors in our Member States which guarantee social protection for all, and don’t just aim for it.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr President! The report raises the right issues concerning job growth and decent jobs, poverty reduction, support for people from extreme age groups, increasing access to education, concern for small and medium-sized entrepreneurs, integration of disabled people in the labour market or initiative for the Digital Single Market. Eurostat estimates that 44% of Europeans do not have digital skills, while 90% of all jobs require them to own. But it is hard to agree that the European pillar of social rights is designed to complement national social security systems. Its inclusion in the procedures of the European semester will be an attempt to push for uniform standards in social policy, which, after all, remains within the competence of the Member States. Union or national regulations must not create new barriers in the internal market and thereby weaken the competitiveness of the European Union economy. And the process of building an economic and monetary union must be transparent and consistent with the principles of the single market.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Mr President! First of all, the EU employment rate reached over 72% in the second half of 2017. That's 235 million employees. The policy of soundness and solidarity has borne fruit. The EU is on the path of growth, as evidenced by the European Semester. But the bad news is that the situation is very different from one Member State to another. For this reason, economic structures are under scrutiny. In order to avoid negative developments in the future, best practice experience will be collected and positive driving forces identified. One of the problem groups is still the longterm unemployed. They belong in the focus. We need more social investment. The average rate of youth unemployment is also too high in the eurozone, at 17.9%. We have made a strong support for the Youth Guarantee in the European Parliament. The resulting Youth Employment Initiative has now grown to 8.8 billion euros. There must be more qualitative jobs and better productivity in many companies, especially in rural areas, as an important prerequisite for rising wages, which, however, fall within the competence of the social partners. Let us face up to other challenges, such as eliminating social inequality and reducing the risk of poverty in large parts of the European Union!

name: Jakob von WEIZSÄCKER
text: – Mr President, when the economic crisis hit us about a decade ago, euro Humpty Dumpty was sitting on a wall. We rushed to prevent him from falling and only just managed to do so. Today he is still sitting there, starting to be in a better mood, as witnessed in the Annual Growth Survey 2018. That is excellent news. By 2020, he may even start smiling. But just watching his cyclical mood swings is not enough; we need him to climb down that wall safely. In order to achieve this, we will need to complete banking union, both in terms of risk reduction and risk sharing, but more fundamentally we need greater clarity about who is in charge of what in the euro area. What should the role of monetary policy be in the next crisis? What should be the role of markets absorbing shocks? What should be the role of various elements of an enhanced European fiscal capacity? Which of these elements should be automatic, which discretionary, and which ones tied to nationality and how? And how do we assure democratic legitimacy and accountability? Many possible answers to these questions have already been put forward by the Commission, by this House and by various expert groups. Last year, President Macron was elected. Tomorrow, a new German government will be formed. The time has come finally to put the necessary elements together and help Humpty Dumpty climb down that wall safely.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, let’s make it very clear that new jobs and social security will never come from legislation on social issues or on labour markets on a European level; it will only come via the reforms that enable new entrepreneurship, investments and innovations. And let’s be very clear about the differences we see in Europe today: we have Member States with a high level of growth, and we have Member States who are still suffering from the crisis and from the problems coming from that. The main problems are coming from the fact that we have a lack of structural reforms. What we need is cohesion or structural reforms, giving opportunities for a convergence of growth, and we need to have higher targets: we need to set targets for higher levels of potential growth, and this can only be done if we are secure, if we are more attractive for investments, if we are more open for entrepreneurship, or if we create labour markets that are open for new jobs and more flexible. We can do it: we can see that a number of Member States who were hit by the crisis have recovered, and other Member States have gone quite well. The recovery we see today is fragile because of monetary policy. Now we need to make it stable by structural reforms.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the data contained in the annual growth analysis for 2018 confirm some trends: the European economy is recovering in all countries, the beneficial effects of this recovery are distributed extremely unequally within society, there remain very strong regional and territorial disparities within the Union. The aim of the European Semester is to ensure convergence and stability in the European Union by coordinating the economic policies of its Member States. To date, however, this objective remains on paper, if it is not accompanied by real benefits for citizens, just as it has purely theoretical value a growth in the economy not accompanied by a reduction in the level of poverty, precariousness, social exclusion, increased wage levels, improving the conditions of the most vulnerable groups. We use this data to make policies aimed at the needs of society and we do not allow the European semester to be just accounting and bureaucracy. Without greater convergence and social cohesion there can be no future for Europe.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: Mr President, as our colleague Thomas Mann said, the latest data on the employment rate confirm the upward trend and the success of European policies in recent years, and the need to continue with them, focusing increasingly on social aspects. That is why I would like to focus my speech on the nearly 120 million people who are still at risk of poverty or social exclusion, especially children. Job creation, which is mainly occurring among the best qualified adults, contrasts with the difficulty of entering the least qualified. The implementation of the new Capacity Agenda for Europe must therefore be a priority. However, in order to truly reduce poverty, we need long-term policies that contribute to the effective and sustainable integration of the farthest, policies that must have the active collaboration of specialized NGOs and organizations of people living in poverty themselves. We need to combine active employment policies with social policies, to ensure equal opportunities in all spheres, to ensure non-discrimination, especially as regards access and promotion in the labour market.

name: Michael DETJEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner. First of all, the Annual Growth Survey presented today is a step backwards in terms of employment and social policy objectives compared to the results achieved in recent years. I would have liked a more ambitious project. The requirements for a social Europe must be identified and must be a top priority. The fight against unemployment and poverty should be mentioned, and the guarantee of living wages that people can really live on. Ten years after the outbreak of the European financial crisis, the low-wage sector continues to grow. Poverty despite work is a scandal in Europe, but unfortunately all too often a reality. Europe can and must take countermeasures here. That is why my group has long been calling for an EU directive on fair working conditions, for all workers, including precarious workers. This includes our call for a minimum income and access to social protection for all. Poverty and unemployment are dangerous not only for economic growth, but for the whole European project.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. The European Commission has been claiming for some time that it wants to move away from a number of incoherent individual recommendations during the European Semester and wants to move towards a coherent pan-European approach. With the package that was released last week, I now have the feeling in some places that could succeed. For the first time in its country reports, the European Commission has examined seven Member States for aggressive tax arrangements: Belgium, Cyprus, Hungary, Ireland, Luxembourg, Malta and the Netherlands. The European Commission's name European tax evoters for the first time is a novelty. So far, the Commission has always claimed — I have a letter from Commissioner Moscovici — that there are no tax havens in the European Union. I am glad that the Commission has now carried out a reality check during the European Semester. This means that it is already a little further than the Council of Ministers, which this week has once again reduced its black list of tax havens by three countries. However, I now expect the Commission not to leave it with these findings. In the country-specific recommendations, the Commission must clearly identify the shortcomings and call for ambitious reforms. You can't stand halfway here. It is all the more important that the country-specific recommendations are actually implemented. We in the European Parliament are ready to help in this.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Hugues Bayet's report makes it possible to identify how critical the issue of the recovery of public investment is, including the mobilization of room for manoeuvre in countries where surpluses today exist. First, because it is public investment that stimulates private investment, but also because it is the one that will enable us to succeed in the ecological and social transition, defend our social model and create jobs. Ultimately, the proposal we are making today is a balanced proposal in its economic, social and environmental dimensions, which ultimately contributes to the establishment of a sustainable model. To this end, the creation of the European Semester is a factor that must be used in its full potential. It is also for this reason that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, for the first time this year, is proposing to you to use it concretely to combat inequalities, to articulate the recommendations that the Commission will make to the various Member States, with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals, or to use these recommendations to combat discrimination in the labour market, particularly between men and women. Finally, I would like to point out how, for us, the question of responsible management of public finances over the long term must be compatible with rising wages. We're not the only ones who say so. Still, in the Council, you must be able to help us be heard.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: — Mr President, Europe is no longer a concern for the rest of the world in terms of economic growth and reduction of unemployment. But, as you have pointed out, Commissioner, we still have countries with excessive imbalances and countries where youth unemployment is still unacceptable. Moreover, Europe, we must admit, is lagging behind in terms of productivity growth. That is why I believe that the European Semester is the powerful instrument by which, in a coordinated manner at Union level, each Member State acts to create incentives to increase productivity and, in general, for a better standard of living. I believe that in the discussions that we are going to have on the future of the Union, the European Commission and my colleagues in Parliament must come up with solutions to strengthen the responsibility of the Member States to fulfil the recommendations that are made in the framework of the European Semester.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to make three points. Firstly, the reports show us very clearly that only two thirds of the country-specific recommendations have been largely implemented by the Member States. This is at a time when the European economy is growing faster than in the last decade. This is at a time when unemployment has been at its lowest level since 2009, at 10.5%, and we had the lowest interest rates. It is time to fully implement structural reforms and to comply with the country-specific measures. Secondly, the European Semester is a process, and I therefore welcome the fact that, for the first time, the priorities of the Pillar of Social Rights are being taken into account and that, as has already been mentioned, many Member States are being monitored for aggressive tax management. Yes, we are improving the European Semester. My third point is that the European Semester is essential for economic policy coordination in the Member States, and for addressing the challenges and the need for action. However, it does not replace the development of monetary union into a full economic and social union. I therefore call for the House of the Banking Union to finish the House of the Banking Union, adopt the new missing measures of the Capital Markets Union, and deepen the Economic, Social and Monetary Union. Solid economies are also addressing their weaknesses in good times and especially in these. We still have some work to do and we also need an efficient sanction mechanism.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, I strongly welcome the emphasis Mr Hetman’s report places on the crucial role of education and economic development, labour market access and individual wellbeing. As the latest CSRs for my country warn, beside the distorting effects of undeclared work, it is a weak education and vocational development sector that weighs most on long-term competitiveness, growth and convergence. Despite being a persistent area of past recommendations, only limited progress has been achieved in what concerns basic skills, high early school leaving, Roma inclusion and rural—urban disparities in education. It does not help either that, instead of being a respected education and career pathway for young professionals, vocational education remains only a second—choice option and, in most cases, is not adapted to labour market needs. I sincerely hope that we will take more heed of advice in these areas and stop practices that jeopardise our future.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the functioning of the euro area has led to increased deficits and debts in the European South, with armies of poor and unemployed. In contrast, Germany, in breach of the Stability Pact, has 8.5% surpluses. Greece has turned into a vast social cemetery, with youth unemployment hitting the ceiling. In order for the Greek people to have a future, they must abolish the memoranda, write off the shameful debt and claim a special status within the European Union and the Eurozone; a special relationship with exceptions for certain sectors of the Greek economy, in order to the Greek people breathe, a special relationship that will lead to the recovery of national monetary sovereignty within the euro, with the Bank of Greece conducting an autonomous monetary policy up to the level of the bank's share capital of the European Central Bank. Only under these conditions can Greece have a future within the European Union and the eurozone, a European Union which must build a social Europe and not exclude Panama from the list of tax havens.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members for this very rich debate. Many Members mentioned the problem of aggressive tax planning. This Parliament has been very vocal in trying to root out tax evasion and tax avoidance, and I agree with you. The erosion of the tax base is one reason why resources for essential public services have been squeezed. This year the Commission has stressed the issue of aggressive tax planning in seven European Member States in their country reports. These are practices that we know have the potential to undermine fairness and the level playing field in our internal market and they increased the burden on the EU taxpayers. It is also a recognised fact that important steps are being taken by Member States across the Union to halt the tide of tax avoidance. But you can count on us to continue working alongside Member States to make this a reality. Let us not spoil the window of opportunity. Acknowledging that the legacy of the crisis is still visible in some Member States and that gross disposable household income has not returned to pre-crisis levels in all parts of Europe. But now is the time for increasing convergence and strengthening resilience for bad times. Now is the time to implement reforms, including those linked to the pillar, to strengthen social resilience, to support and empower entrepreneurs and workers and other citizens, women and men, young and old alike, wherever they are born so that they can embrace the changes of the 21st century, and no longer have to fear them. We can only succeed if we act together, and thus our dialogue does not stop today. Our intention is to pursue dialogue with you, the European Parliament, with Member States, with national parliaments, with social partners and all relevant stakeholders throughout the cycle of the Semester. Likewise, we encourage Member States to involve social partners and civil society in the definition and implementation of major reforms. The European Parliament’s active participation in the debate on the annual growth survey is important. I salute the work done by the rapporteurs, by the committees and the Members involved in the drafting of the reports. Your insights and views are very valuable to feed into our work on the European Semester. In recent years, at the height of the crisis as well as in the current more favourable conditions, the European Semester has proven instrumental to foster, guide and support reform processes in Member States. I look forward to continuing our constructive dialogue in the coming months.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, before making my concluding remarks I would like to respond to the questions specifically addressed for my attention by Mr Lucke.  I would like to say that the future of the European monetary union is a question of interest for all European citizens, so we will work on creating optimal conditions for strong and sustainable economic growth in the European Union, through initiatives to strengthen the European monetary union. In March, leaders of the euro area will hold an open debate on long—term issues that are specific to the euro area, and work on the follow-up to the December Euro Summit is ongoing, with a view to a first set of decisions by the leaders in June.  Concerning my concluding remarks, I would like to thank you very much for your remarks. You addressed important points and your remarks will provide valuable input for discussions in the Council that touch upon many aspects of the European Semester, such as education, employment – with particular accent on youth employment – competitiveness, environmental and social policies. The Country Reports published by the Commission last week represent the next important step in the current European Semester. They formed the basis for the work which will eventually lead to the adoption of this Semester’s country—specific recommendations during the summer. When working on the European Semester and debating the country specific recommendations, we should always remember the importance of reaching as many citizens as possible, to increase national ownership. So I commend the initiatives taken in this regard, including the increased dialogue in the capitals and the consultations with the social partners.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: rapporteur. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, thank you for these discussions. In conclusion, I would like to say that while economic expansion is stronger in 2018, inequalities between our fellow citizens are still far too present and therefore within the framework of the Semester coordination tool and with this marked economic improvement, I think we cannot be mistaken. I believe that we really need strong actions — as you said, Commissioner — balanced and inclusive, and there is still much to be done on this, but I am particularly pleased — and this is partly thanks to you, Mrs Thyssen — the full integration of the social pillar and its 14 indicators into the full integration of the social pillar and its 14 indicators into the European Semester because, contrary to what some people think, social is not just an expenditure but can also be an engine of the economy. There have been numerous studies which have shown that an investment of 2% of European GDP in the social sector would create nearly 20 million jobs in Europe, including women's jobs. So it was more than time, if we really want to be effective, to analyze our economic policies from a social and environmental perspective, and of course I welcome that. Finally, I hope that the Commission and the Council will follow us in strong measures for the benefit of Europeans. I think there is the survival of Europe.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: rapporteur. — Mr President! First of all, I would like to thank you for today's interesting debate, the European Commission for preparing a comprehensive and balanced annual growth analysis, as well as my colleagues and fellow Members from other political groups for working together on this important report. Today's debate has clearly shown that all of us is a single goal of an economically strong European Union, which cares for its citizens and wants to ensure a decent life, stable employment and access to quality social services. I am very pleased that today during the debate, the issue related to care and children in general has resounded several times. Personally, however, I am a proponent of the pragmatic approach and the so-called golden measure. For I believe that by setting ourselves too ambitious and unrealistic objectives, we risk simply not being able to achieve them, by which means we will remain in the same place instead of moving closer to the goal. On the other hand, by focusing too much on one aspect, be it the economy or social issues, we can neglect the latter, which will also cause a valuable balance between the two. For we must remember that the economy and social issues are closely intertwined and dependent on each other. We can't have strong social policies if we don't have a strong economy, and vice versa. I think in the report on the annual growth analysis we have been able to reflect this need for a balanced approach. That's why I'm counting on your support in tomorrow's vote.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: The joint debate is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. I would like to thank the ladies and the interpreters for their professionalism and dedication, and for safeguarding the collective interests, once again, of this House. Written statements (Rule 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. — The figures speak positively and show that the EU employment rate is growing and reached 72.3% in the second quarter of 2017 with a total of 235.4 million employees, which represents progress towards the Europe 2020 target of the 75% employment rate. The rise in employment growth is more significant among older workers, high-skilled workers and men, while it is weaker among young, low-skilled workers and women, whose advancement should continue to work. However, despite the slight improvement in employment, the youth unemployment rate remains worryingly high and is 16.6% and 18.7% respectively in the euro area. The 2018 Annual Growth Survey, together with the Integrated European Pillar of Social Rights, is an important part of overall policies for quality jobs, sustainable growth and investment, aimed at increasing productivity and wages, creating jobs, reducing inequality and poverty, and improving social protection and access to public services and their quality. I also consider this report to be an important indicator for Member States as to what they should take into account when drawing up their national policies and reform plans. Particular emphasis should be placed on adapting education policy and improving the framework for acquiring skills, especially digital ones, which are extremely necessary at the present time.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. — The facts speak for themselves: Hungarian data are orders of magnitude better than the EU: youth unemployment in the euro area is 18.7%, in my country 10.7%! The EU calls on Member States to reduce taxes on food, which is an important measure for social justice. This has already been achieved in Hungary: in 2017 the VAT rate for poultry meat, eggs and fresh milk decreased to 5%. In 2018, VAT on live fish, fish fillets and domestic pork offal will decrease. In 2015, 119 million people in the EU were at risk of poverty or social exclusion, which is far from the goal of the Europe 2020 strategy. Since 2008, the number of poor has increased by two million, while 2.5 million migrants have arrived from outside the EU in a single year, and most of them have come from outside the EU, untrained. Therefore, Hungary does not want to become an immigrant country either. My country is also at the forefront in the distribution of produced goods: according to the law, if GDP growth is higher than 3.5%, pensioners will receive a pension premium. I am pleased that the report is asking Member States to increase the inclusion of people with disabilities in the labour market, and we must do everything we can to do in the future.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. — On 13 March 2018, the European Parliament called on the Commission to strengthen its surveillance of European nations. Announced goal: even more austerity and an attack on pension systems. Indeed, the long economic and financial crisis in Europe has shown that the competence of the Commission's' experts' is limited in economic matters. Massive immigration, wage freezing, pension planing have not revived growth. The most dynamic countries in the world, such as China, are acting contrary to the Commission's recommendations. China has applied the national preference without immigration, and it has grown by more than 6% each year since 1991. Revitalising Europe will be through European preference and the launch of new industries. For proof, Ariane was born in 1973 from cooperation between 8 Member States of the European Union, Switzerland and Norway, outside the auspices of the Brussels Commission.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: in writing. — If the EU wants to compete with a competitive and efficient market economy like the USA, it should first be necessary to ensure the functioning of the European internal market. The EU's competitiveness problems are extensive, complex and profound. The debate should draw attention to key internal market barriers, which are manifested as a large fluctuation in prices within the EU. Such barriers include market fragmentation due to language and cultural differences, as well as indirect barriers to trade and entry, such as derogatory regulation or favoured by local producers. Apparent solutions, such as the payment of various subsidies to a wide range of destinations such as regional development, investment support, bank support, new institutions and governance, will weaken Europe in the long run, even if the goal has been good. Unless the subsidies are optimally allocated to education, research and technology development, they will only increase spending and inefficiency. Immigration policy also needs more attention. If it could succeed, it would be the best social, education and security policy in all EU countries.
